In addition to the grounds for revocation set forth in Section 3-1-15 of this Title, a taxicab operator's license may be revoked for:
A. Three (3) or more violations of the provisions of chapter 11, Rules of the Road, of the Illinois Vehicle Code2, or for any violation of sections 5/11-501 or
5/11-503 of the Illinois Vehicle Code expressly incorporated herein by reference.
B. The operation in the Village of any vehicle which has not been certified by a State approved testing facility to be in compliance with all of the safety
requirements of chapter 12 of the Illinois Vehicle Code3. (1984 Code)

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 90/702
Chapter 12
BUS SERVICES
3-12-1: LICENSE REQUIRED, EXCEPTIONS:
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in Section 3-1-1 of this Title, no license shall be required for the following:
A. The business of operating a scheduled school bus service within the corporate limits of the Village.
B. The business of operating a scheduled bus service for the transportation of persons within the corporate limits of the Village, where such business
service is otherwise being regulated by the Illinois Commerce Commission and/or the Interstate Commerce Commission. (1984 Code)
3-12-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
In addition to the information required under Section 3-1-3 of this Title, an application for a license under this Chapter shall contain the following
information:
A. A list of the names and addresses of all governmental units and all agencies or authorities organized thereunder that license and/or franchise the
applicant for the operation of a bus service for the transportation of persons.
B. A copy of the applicant's most recent financial statements, including but not limited to: balance sheet, profit and loss statement and statement of
changes in financial condition, for the most recent fiscal year available.
C. A listing of fares, routes, schedules and the location of all proposed boarding locations and stops under which the applicant proposes to operate,
including a map showing the proposed routes.
D. A list of the type of vehicles which the applicant proposes to utilize during the term of the license, including a full and complete description of such
equipment, and the certificate of safety for each vehicle as required in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/13-101.
E. Each application shall contain such additional information as may be needed for the proper guidance of the Village officials in the issuing of the license.
All applications shall be signed by the applicant or its duly authorized representative and verified by oath or affidavit. (1984 Code)
3-12-3: FEE PERIOD:
A. The license fee provided in Section 3-1-1 of this Title shall be in lieu of any other vehicle fee required by this Title, including parking fees for parking in
the Municipal Commuter Parking Lot. The Village Clerk shall issue suitable tags or stickers for the number of buses covered by each license. Such tag
or sticker shall be displayed in the right front windshield on each bus while it is in use.
B. The licensee shall notify the Clerk of the motor number and State license number of each bus operated and of the corresponding Village tag or sticker
number. (1984 Code)
3-12-4: ROUTES:
A. The issuance of a license shall be deemed to be approval of those routes specified in the application for license. Upon the issuance of a license under
this Chapter, the licensee shall file with the Village Clerk a map or diagram showing the routes to be served. Each street, road or highway shall be
identified and any public transportation service within two (2) miles of the route(s) shall be shown or mentioned.
B. Should any licensee desire to make any changes in its routes, the licensee shall first submit a revised route plan to the Village Board and receive its
approval prior to placing said revised route plan into effect. Residents, carriers or other operators and interested individuals shall be given an
opportunity to voice approval or objections to the proposed route change. (1984 Code)
3-12-5: LOCATION OF STOPS:
The location of all bus stops shall be subject to regulation and approval by the President and Board of Trustees. (1984 Code)
3-12-6: REGULATION OF OPERATORS:
No person shall operate any bus unless such person has a valid license issued by the State with a proper classification to permit the operation of such
vehicle. (1984 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 91/702
3-12-7: TRAFFIC REGULATIONS:
Unless otherwise provided by the Village, operations conducted under the provisions of this Chapter shall be exempt from compliance with Village vehicle
or axle weight restrictions on Village streets. However, each licensee shall observe all speed restrictions and other traffic regulations imposed by the
Village within the Village. (1984 Code)
3-12-8: MAINTENANCE OF PUBLIC WAYS:
The Village reserves the right to maintain the streets, alleys, public ways and facilities located within its corporate limits in such a manner as the Village
shall, in its exclusive discretion, determine. The Village shall not be liable to any licensee for any interruption in service or for interference with the
operation of any licensee's bus transportation system arising in any manner, directly or indirectly, out of the use or maintenance by the Village of the
streets, alleys, public ways and facilities located within the corporate limits of the Village. (1984 Code)
3-12-9: EMERGENCY ROUTE CHANGES:
A. In extraordinary circumstances and on a temporary basis, a licensee may deviate from its authorized routes without formal approval of a route change.
Deviations, however, shall be limited to:
1. A temporary closing of a road by virtue of construction, paving or weather conditions.
2. The temporary establishment of one-way traffic on any road.
B. In the event of a temporary deviation of a route, a licensee shall make every effort to notify passengers of the change and to resume the regular route
operations at the earliest practicable moment.
C. Whenever any licensee has cause to believe that any temporary route change will become permanent, the licensee shall apply for a permanent route
change as specified in subsection 3-12-4B. (1984 Code)
3-12-10: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
No person or entity shall operate a bus transportation service in the Village unless he or it maintains in effect at all times insurance coverage as follows:
Any licensee operating a bus transportation service under this Chapter shall defend, indemnify, protect and save harmless the Village, its officials, officers,
employees, agents, consultants and volunteers working on behalf of the Village, from and against liability, losses, physical damage to property and bodily
injury or death to persons, including payments made under any worker's compensation law, which may arise out of the licensee's operation of its bus
transportation service within or without the limits of the Village. Each licensee shall further indemnify and hold harmless the Village, its officials, officers,
employees, agents, consultants and volunteers while acting on behalf of the Village from and against any liability or losses sustained as a direct or indirect
result of the action of the licensee's agents or employees or in any way arising out of the granting of his license. Each licensee shall carry commercial
general liability and business automobile liability insurance with an insurance company licensed to do business in the State, said insurance company
having a rating of B+:VII or better in the latest edition of the Best & Co. Insurance Guide, with policy limits for the commercial general liability insurance of
not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit per occurrence for bodily injury, personal injury and property damage with a general
aggregate limit of no less than two million dollars ($2,000,000.00). The policy limits for the business automobile liability insurance shall be not less than
one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit for bodily injury and property damage. Such insurance to be utilized to protect the licensee and
the Village, its officials, officers, employees, agents, consultants and volunteers while acting on behalf of the Village, as their interests may appear, from
and against all claims, demands, actions, judgments, costs, expenses and liabilities, including, without limitation, attorney's fees which may arise or result
directly or indirectly from or by reason of any such liability, loss, injury or damage. Said policy shall contain a provision requiring the insured to notify the
Village not less than ten (10) days prior to cancellation or change of any policy. The Village, its officials, officers, employees, agents, consultants and
volunteers while acting on behalf of the Village, shall appear as additional named insureds under each policy. At least ten (10) days prior to commencing
any operations in the Village, the licensee shall provide the Village with certificates of insurance for each policy. Each licensee shall also carry such
insurance as may be necessary to protect it and the Village from all claims under the worker's compensation laws from time to time in effect that may be
applicable to the licensee. All insurance required by this Chapter shall be and remain in full force and effect for the entire period of the license. The
certificate(s) of insurance, and, if requested by the Village Attorney, the policies of insurance, or a certified copy or copies thereof, shall be approved by the
Village Attorney and shall be deposited with and kept on file by the Village Clerk. (Ord. 96-14, 2-6-1996)
3-12-11: BUS FARES:
Bus fares shall not exceed the following rate limits without approval of the Village for service from the Village to downtown Chicago and return:
Monthly service $100.00
Weekly service 25.00
(1984 Code)
Chapter 13
ASPHALT PLANTS
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 92/702
3-13-1: HOURS OF OPERATION:
It shall be unlawful to operate any such plant at any time between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. or at any time on
Sunday. (1984 Code)
3-13-2: REQUIREMENTS:
No such plant shall be operated unless it is equipped with adequate devices in good working order to prevent the escape of dense smoke, noxious fumes,
soot or dust in accordance with the more stringent of: 1) the regulations of the Zoning Ordinance, or 2) the rules and regulations of the Illinois
Environmental Protection Agency. (1984 Code)
Chapter 14
FACTORIES, MACHINE SHOPS
3-14-1: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
In addition to the information required under Section 3-1-3, an application for a factory license shall include the number of employees of such factory on
every shift. If requested by the Village Clerk, the applicant shall furnish certified copies of all payroll records required by law to be furnished to the State of
Illinois; provided, however, that only those records need be furnished which indicate the number of employees of such licensee. (1984 Code)
Chapter 15
REDI-MIX PLANTS
3-15-1: HOURS OF OPERATION:
It shall be unlawful to operate any such plant at any time between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. or at any time on
Sunday.
3-15-2: REQUIREMENTS:
No such plant shall be operated unless it is equipped with adequate devices in good working order to prevent the escape of dense smoke, noxious fumes,
soot or dust in accordance with the more stringent of 1) the regulations of the Bartlett Zoning Ordinance, or 2) the rules and regulations of the Illinois
Environmental Protection Agency. (1984 Code)
Chapter 16
QUARRIES, GRAVEL PITS AND MINING OPERATIONS
3-16-1: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
In addition to the information required under Section 3-1-3, the application shall state thereon the location of the quarry, gravel pit or mining operation and
shall contain a statement by the applicant that all of the requirements of this Chapter have been complied with.
3-16-2: RECORDS MAINTAINED:
Every person or other entity maintaining or operating a quarry, gravel pit or mining operation shall maintain records indicating:
A. The identity of every entity which hauls gravel, sand, clay, dirt or other materials ("gravel") from such quarry, gravel pit or mining operation ("gravel pit"),
the address of such entity.
B. The identity of the liability insurance carrier of such entity, the policy number, limits and expiration date of each policy.
C. The empty weight of each vehicle operated by such entity on the Village streets.
D. The gross weight of each such vehicle when it leaves the quarry, gravel pit or mining operation.
E. The number of trips made by each gravel truck operator each day.
3-16-3: GRAVEL TRUCK OPERATIONS, BOND REQUIRED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 93/702
Every person or other entity maintaining or operating a quarry, gravel pit or mining operation shall:
A. Post a bond in such amount (in cash or with such sureties and on such forms as shall be approved by the corporate authorities) as the corporate
authorities determine from time to time to be required to guarantee the proper repair of Village streets damaged by such gravel truck operators on the
basis of the in formation supplied pursuant to Section 3-16-2 above, and pending determination of the proper amount of the bond to be required of
each individual gravel pit operator, the amount of bond required is determined to be ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
B. Repair or cause to be repaired all damage to the Village streets caused by the gravel hauling activities of gravel truck operators hauling gravel from
such gravel pit.
C. No entity which fails to comply with the bond and record keeping provisions of this Chapter shall be permitted to haul gravel from any gravel pit.
3-16-4: COMPLY WITH ORDINANCES:
No license shall be issued to an applicant who fails to comply with the provisions of the Surface Mine Land Conservation and Regulation Act.1
3-16-5: SAFETY REQUIREMENTS:
Every person maintaining or operating a quarry, gravel pit or other mining operation shall equip the same with adequate safeguards both as concerns the
public and the employees of said quarry, gravel pit or mining operation. Each quarry, gravel pit or mining operation must be surrounded by a fence at least
four feet (4') high which will safeguard the public.
3-16-6: HOURS OF OPERATION:
No owner or operator of a quarry, gravel pit or mining operation shall permit the same to operate between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) P.M. and seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M., nor at any time between six o'clock (6:00) P.M. on a Saturday evening and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. on the following Monday morning.
3-16-7: CHILDREN:
No owner or operator of a quarry, gravel pit or mining operation, or foreman or watchman in charge of the work shall allow any child or children sixteen
(16) years or less to be in or around a quarry, gravel pit or mining operation at any time of the day or night.
3-16-8: RAILROAD SIDINGS:
All railroad sidings into a quarry, gravel pit or other mining operation shall be adequately marked and warning bells or signals placed at any intersection of
such siding with a public thoroughfare. (1984 Code)
Chapter 17
PRECIOUS METAL DEALERS, PAWNBROKERS AND DEALERS IN SECONDHAND
ARTICLES
3-17-1: DEFINITIONS:
BULLION: Precious metals in bulk form cast into bars, bricks, cubes, rounds, ingots and/or government minted and/or issued coins that are traded on
commodity markets which is valued by its mass and purity rather than by its face value as money or currency, and which does not have established
numismatic or collectible value which is greater than its value as a commodity.
COIN DEALERS: Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or limited liability company engaged in the business of buying and/or selling coins for their
value as collector's items, for their value for gold content or silver content, or buying coins containing any gold or silver at a price above the face value of
the coin.
COVERED TRANSACTION: Any purchase or sale of bullion, jewelry or secondhand article made of or containing precious metal, or precious metal scrap,
by a coin dealer as defined in this section; any purchase or sale by a "gold buyer" as defined in this section; any purchase or sale by a "silver buyer" as
defined in this section; any purchase or sale by a "precious metal dealer" as defined in this section; any action by a "pawnbroker" as defined in this section
resulting in the pawnbroker obtaining possession of any bullion, coin with value above its face value, any gold, any object made of gold or gold alloy, any
silver, or any object made of silver, or of silvery alloy, any other precious metal or any object made of other precious metal.
ENGAGE IN OR CONDUCT BUSINESS: The purchase, sale, barter or exchange of any item of property, including the advertising therefor, and including
such business conducted by an established dealer in a permanent location and including any temporary, transient or itinerant business.
GOLD BUYER: Any person, firm, sole proprietorship, partnership, corporation or limited liability company engaged in the business of buying gold or
objects made of gold or of gold alloy from the public.
ITINERANT DEALER: Any "precious metal dealer" as defined herein who engages in any temporary or transient business conducted in a shop, room,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 94/702
hotel room or other premises rented for any duration of one to thirty (30) consecutive days or used on a temporary basis.
MERCHANT: Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or limited liability company engaged in the business of buying and selling anywhere in the village.
PAWNBROKER: Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or limited liability company engaged in the business of lending money secured by the deposit
or pledge of physically delivered personal property (other than property the ownership of which is subject to legal dispute, securities, printed evidence of
indebtedness, or printed evidence of ownership of personal property) and taking possession of the personal property, or who deals in the purchase of such
personal property on the condition of selling it back at a stipulated price. A person, firm, partnership, corporation or limited liability company shall be
deemed to be a pawnbroker whether the transaction takes the form of a loan by the pawnbroker secured by the personal property, or a sale to the
pawnbroker of personal property with the right to repurchase within a stated period of time, but the business of pawnbroker does not include the lending of
money on deposit or pledge of title to property.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, joint stock company, corporation, limited liability company, association, or
combination of individuals or business entities of whatever form or character.
PRECIOUS METAL: A rare naturally occurring metallic chemical element of high economic value, including gold, silver, platinum and palladium.
PRECIOUS METAL DEALER: Any gold buyer, silver buyer, coin dealer, pawnbroker or person, firm, sole proprietorship, partnership, corporation, limited
liability company, or merchant, and any principal thereof, regularly engaged for thirty (30) days or more from one location in or conducting business for the
purchase, sale, barter, exchange or the pawn of coins, bullion, precious metal, precious metal scrap, or secondhand articles or jewelry that is made out of
or which contains one or more precious metals for the purpose of purchasing, reselling, trading, bartering or pawning the precious metal scrap therefrom.
PRECIOUS METAL SCRAP: Any secondhand item, including jewelry, broken jewelry, watches, silverware or object made of, or containing one or more
precious metals, which is not in the form of bullion.
SECONDHAND ARTICLE: Any item of personal property or object of value, previously owned or used, which is not purchased or sold as new.
Secondhand articles do not include property purchased by one licensed, established merchant from another within or without the village in the normal
course of business.
SILVER BUYER: Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or limited liability company engaged in the business of buying silver or objects made of silver
or silver alloy from the public.
VILLAGE: The village of Bartlett, Cook, DuPage and Kane Counties, Illinois. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
3-17-2: BUSINESSES NOT COVERED BY PRECIOUS METAL DEALER LICENSE REQUIREMENTS AND OTHER DEALERS OF
SECONDHAND ARTICLES:
A. This chapter shall not affect persons that sell items otherwise covered by this chapter to the public, but purchase the same from dealers, manufacturers
or wholesalers, and do not purchase such items from the public.
B. Except for charitable organizations, any person, firm, partnership, corporation, or limited liability company operating, engaged in or conducting business
as a secondhand store that sells, purchases, barters or exchanges secondhand articles other than gold, silver, precious metals, or items made of or
containing gold, silver or other precious metal and which are not covered transactions as defined in this chapter, shall nevertheless keep a record of all
articles purchased, which records shall be, together with the articles themselves, open to inspection by any member of the police department at all
reasonable hours. Merchants of secondhand articles that occasionally purchase antiques or items such as household goods, costume jewelry or
antique jewelry that may be made out of or contain a precious metal, but which purchases and the resale thereof are incidental to its other operations,
meaning not more than thirty percent (30%) of its total gross receipts per calendar year are generated by the sale of such secondhand articles that are
made out of or which contain precious metals, are exempt from the recordkeeping requirements of section 3-17-8 of this chapter and the transmission
of report requirements set forth in section 3-17-9 of this chapter, but are required to comply with the recordkeeping requirements of this section. (Ord.
2012-50, 7-3-2012)
3-17-3: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person, firm, sole proprietorship, partnership, corporation or limited liability company shall be engaged in the business of gold buyer, silver buyer, coin
dealer, or precious metal dealer anywhere in this village without complying with this chapter and obtaining a license therefor. Any pawnbroker accepting
any coins containing any gold or silver at a price above the face value and any pawnbroker accepting any secondhand article or object made of or
containing gold, silver or other precious metal as security for a loan or in a purchase with the seller having a right to repurchase within a period of time is
required to comply with this chapter and obtain a license therefor. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
3-17-4: FEES:
The fees for licenses hereunder shall be as provided in this section. One license, one license fee and one investigation fee shall entitle a merchant or
pawnbroker to engage in any one or all of the businesses of gold buyer, silver buyer, coin dealer or precious metal dealer. Such fee shall be in addition to
all other license fees for the pawnbroker business or other business engaged in by the applicant. The investigation fee and the license fee shall be
deposited with the village clerk at the time the application is made.
A. Nonrefundable investigation fee, due from each applicant for a precious metal dealer license or itinerant dealer license, of twenty five dollars ($25.00).
B. Annual license fee, to be refunded if license is not granted, of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
C. Temporary itinerant dealer license fee, to be refunded if the temporary license is not granted, of fifty dollars ($50.00) per week that the business will be
in operation, but not over one hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 95/702
3-17-5: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Applicants for a license under this chapter, whether a person, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, joint stock company, corporation or limited
liability company shall file within thirty (30) days of the effective date hereof and each year thereafter on or before May 1, a written, sworn application on a
form provided by the village clerk, signed by the applicant if an individual, by all partners if a partnership, by all joint venturers if a joint venture, by the
president if an association or joint stock company, and by all managers if a limited liability company, with the village clerk showing:
A. The name or names of the principals, agents, and employees of the applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on in
the village; the local address or addresses of such person or persons while engaged in such business; the permanent address or addresses of such
person or persons; the capacity in which such persons will act (as proprietor, principal, agent, employee or otherwise); the name and address of the
person, firm, corporation or limited liability company for whose account the business will be carried on if any; and if a corporation or limited liability
company under the laws of what state it is incorporated or organized. As used in this subsection, "principal" means the proprietor if a sole
proprietorship, the partners if a partnership, the joint venturers if a joint venture, the directors and officers of an association, the directors and officers
and each stockholder owning more than twenty percent (20%) of a joint stock company or corporation, and the managers and each member owning
more than twenty percent (20%) membership interest in a limited liability company.
B. The fingerprints of the principals, agents and employees of precious metal dealers.
C. Evidence provided by the applicant to the satisfaction of the chief of police that:
1. None of the principals, agents or employees of the applicant has been convicted of any misdemeanor involving theft, receiving stolen goods,
burglary, robbery, money laundering, crime of deception or other fraud, sale of illegal drugs or narcotics, or any felony in the federal or state courts,
within the five (5) years immediately preceding filing the application;
2. No fraud, misrepresentation or false statement of material or relevant facts is contained in the application submitted by the applicant; or
3. The applicant has not engaged in a fraudulent transaction or enterprise within the five (5) years immediately preceding filing the application.
D. The place or places in the village where it is proposed to carry on the applicant's business, and the length of time during which it is proposed that said
business shall be conducted.
E. The place, or places if more than one location, including any other permanent place of business of the applicant, where the applicant within the six (6)
months next preceding the date of said application conducted an activity subject to the regulations hereof, stating the nature thereof and giving the post
office, street addresses, and town, village, or city of any building or office in which said business was conducted.
F. A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers.
G. Whether or not the person or persons having the management or supervision of the applicant's business have been convicted within the last five (5)
years of a felony, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal or state law, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor.
H. Credentials from the person, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, joint stock company, corporation or limited liability company for which the
applicant proposes to do business, authority for the applicant to act as such representative.
I. Such other information as to the identity or character of the person or persons having the management or supervision of the applicant's business or the
method or plan of doing such business as the chief of police may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this chapter in the protection of the public good.
J. The application shall state thereon that "It is unlawful for any person to make a false statement on this application". Any false statement made on the
application form will void the application and constitute a misdemeanor punishable as provided by law and shall be grounds for the nonissuance,
suspension and/or revocation of a license required and/or issued under this chapter. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
3-17-6: STANDARDS FOR DETERMINING ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
After the filing of an application accompanied by the required fees, the chief of police will conduct an investigation to be made of the applicant and the
applicable principals, agents and employees of the applicant. A precious metal dealer's license shall be issued by the village clerk unless the village clerk
finds, on the basis of the application and reports submitted by the chief of police, or his designee, that:
A. Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for such establishment license; or
B. Based on the entry of a final, unappealable order by any court, administrative agency, or hearing officer finding that the applicant or other person or
entity employed by the applicant or owning an interest in the entity subject to the requirements of this chapter:
1. Is guilty of any felony; or
2. Is guilty of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, including, but not limited to:
a. Theft; or
b. Possession or receipt of stolen property or dealing in the sale of stolen property; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 96/702
c. Robbery; or
d. Burglary; or
e. Crime of deception or fraud; or
f. Sale of illegal drugs or narcotics; or
g. Money laundering.
3. Has been engaged in acts constituting a nuisance in fact; or
4. Has been engaged in acts constituting a nuisance per se as enumerated in Illinois statutes or this code; or
5. Has been engaged in acts constituting a danger to the public, health, safety or morals; or
6. Has violated the consumer fraud laws of the state of Illinois, or any other state, or of the United States; or
7. Engaged in a business or profession in defiance of the state statute or local ordinance regulating or prohibiting the same, which includes, but is not
limited to, the following:
a. Theft; or
b. Possession or receipt of stolen property or dealing in the sale of stolen property; or
c. Robbery; or
d. Burglary; or
e. Crime of deception or fraud; or
f. Sale of illegal drugs or narcotics; or
g. Money laundering; or
h. The pawnbroker regulation act1.
8. Has been found to have violated any substantially identical provision of the ordinance of any other municipality by the final, unappealable order of
any court, hearing officer of administrative agency.
C. The premises upon or from which the proposed business activity is to be conducted does not comply with the requirements of this code, including the
building code, the property maintenance code, zoning ordinance, and all other applicable ordinances of the village and the rules and regulations of the
state fire marshal.
D. No license shall be issued or renewed to any person, firm, partnership, corporation or limited liability company that has repeatedly and wilfully violated
this chapter.
E. No license shall be issued or renewed if any officer, partner or owner of twenty percent (20%) or more of the shares or membership interest of the
applicant has repeatedly and wilfully violated this chapter. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
3-17-7: PROCESSING LICENSE APPLICATIONS AND ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
The village clerk shall, within thirty (30) days following the date of the filing of the application for a precious metal dealer's license, or itinerant dealer's
license, and payment of the required fees, issue the applicant a license hereunder provided that the chief of police has first given his written report that the
applicant has qualified for said license. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
3-17-8: RECORD OF TRANSACTION:
A. Each merchant, pawnbroker, precious metal dealer, and itinerant dealer subject to this chapter shall keep the following contemporaneous record
concerning each item received in a covered transaction in the English language at the time of each covered transaction within the village in the course
of his business, an accurate account of each transaction:
1. A digital photograph of the item unless it is bullion.
2. An accurate description of the item or items purchased, bartered, exchanged or received, including any marking that is engraved, etched or written
upon any item bartered, exchanged or received.
3. The name, residence address, driver's license number and description of the person selling, bartering or exchanging any item in a covered
transaction, including, the hair color, sex, approximate height, weight, date of birth and any distinguishing features of such person.
B. This record shall be kept daily in one of the following ways:
1. Entered into a computerized recordkeeping system approved and designated by the chief of police; or
2. In a bound book, or on a continuous sheet of paper or tape, handwritten in ink or typed, so that it will be obvious that an entry has been removed.
Such information may be made on cards, individual sheets or order pads if such sheet or card is numbered, so that it will be obvious if an entry is
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 97/702
removed.
C. With respect to pawnbrokers that take possession of bullion, jewelry, or secondhand articles made of or containing any precious metal, the
recordkeeping requirements and the other duties, obligations and requirements imposed by this chapter shall not in any manner alter or amend the
pawnbroker's duties, obligations and requirements under state law, including, but not limited to, the pawnbroker regulation act2, and the duties,
obligations, and requirements imposed on pawnbrokers by this chapter shall be in addition thereto. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
3-17-9: REPORTS TO POLICE:
Computerized recordkeeping entries containing the required information and digital photographs as required by section 3-17-8 of this chapter shall be
entered and transmitted by the precious metal dealer or pawnbroker to and received by the chief of police or his designee via the internet within the same
business day of the purchase, barter, exchange, or pawn of each item in a covered transaction, or alternatively, written records containing the information
and digital photographs as required by section 3-17-8 of this chapter shall be delivered by the precious metal dealer or pawnbroker to the chief of police or
his designee each day that a covered transaction occurs within the same day as the purchase, barter, exchange or pawn of each item in a covered
transaction. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
3-17-10: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
Every precious metal dealer shall admit to his premises at any reasonable time any law enforcement officer to examine his computerized recordkeeping
system user interface or written record as required to be kept pursuant to section 3-17-8 of this chapter, as well as articles purchased or received which
are within such premises. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
3-17-11: ARTICLES TO BE RETAINED:
No precious metal dealer shall sell, melt, change the form of, or dispose of any jewelry, secondhand article or precious metal scrap received by him, of
which he is required to make record and report under this chapter, within five (5) business days after taking possession of such jewelry, secondhand article
or precious metal scrap, or within five (5) business days after entering the required information into the designated computerized recordkeeping system, or
physically delivering the written record to the chief of police or his designee, whichever period is longer. All such jewelry, secondhand articles and precious
metal scrap shall be retained in his possession at the location specified in the license required herein during the five (5) business day period. For purposes
of this section, "business days" shall mean Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays (except for recognized national holidays) and shall
not include Saturdays or Sundays. The five (5) day retention period shall not be applicable to bullion. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
3-17-12: PROHIBITIONS:
A. No precious metal dealer or pawnbroker shall have in his place of business or in his possession, or shall have acquired and resold, bartered or
exchanged, any item, article or property which is proved to have been stolen, the account and report of which he has not kept and reported as herein
prescribed.
B. It shall be unlawful for any precious metal dealer or pawnbroker in the course of his business or occupation to acquire, by purchase, barter, exchange or
otherwise, any secondhand articles, bullion or goods containing precious metal from any person under eighteen (18) years of age.
C. It shall be unlawful for any precious metal dealer or pawnbroker to acquire, by purchase, barter, exchange or otherwise, goods bearing evidence of a
serial number or other identifying mark which has been tampered with or scratched or obliterated in any manner unless such person immediately
contacts the police department of the village, and make a complete report thereof.
D. It shall be unlawful for any precious metal dealer and/or pawnbroker to accept, buy or exchange any item, article, or property prior to examining the
identifying credentials of the person pawning, selling or exchanging said item(s), article(s) or property. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
3-17-13: TRANSFER OF LICENSES:
No license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be assignable or otherwise transferable. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
3-17-14: TIME LIMIT FOR FILING APPLICATION FOR LICENSE AND COMPLIANCE:
All precious metal dealers or persons who engage in or conduct business involving the purchase, sale, barter, exchange or the pawn of bullion, precious
metal scrap or secondhand articles made of or containing precious metals in the village must file an application for a precious metal dealer's license and
applicable fees, and shall cause its principal(s), owner(s) and employees to submit his, her or their fingerprints to the police department as required by this
chapter within sixty (60) days of the effective date of this chapter. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
3-17-15: TERMINATION:
Every license issued under this chapter shall expire on April 30 of each year unless sooner suspended or revoked. Applications for renewal, together with
the annual license fee, shall be delivered to the village clerk on or before April 1 of each year. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 98/702
3-17-16: SUSPENSION:
Any licenses issued under this chapter may be suspended for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days by the village administrator, who shall also be
authorized to summarily order the cessation of business operations and the closing of the premises where the business is carried on for said period of time
in the event the village administrator determines that the continued conduct or operation of the business constitutes a danger to the public health, safety,
morals or welfare, in accordance with the procedures set forth in section 3-1-15 of this title, which is hereby made applicable to licenses issued under this
chapter. Hearings on the suspension of a license under this chapter, and a business license issued under chapter 1 of this title may be held concurrently.
(Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
3-17-17: REVOCATION:
Any license issued under this chapter to any precious metal dealer, itinerant dealer, pawnbroker or other person that engages in a covered transaction
under this chapter during the term of such license, may be revoked by the village president and board of trustees for any of the following causes:
A. Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for such license.
B. The entry of a final, unappealable order by any court, administrative agency, or hearing officer finding that the licensee, or any person or entity required
to procure a license under this chapter, or file evidence of exemption as a limited sales dealer under this chapter, or of any of said licensee's principals,
agents or employees involved in the operation of an establishment in the village regulated by this chapter:
1. Is guilty of a felony; or
2. Is guilty of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, including, but not limited to:
a. Theft; or
b. Possession or receipt of stolen property or dealing in the sale of stolen property; or
c. Robbery; or
d. Burglary; or
e. Crime of deception or fraud; or
f. Sale of illegal drugs or narcotics; or
g. Money laundering; or
3. Has been engaged in acts constituting a nuisance of fact; or
4. Has been engaged in acts constituting a nuisance per se as enumerated in Illinois statutes or this code; or
5. Has been engaged in acts constituting a danger to the public health, safety or morals; or
6. Has violated the consumer fraud laws of the state of Illinois, or other state, or of the United States; or
7. Has been engaged in a business or profession in defiance of the state statute or local ordinance regulating or prohibiting the same, which includes,
but is not limited to, the following:
a. Theft; or
b. Possession or receipt of stolen property or dealing in the sale of stolen property; or
c. Robbery; or
d. Burglary; or
e. Crime of deception or fraud; or
f. Sale of illegal drugs or narcotics; or
g. Money laundering; or
8. Has violated the pawnbroker regulation act3.
C. Failure of the licensee to pay any fine, penalty, license fee or alarm service fee owed the village.
D. Refusal by the applicant, licensee or any precious metal dealer or other person or entity who engages in or conducts business in secondhand articles
containing precious metals to permit any inspection by a duly authorized police officer or enforcement officer or employee of the village while in the
performance of their duties in making any inspection required under this chapter or any village ordinance.
E. The third violation by the licensee of any one or more of:
1. The general regulations applicable to all licensees set forth in chapter 1 of this title; or
2. The special regulations governing the licensee's business, trade or occupation set forth in chapter 1 of this title.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 99/702
3. Any violation of this chapter other than as provided in subsection F of this section.
F. Any single violation of section 3-17-11 of this chapter, where said violation is committed by a licensee, or by any principal, agent or employee of
licensee, occurring within the village.
G. Failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter.
H. No license revocation shall be effective until after the licensee has had an opportunity to have hearing pursuant to the procedures set forth in
subsection 3-1-15D of this title, which section is hereby made applicable to licenses issued under this chapter.
I. Hearings on the revocation of a license issued under this chapter and the revocation of a business license may be held concurrently. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-
2012)
3-17-18: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, partnership, corporation, or limited liability company violating the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than one hundred
dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
3-17-19: SAVING CLAUSE:
The provisions set forth in chapter 1 of this title are hereby incorporated into and made a part of this chapter; provided, however, that in the event of any
conflict between the provisions set forth in chapter 1 of this title and the provisions set forth in this chapter, the provisions set forth in this chapter shall
control to the extent of such conflict or inconsistency. (Ord. 2012-50, 7-3-2012)
Chapter 18
SOLICITORS
3-18-1: DEFINITIONS:
CONTRIBUTION: The promise or grant of any donation, money, alms, food, clothing or property of any kind or value.
OBSCENITY: Any material that: a) the average person, applying contemporary adult community standards, would find that, taken as a whole, it appeals to
the prurient interest; and b) the average person, applying contemporary adult community standards, would find that it depicts or describes, in a patently
offensive way, ultimate sexual acts or sadomasochistic sexual acts, whether normal or perverted, actual or simulated, or masturbation, excretory functions
or lewd exhibition of the genitals; and c) taken as a whole, it lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value.
SOLICIT: To go to any premises in the village without prior appointment or prearrangement with the occupant of such premises or to go upon any public
street, sidewalk or other property owned by the village: a) to ask for a contribution, or b) to sell, offer for sale, barter or exchange, or to take orders for the
present or future delivery of any good, service, ware, merchandise or other article or thing whatsoever.
SOLICITOR: Any person who goes to any premises in the village without prior appointment or prearrangement with the occupant of such premises, or
goes upon any public street, sidewalk or other property owned by the village: a) to ask for a contribution, or b) to sell, offer for sale, barter or exchange, or
to take orders for the present or future delivery of any good, service, ware, merchandise or other article or thing whatsoever. (Ord. 2002-117, 11-19-2002)
3-18-2: DECLARATION OF VILLAGE POLICY:
It is hereby declared to be the policy of the village president and board of trustees that the occupants of premises in the village shall have the opportunity
to determine whether solicitors: a) will be invited to solicit at such premises, or b) will be prohibited from soliciting at such premises under any
circumstances. Such election shall be made by posting a notice in the manner set forth in section 3-18-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 2002-117, 11-19-2002)
3-18-3: FORM OF NOTICE PROHIBITING SOLICITORS:
A. Each resident who desires to secure the protection intended to be provided by the regulations pertaining to solicitors contained in this chapter may elect
to prohibit solicitors at his or her residence or place of business by posting upon or within thirty inches (30") of the main entrance door to his or her
residence or place of business a weatherproof card, approximately three inches by four inches (3" x 4") in size as follows:
NO SOLICITORS INVITED
B. Such notice shall be printed with letters at least one-third inch (1/3") in height. For the purpose of uniformity, the cards shall be provided by the village
clerk to persons requesting them, at the cost thereof.
C. Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor of the determination by the occupant of such premises to prohibit solicitation as
therein stated.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 100/702
D. If no such card is posted, it shall be presumed that the occupant has elected not to prohibit solicitors. (Ord. 2002-117, 11-19-2002)
3-18-4: DUTY OF SOLICITORS:
A. It shall be the duty of every solicitor upon going onto any premises in the village to first determine whether the notice specified in section 3-18-3 of this
chapter is exhibited as therein set forth, and to be governed by any prohibitions contained in such notice.
1. If the notice states "NO SOLICITORS INVITED" then the solicitor shall immediately and peacefully leave the premises.
B. Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any premises, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from such premises when
requested to do so by its occupant. (Ord. 2002-117, 11-19-2002)
3-18-5: UNINVITED SOLICITING PROHIBITED:
It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door, or
create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such premises, for the purpose of securing an audience with
the occupant thereof in order to "solicit" as herein defined, in defiance of the notice exhibited at such premises in accordance with section 3-18-3 of this
chapter or oral notice given in accordance with the provisions of section 3-18-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 2002-117, 11-19-2002)
3-18-6: LIMITATIONS ON SOLICITING:
It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door or
rap or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence for the purpose
of securing any audience with the occupant thereof and to "solicit", as herein defined, prior to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M.
(local time) of any weekday, or at any time on a Sunday or on a state or national holiday. (Ord. 2002-117, 11-19-2002)
3-18-7: FRAUD:
It shall be unlawful for any solicitor to cheat or deceive any person or to make any fraudulent misrepresentation, whether through himself or herself or
through an employee or agent, while acting as a solicitor in the village. (Ord. 2002-117, 11-19-2002)
3-18-8: LOUD NOISES AND SPEAKING DEVICES:
No solicitor, nor anyone on his or her behalf, shall, for the purposes of attracting attention to his or her solicitation or to any goods, wares or merchandise
which such solicitor proposes to sell, blow a horn or use any other sound device, including any loudspeaking radio or amplifying system upon any of the
streets, alleys, parks or other public places of the village, or upon any private premises in the village, where the volume of sound emitted or produced
therefrom and reaching any portion of such public places or private premises unreasonably interferes with the enjoyment of life by any resident of Bartlett.
(Ord. 2002-117, 11-19-2002)
3-18-9: SOLICITING ON HIGHWAYS AND STREETS RESTRICTED:
No solicitor shall stand upon any highway or public street for the purpose of soliciting contributions from the occupant of any vehicle in violation of section
11-1006 of the Illinois vehicle code1. Solicitation on public highways or streets in Bartlett shall be permitted only at the following intersections:
Devon Avenue and South Main Street;
Oak Avenue and North Avenue;
On Schick Road at Route 59;
On South Bartlett Road at Stearns Road;
On Struckman at Route 59;
On West Bartlett Road at Route 59;
On Westridge at West Bartlett Road;
Prospect Avenue and Devon Avenue;
Schick Road and South Bartlett Road;
Struckman Boulevard and South Bartlett Road;
and only between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and three o'clock (3:00) P.M. daily, upon the following conditions:
A. Any solicitor engaged in solicitation upon a public street shall be at least eighteen (18) years of age and shall wear a high visibility vest. Solicitors shall
stand on or so near to the curbside of the street as to avoid creating a traffic hazard. In no event shall solicitors stand at or near the center of any
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 101/702
street.
B. The soliciting agency shall be registered with the Illinois attorney general as a charitable organization as provided by "an act to regulate solicitation and
collection for funds for charitable purposes, provide penalties for violations thereof, and making an appropriation therefor", approved July 26, 1963, as
amended.
C. The soliciting agency shall be liable for any injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which is causally related to any act of ordinary
negligence of the soliciting agent.
D. Prior to soliciting on any highway or public street in the village of Bartlett as provided in this section, the soliciting agency shall obtain a highway
solicitation permit and shall file with the village clerk at the time of application for such permit, the date or dates on which said highway solicitation will
occur within the village. Prior to issuance of the highway solicitation permit, the soliciting agency shall file with the village clerk: 1) a release and
indemnification agreement in the form on file with the village clerk as exhibit A from the soliciting agency agreeing for itself and its successors to
release the village from liability and to indemnify, defend and hold the village, its president and board of trustees, and its officials, officers, employees,
agents and volunteers, harmless from and against any and all liability arising out of claims for bodily injury, including personal injury and accidental
death and property damage or any such claim for damage arising out of the acts or omissions of the soliciting agency and any of the individuals
soliciting on its behalf in connection with solicitation upon any public streets or highways; and 2) a certificate of insurance to the village clerk evidencing
that the soliciting agency has commercial general liability and property damage insurance in full force and effect covering the days on which the
soliciting agency intends to solicit on the said highways or public streets in the village to protect it from claims for bodily injury, including personal injury
and accidental death, as well as claims for property damage, in an amount not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury on account
of any one occurrence, and property damage of not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) on account of any one occurrence, with
combined aggregate limits of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). Said certificate of insurance shall name the village as additional insured
thereon and shall provide the insurance policy is noncancelable unless the village is given thirty (30) days prior written notification. (Ord. 2002-117, 11-
19-2002)
3-18-10: USE OF STREETS:
No solicitor shall have any exclusive right to any location in the public streets, right of way, or other public property, nor shall he or she be permitted to
operate in any congested area where his or her operations unreasonably impede or obstruct use of same by the public. For the purpose of this section, the
judgment of a police officer, exercised in good faith, shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public unreasonably impeded
or obstructed. (Ord. 2002-117, 11-19-2002)
3-18-11: OBSCENE MATERIALS:
It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door, or
create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such premises, for the purpose of securing an audience with
the occupant thereof in order to "solicit" any "obscene" writing, picture, record or other representation or embodiment of "obscenity" as defined in section
3-18-1 of this chapter; provided, however, that said solicitor has knowledge of the nature of the content thereof, or recklessly fails to exercise a reasonable
inspection thereof which would have disclosed the nature of the content. Nothing in this section shall be construed as authorizing the prior restraint of the
solicitation of any allegedly obscene materials. (Ord. 2002-117, 11-19-2002)
3-18-12: UNLAWFUL SOLICITATION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit within the corporate limits of the village if he or she has been convicted of any felony or a misdemeanor
involving moral turpitude or has been found to have violated any consumer fraud law of the state, or any other state or of the United States by any court or
administrative agency within the last five (5) years. (Ord. 2002-117, 11-19-2002)
3-18-13: PROHIBITION OF FURTHER SOLICITATION:
The village clerk shall notify a solicitor by certified mail, return receipt requested, and the village attorney shall be and he is hereby authorized to apply to
either the United States district court for the northern district of Illinois or the circuit court of Cook, DuPage, or Kane County, Illinois, for a judicial
determination as to whether further solicitation in the village by such solicitor may be prohibited if any of the following occur:
A. A violation of any of the provisions of sections 3-18-4 through 3-18-11 of this chapter; or
B. The village clerk or any other agent or employee of the village receives ten (10) or more bona fide, sworn complaints setting forth facts showing a
violation and harm of any provision of this chapter or any of the laws of this state; or
C. The solicitor has engaged in fraud or misrepresentation to obtain money or property; or
D. Promising any person that the proceeds of a solicitation of funds will be refunded upon request and thereafter wilfully failing to make a written refund
request within sixty (60) days; or
E. Promising any person that he or she will receive a refund upon request without providing a written statement of the refund terms and conditions; or
F. Knowing misrepresentation that a donor will obtain a federal tax deduction; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 102/702
G. Wilful use of solicited funds to commit a crime. (Ord. 2002-117, 11-19-2002)
3-18-14: PENALTIES:
Any person who solicits within the corporate limits of the village in violation of this chapter is subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and each act of solicitation in violation of this chapter constitutes a separate offense. (Ord. 2002-117, 11-19-
2002)
Chapter 19
RAFFLES
3-19-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and terms shall have the meanings set forth, except where otherwise specifically indicated. Words and terms not defined shall have
the meanings indicated by common dictionary definition.
BUSINESS: A voluntary organization composed of individuals and businesses who have joined together to advance the commercial, financial, industrial
and civic interests of a community.
CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION: An organization or institution organized and operated to benefit an indefinite number of the public. The service rendered
to those eligible for benefits must also confer some benefit on the public.
EDUCATIONAL ORGANIZATION: An organization or institution organized and operated to provide systematic instruction in useful branches of learning by
methods common to schools and institutions of learning which compare favorably in their scope and intensity with the course of study presented in taxsupported
schools.
FRATERNAL ORGANIZATION: An organization of persons having a common interest, the primary interest of which is to both promote the welfare of its
members and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to lessen the burdens of government by caring for those that otherwise would
be cared for by the government.
LABOR ORGANIZATION: An organization composed of workers organized with the objective of betterment of the conditions of those engaged in such
pursuit and the development of a higher degree of efficiency in their respective occupations.
LOTTERY: Any scheme or procedure whereby one or more prizes are distributed by chance among persons who have paid or promised consideration for
a chance to win such prizes, whether such scheme or procedure is called a lottery, raffle, gift, sale or some other name.
NET PROCEEDS: The gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less reasonable sums expended for prizes, local license fees and other reasonable
operating expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle.
NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION: An organization or institution organized and conducted on a not-for-profit basis with no personal profit inuring to any one
as a result of the operation.
RAFFLE: A form of lottery in which:
A. The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance, represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of numbers or by
some other medium, one or more of which chances are to be designated the winning chance;
B. The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing or by some other method based on an element of chance by an act or sets of acts on the
part of persons conducting or connected with the lottery, except that the winning chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly
exhibited sporting contest.
RELIGIOUS ORGANIZATION: Any church, congregation, society or organization founded for the purpose of religious worship.
VETERANS' ORGANIZATION: An organization or association comprised of members of which substantially all are individuals who are veterans or
spouses, widows or widowers of veterans, the primary purpose of which is to promote the welfare of its members and to provide assistance to the general
public in such a way as to confer a public benefit. (1984 Code; amd. Ord. 98-11, 2-3-1998)
3-19-2: LICENSING OF RAFFLES:
A. No person, firm or corporation shall conduct raffles without having first obtained a license therefor pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. 98-11, 2-3-1998)
B. Licenses shall be issued only to bona fide religious, charitable, labor, business, fraternal, educational or veterans' organizations that operate without
profit to their members and which have been in existence continuously for a period of five (5) years immediately before making application for a license
and which have had during that entire five (5) year period a bona fide membership engaged in carrying out their objects, or to a nonprofit fundraising
organization that the village administrator or her designee determines is organized for the sole purpose of providing financial assistance to an identified
individual or group of individuals suffering extreme financial hardship as the result of an illness, disability, accident or disaster. (Ord. 2002-12, 2-5-2002)
C. A license shall authorize the licensee to conduct raffles, as defined herein, and each license shall be valid for: 1) one raffle, or 2) for a specified number
of raffles to be conducted during a specified period not to exceed one year. A license may be suspended or revoked for any violation of this chapter or
for any violation of the raffles act1. (Ord. 98-11, 2-3-1998)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 103/702
D. Licenses issued by the village administrator, or her designee, are subject to the following restrictions: (Ord. 2002-12, 2-5-2002)
1. The license and application for license must specify the number of raffles to be conducted by the licensee/applicant and the specified time period in
which the license will be in effect (not to exceed 1 year). For each raffle to be conducted by the licensee/applicant, the license and application for
license must specify the area or areas within the corporate limits of the village in which raffle chances will be sold or issued, the time period during
which raffle chances will be sold or issued, the time of determination of winning chances, and the location or locations at which winning chances will
be determined.
2. The license application must contain a sworn statement attesting to the not for profit character of the prospective licensee organization, signed by
the presiding officer and the secretary of that organization.
3. The following are ineligible for any license under this chapter:
a. Any person who has been convicted of a felony;
b. Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling promoter;
c. Any person who is not of good moral character;
d. Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in subsection D3a, D3b or D3c of this section has a proprietary, equitable or credit interest, or in
which such a person is active or employed;
e. Any organization in which a person defined in subsection D3a, D3b or D3c of this section is an officer, director or employee whether compensated
or not;
f. Any organization in which a person defined in subsection D3a, D3b or D3c of this section is to participate in the management or operation of a
"raffle" as defined herein. (Ord. 98-11, 2-3-1998)
3-19-3: LICENSING LIMITATIONS:
All licenses granted for the purpose of operating raffles within the village shall be subject to the following limitations: (1984 Code)
A. The aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise awarded by a licensee in a single raffle shall not exceed fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00).
B. The maximum retail value of each prize awarded by a licensee in a single raffle shall not exceed fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). (Ord. 2002-12, 2-5-
2002)
C. The maximum price which may be charged for each raffle chance issued or sold shall not exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00).
D. The maximum days during which chances may be issued or sold for a single raffle shall not exceed three hundred (300) days. (1984 Code)
3-19-4: LICENSE APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
A. All applicants for a raffle license must complete and sign an application, which will be available at the village hall during regular business hours.
B. Each application shall include a license fee in the amount of five dollars ($5.00) before said application shall be considered complete.
C. Upon receipt of a completed application and application fee by the village clerk, the village administrator, or her designee, shall act upon the license
application within thirty (30) days from the date of receipt of said completed application and application fee. The village administrator, or her designee,
shall direct the village clerk to issue the raffle license within said thirty (30) day period if the applicant meets the standards set forth in this chapter and
has paid the application fee and furnished the fidelity bond or waiver required under section 3-19-6 of this chapter, and is not ineligible for a raffle
license pursuant to subsection 3-19-2D3 of this chapter. In the event the village administrator denies a raffle license application, and/or directs the
village clerk not to issue a raffle license, the village administrator shall issue the applicant a written notice of denial within said thirty (30) day period
expressly referring to the specific requirement or requirements of this chapter that the applicant failed to meet.
D. The applicant may appeal the decision of the village administrator, or her designee, denying the raffle license application within thirty (30) days after
notice of denial is mailed to the applicant, by submitting to the village clerk a written request for a hearing before the village president and board of
trustees. The clerk shall give the applicant at least ten (10) days' prior notice of the time and place of such hearing. The village president and board of
trustees shall consider the application and shall hear evidence regarding the license denial and the basis for said denial. The applicant or his or her
attorney shall have the right to examine witnesses and present evidence on behalf of the applicant. At the conclusion of the hearing, the village
president and board of trustees shall affirm or reverse the denial of such application, and at its next succeeding regular meeting of the corporate
authorities shall make findings of fact and approve of a formal written order affirming or reversing the denial of the raffle license application.
E. Any raffle license issued in violation of the provisions of this section shall be null and void. (Ord. 2002-12, 2-5-2002)
3-19-5: CONDUCT OF RAFFLES:
The conducting of raffles is subject to the following restrictions:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 104/702
A. The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that game.
B. No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization may participate in the management or operation of the raffle.
C. No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in the management or operation of the raffle.
D. A licensee may rent a premises on which to determine the winning chance or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also licensed under
this chapter. (1984 Code)
E. Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the area specified on the license and winning chances may be determined only at those locations
specified on the license. (Ord. 98-11, 2-3-1998)
F. No person under the age of eighteen (18) years may participate in the conducting of raffles or chances. A person under the age of eighteen (18) years
may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only when accompanied by his parent or legal guardian. (1984 Code)
3-19-6: RAFFLE MANAGER AND BOND:
The operation and conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of a single raffles manager designated by the licensee organization. Unless the
applicant executes a waiver and all of the members of the organization applying for the raffle license vote unanimously to waive the requirement that the
raffle manager shall post a fidelity bond as evidenced by a list of all of the members of the organization and a certified copy of a resolution, minutes of a
meeting of said members and/or other written documentation indicating said unanimous vote and/or consents to the waiver by all such members, the
manager shall give a fidelity bond in an amount equal to the greater of: a) one hundred ten percent (110%) of its estimate of the gross receipts it
anticipates that will be received by the licensed organization for the raffle or raffles for which the license is being applied for, or b) one hundred ten percent
(110%) of the estimated aggregate value of all of the prizes for the raffle or raffles being applied for; in favor of the licensee organization, conditioned upon
the raffle manager's honesty in the performance of his or her duties. Terms of the bond shall provide that notice shall be given in writing to the licensing
authority not less than thirty (30) days prior to its cancellation. An applicant may request that the amount of said bond be reduced, but only the president
and board of trustees shall have the authority to determine a different amount of the fidelity bond, based on good cause shown by the applying
organization. (Ord. 2002-12, 2-5-2002)
3-19-7: RECORDS OF LICENSEE:
A. Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single gathering
or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All deductions from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be documented
with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the purchased item or service or other reason for the deduction and the recipient.
The distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee, purpose, amount and date of payment.
B. Gross receipts from the operation of raffle programs shall be segregated from other revenues of the organization, including bingo gross receipts, if
bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization, pursuant to license therefor issued by the department of revenue of the state, and
placed in a separate account. Each organization shall have separate records of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts, expenses and
net proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same person who accounts for other revenues of the organization.
C. Each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall report monthly to its membership, and to the licensing local unit of government, its gross receipts,
expenses and net proceeds from raffles and the distribution of net proceeds itemized as required in this section.
D. Records required by this section shall be preserved for three (3) years, and organizations shall make available their records relating to operation of
raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and places. (1984 Code)
3-19-8: ENFORCEMENT:
Any law enforcement agency that takes action relating to the operation of a charitable game shall notify the department of revenue and specify the extent
of the action taken and the reasons for such action. (Ord. 98-11, 2-3-1998)
3-19-9: GAMBLING; OTHER ACTIVITIES:
Nothing in this act shall be construed to authorize the conducting or operating of any gambling scheme, enterprise, activity or device other than raffles as
provided herein. (Ord. 98-11, 2-3-1998)
Chapter 20
AUCTIONS AND AUCTIONEERS
3-20-1: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 105/702
In addition to the information required under section 3-1-3 of this title, an application for an auction and auctioneer's license shall state the names of any
employees, not to exceed two (2), who are to be authorized to conduct auctions under the authority of the license. The chief of police shall investigate the
character of every applicant for an auctioneer's license, and no such license shall be issued to any person who has a criminal history reflecting violence or
immorality. (1984 Code)
3-20-2: STREET AUCTIONS PROHIBITED:
No person shall sell or attempt to sell at public auction any personal or real property upon the public streets or sidewalks of the village. (1984 Code)
3-20-3: DISINFECTION OF SECONDHAND ARTICLES:
It shall be unlawful for any auctioneer to sell or offer for sale any article of secondhand clothing, wearing apparel or other articles by means of which
disease may be conveyed, unless the same has first been thoroughly disinfected. (1984 Code)
3-20-4: INSURANCE:
No license shall be issued for the conduct of an auction on any property owned or controlled by the village, or occurring within the corporate limits of the
village, unless the licensee shall provide the village with insurance coverage in accordance with the following requirements:
Any licensee operating an auction under this chapter shall defend, indemnify, protect and save harmless the village, its officials, officers, employees,
agents, consultants and volunteers working on behalf of the village, from and against liability, losses, physical damage to property, and bodily injury or
death to persons, including payments made under any worker's compensation law, which may arise out of the licensee's operation of an auction within the
limits of the village. Each licensee shall further indemnify and hold harmless the village, its officials, officers, employees, agents, consultants and
volunteers while acting on behalf of the village from and against any liability or losses sustained as a direct or indirect result of the action of the licensee's
agents or employees or in any way arising out of the granting of his license. Each licensee shall carry commercial general liability insurance with an
insurance company licensed to do business in the state having a rating of B+:VII or better. The policy limits for the commercial general liability insurance
shall be not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit per occurrence for bodily injury, personal injury and property damage with a
general aggregate shall be no less than two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) or there shall be an event specific aggregate of not less than one million dollars
($1,000,000.00). Such insurance to be utilized to protect the licensee and the village, its officials, officers, employees, agents, consultants and volunteers
while acting on behalf of the village, as their interests may appear, from and against all claims, demands, actions, judgments, costs, expenses and
liabilities, including without limitation attorney fees which may arise or result directly or indirectly from or by reason of any such liability, loss, injury or
damage. Said policy shall contain a provision requiring the insured to notify the village not less than ten (10) days prior to cancellation or change of any
policy. The village, its officials, officers, employees, agents, consultants and volunteers while acting on behalf of the village, shall appear as additional
named insureds under each policy. At least ten (10) days prior to commencing any operations in the village, the licensee shall provide the village with
certificates of insurance for each policy. Each licensee shall also carry such insurance as may be necessary to protect it and the village from all claims
under the workers' compensation laws from time to time in effect that may be applicable to the licensee. All insurance required by this chapter shall be and
remain in full force and effect for the entire period the license is in effect. The certificate(s) of insurance, and, if requested by the village attorney, the
policies of insurance, or a certified copy or copies thereof, shall be approved by the village attorney and shall be deposited with and kept on file by the
village clerk. (Ord. 96-14, 2-6-1996)
Chapter 21
GARAGE, YARD AND RUMMAGE SALES
3-21-1: APPLICATION:
No garage, yard or rummage sale shall be conducted in the Village without first applying for and obtaining a permit therefor from the Village Clerk. (1984
Code)
3-21-2: LIMIT PER YEAR:
Not more than three (3) permits shall be issued for garage sales to any applicant, or to any one applicant or for any one premises in the Village during any
calendar year. (1984 Code)
3-21-3: HOURS OF OPERATION:
A garage, yard and/or rummage sale may be conducted only on any three (3) consecutive days of the week between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M.
and five o'clock (5:00) P.M. (1984 Code)
3-21-4: SIGNS:
Garage, yard and/or rummage sale signs may be posted only in accordance with the provisions of the Bartlett Zoning Ordinance1. In no event shall any
such sign be posted on any private property without the permission of the owner, and in no event upon any Village or other public property. (1984 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 106/702
Chapter 22
AMPLIFIERS
3-22-1: OPERATION IN THE VILLAGE:
No person or entity shall operate a device by which sounds are magnified and made heard over any public street or public place without first having
secured an amplifier permit issued by the Community Development Director or designee. (Ord. 2017-19, 3-7-2017)
3-22-2: AMPLIFIER REGULATIONS:
