A. No permittee shall use or operate or employ any such device within the radius of two (2) blocks from any hospital or within the radius of two (2) blocks
of any religious institution while services are being held therein.
B. The hours to use, operate or employ any such amplified device within the Village limits shall be between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to the
hour of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. Monday through Saturday and between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to the hour of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
on Sunday.
C. This section shall not apply to radios in homes or in private vehicles, when the same are operated in such a manner as not to be audible at a distance
of fifty feet (50') from such vehicle, nor to noise devices, bands or other musical devices used in any public parade or procession which is operated
under a permit in accordance with the ordinances of the Village.
D. Whenever the Community Development Director or designee determines that it is in the public interest, an extended amplifier permit may be issued
authorizing a permittee to use such devices in the Village for not more than five (5) days at a time during such hours as the Community Development
Director or designee may establish in such an extended amplifier permit, not before six o'clock (6:00) A.M.
E. No permittee shall cause or permit to be emanated or emitted from any such device any lewd, obscene, profane or indecent language, sounds, or any
false representation of any matter, product or project advertised thereby, the sale of which is prohibited by any law, ordinance or statute.
F. An amplifier permit may be denied by the Community Development Director or designee from an applicant who has previously received documented
complaints by the Police Department or Code Enforcement of excessive noise or extending the amplification beyond the permitted hours of operation.
(Ord. 2017-143, 11-7-2017)
Chapter 23
BARBER SHOPS
3-23-1: SANITARY REQUIREMENTS:
A. General: It shall be the duty of the licensee at all times to keep the licensed premises in a clean and proper sanitary condition. All persons employed or
working in the licensed premises as barbers shall keep themselves and their clothing clean, and shall be required to wash their hands immediately
before serving a customer. All towels and washcloths shall be washed with soap and water and boiled before being used. All receptacles, finger bowls,
utensils, vessels and appliances shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. Separate receptacles shall be provided for soiled towels and separate
receptacles for receiving discarded shaving and other paper.
B. Precautionary Measures: It shall be the duty of every person licensed to conduct a barber shop to at all times keep the licensed premises in a clean and
proper sanitary condition. All necessary measures shall be taken to properly safeguard the life and health of patrons and all persons engaged therein
against communicable and contagious diseases. No person who is afflicted with any communicable or contagious disease shall be permitted to be
employed or engaged in shaving, haircutting or other tonsorial work on patrons.
3-23-2: LIMITATION ON LOCATION:
No barber shops shall be located or conducted except as an independent unit, completely equipped as such and separated from any living, dining or
sleeping apartment, restaurant or food establishment, and such premises shall be adequately ventilated. (1984 Code)
Chapter 24
ALARMS
3-24-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with
the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words used in the singular number include the plural number.
ALARM AGENT: Any person working for an alarm business.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 107/702
ALARM BUSINESS: See section 3-24-3 of this chapter, private alarm contractor.
ALARM SYSTEM: An assembly of equipment arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which the police are expected
to respond.
ALARM USER: Any person on whose premises an alarm system is maintained within the village limits, except for alarm systems on a motor vehicle.
ANSWERING SERVICE: A service which receives on a continuous basis through trained employees emergency signals from alarm systems and
thereafter immediately relays the message by live voice through a telephone system to the village's communication center.
CENTRAL STATION: A system in which the operation of electrical protection circuits and devices are signaled automatically to, recorded in, maintained
and supervised from a place of business having trained operators and guards in attendance at all times.
DIGITAL COMMUNICATORS (Also Called AUTOMATIC DIALING ALARM EQUIPMENT): An alarm system which has the capability of transmitting system
signals which are received at the village's communication center or DU-COMM or any communication center and in which the alarm user uses his existing
telephone lines instead of a dedicated line.
FALSE ALARM: The activation of an alarm system through mechanical or electronic failure, malfunction, improper installation or the negligence of the
owner or lessee of an alarm system or his employees or agents, except that the following shall not be considered false alarms:
A. Alarms caused by the failure or malfunction of equipment located in the village's communication center.
B. Alarms occurring on a repeated basis without apparent cause, but where a continuous good faith effort is being made jointly by the alarm user, the
alarm business and any other concerned person to correct the malfunction expeditiously with written verification as determined by the alarm review
officer.
C. Alarms caused by an attempted illegal entry, of which there is visible evidence.
D. Alarms caused by an on premises fire.
E. Alarms intentionally caused by a person acting under a reasonable belief that a need exists to call the police department.
HARD WIRED ALARMS: An alarm system which has the capability of transmitting system signals which are received at the village's communication center
over dedicated lines.
MODIFIED CENTRAL STATION SYSTEM: An office to which remote alarm and supervisory signaling devices are connected, where operators supervise
the circuits.
ON PREMISES ALARM: An alarm system installed for the purposes of alerting people on premises to an emergency condition. Police personnel do not
respond to this alarm unless notified further by persons on the affected premises.
ON PREMISES ALARM WITH OUTSIDE RINGER: An alarm system that audibly announces an emergency condition to which police personnel are
required to respond.
VOICE DIALING ALARM EQUIPMENT: An alarm system which automatically sends over regular telephone lines, by direct connection or otherwise, a
prerecorded voice message indicating the existence of an emergency situation which the alarm system is designed to detect. (1984 Code; amd. Ord. 94-
89, 9-20-1994)
3-24-2: POLICE CHIEF AS ADMINISTRATOR:
The police chief, or his designee, shall be charged with the administration within the village of the appropriate provisions of this chapter. (1984 Code)
3-24-3: PRIVATE ALARM CONTRACTOR:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as licensing private alarm contractors. (1984 Code)
3-24-4: CENTRAL STATIONS; MODIFIED CENTRAL STATIONS; ANSWERING SERVICES:
A. No person or entity shall cause or permit any central station, modified central station, answering service, digital communicator, automatic dialing alarm
equipment or voice dialing alarm equipment to transmit any alarm over the existing telephone lines of DU-COMM or the Bartlett police department.
B. Any central station, modified central station or answering service shall also meet the following minimum requirements:
1. The premises from which its business is to be conducted shall: a) meet the requirements of the Bartlett building code and the regulations of the
Bartlett fire protection district; and b) be reasonably secure.
2. A sufficient number of operators shall be on duty at all times to assure that all emergency messages received will be relayed immediately to DUCOMM.
3. As soon as possible after notifying DU-COMM, the operator concerned shall notify the subscriber involved of such action and the nature of the
emergency.
4. Each alarm user shall be required to cooperate in a test of its alarm equipment at least once a year to determine if each device is working properly
and shall submit the results of such test to the chief of police.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 108/702
5. When any test result indicates that any alarm system is not functioning in accordance with the standards set forth in section 3-24-5 of this chapter,
the chief of police shall be notified within twenty four (24) hours. (Ord. 2001-07, 1-16-2001)
3-24-5: ALARM USERS:
No person or entity under any circumstances shall use an alarm system which uses voice dialing alarm equipment connected to the telephone system of
DU-COMM or the Bartlett police department. Nothing herein contained shall be construed as prohibiting any person or entity from using an alarm system,
which is connected directly to an alarm panel at DU-COMM or the Bartlett police department, activating an alarm system there without using the telephone
lines of DU-COMM or the Bartlett police department.
A. Standards:
1. All alarm systems installed in commercial, residential or public buildings after the effective date hereof shall utilize equipment and methods of
installation substantially equivalent to or exceeding applicable Underwriters' Laboratories (UL) and American national standards institute (ANSI)
standards and all applicable village codes.
2. New installations shall be inspected by the village's building inspector or electrical inspector to ascertain compliance with both UL and ANSI
standards and applicable village codes.
3. The alarm user shall be responsible for: a) maintaining the system in good repair to assure reliability of operation; and b) having the alarm system
repaired as quickly as possible after any malfunction is detected.
4. Each alarm user who has an on premises alarm with an outside ringer shall cause such outside ringer to be turned off within thirty (30) minutes after
it is activated.
5. Alarm users with voice dialing systems shall disconnect them within sixty (60) days after the effective date of this chapter. (Ord. 2001-07, 1-16-2001)
B. False Alarm Charges: Any alarm user shall be charged a service charge for false alarms emanating from his, her or its alarm system and transmitted to
the police department or its designee, during the calendar year starting January 1 through December 31, in accordance with the following schedule:
0 - 4 false alarms No charge
5 - 8 false alarms $ 50.00 for each false alarm
9 - more 100.00 for each false alarm
The same schedule of charges for false alarms shall apply to any outside ringer alarm system which causes a false alarm.
C. Notice: After the police department has recorded four (4) alarm occurrences in any calendar year, it shall notify the alarm user, in writing, by first class
mail of such fact and that additional false alarms will result in service charges in accordance with the schedule set forth in subsection B of this section.
Upon additional alarm occurrences, the village of Bartlett crime prevention unit will notify the village of Bartlett finance department and the licensee
and/or alarm owner will be invoiced by the finance department for the service charge(s) which have been imposed in accordance with subsection B of
this section. The finance department will be provided with names, addresses, the number of violations, the date and time of each such violation and the
applicable fines, penalties and/or alarm service charges to be assessed to each violator. The licensee and/or owner of the offending alarm shall have
thirty (30) days from the date said invoice is mailed to appeal the charges to the alarm review officer designated by the police chief to hear said
appeals. The finance department shall notify the licensee and/or the owner of the offending alarm in writing by mailing a written notice setting forth the
date and time of each such violations and an invoice setting forth the fines, penalties and/or alarm services charges imposed in accordance with the
schedule set forth in subsection B of this section, and shall further apprise the licensee and/or the owner that he, she or it has thirty (30) days from the
mailing of said notice to pay the fines, penalties and alarm service charges or to appeal the imposition of such fines, penalties and alarm service
charges. Failure to appeal fines, penalties and/or alarm service charges involved within said thirty (30) days of the mailing of said notice by the finance
department shall constitute a waiver of the right to appeal said fines, penalties and/or service charges. (Ord. 94-89, 9-20-1994)
3-24-6: INSPECTION OF ALARM DEVICES AND BUSINESSES:
A. For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this chapter, the police chief or his designee shall have the authority with the permission of the occupant,
at reasonable times and upon reasonable oral notice, to enter any premises in the village in or upon which an alarm system or an alarm business in
which an alarm system or a central station, modified central station or answering service is located to inspect the installation and/or operation of such
alarm system or business.
B. If such inspection reveals any violation of the provisions of this chapter, a written report detailing such violation shall be promptly sent to the alarm user.
Such report shall require corrections to be accomplished within thirty (30) days after receipt of the notice of the violation. The alarm user and/or owner
shall be granted a reasonable extension of time to correct such violations upon good cause shown. (Ord. 2001-07, 1-16-2001)
3-24-7: TESTING OF EQUIPMENT:
Nothing contained herein shall be construed as a contract or agreement by the village to provide any special services to alarm users or to respond to
alarms other than in the ordinary course of police operations on the basis of available manpower and patrol cars. No alarm system designed to transmit
emergency messages directly by telephone to DU-COMM or the police department shall be tested or demonstrated without permission from the police
chief. Permission is not required to test or demonstrate alarm devices not transmitting emergency messages directly by telephone to the police department
unless the messages are to be relayed to the police department. (1984 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 109/702
3-24-8: NONLIABILITY OF THE VILLAGE:
The village shall not be liable for any defects in operation of the alarm systems or signal line systems, for any failure or neglect to respond appropriately to
an emergency call from any establishment with a license or permit issued pursuant to this chapter. In the event that the village finds it necessary to
disconnect any emergency alarm system, the village shall incur no liability by such action. (1984 Code)
3-24-9: DISCONNECTION OF ALARM SYSTEM AND TERMINATION OF SERVICE:
A. An alarm user's alarm system shall be disconnected from DU-COMM and/or the police department and service terminated as provided in subsection C
of this section for any of the following causes:
1. Violation of this chapter or any of its provisions;
2. Fraudulent information provided by the alarm user;
3. More than twelve (12) false alarms in any one calendar year (January 1 through December 31);
B. In the event an alarm user's alarm system shall be disconnected from DU-COMM and/or the police department, the police department shall have no
responsibility or obligation to respond to any alarm transmitted by said alarm system.
C. 1. The chief of police shall designate an alarm review officer in all cases where an alarm user's alarm system is sought to be disconnected from the
police department and/or DU-COMM and service terminated. An alarm review officer designated by the chief of police shall notify the alarm user in
writing by certified mail, return receipt requested, that the village intends to disconnect his, her or its alarm system from the police department, its
designee and/or DU-COMM, and/or terminate service for a violation of subsection A of this section and that said alarm user has a right to a hearing
before a designee of the chief of police to determine whether or not the alarm system should be disconnected from the police department, its designee
and/or DU-COMM and/or services terminated. Said notice shall further inform the alarm user that he, she or it must request said hearing in writing
within thirty (30) days of the date of said notice, and that failure of said alarm user to request a hearing within said thirty (30) day period will result in the
alarm user waiving his, her or its right to a hearing.
2. If a hearing is requested within said thirty (30) days, a hearing will be convened within fifteen (15) days of receipt by the police chief or the police
chief's designee. At such hearing, the alarm review officer shall present evidence of the violation or cause on the basis of which the alarm system
should be disconnected and services disconnected and the alarm user or his/her or its attorney shall have the right to examine witnesses and
present evidence on behalf of the alarm user. After conclusion of the hearing, the designee of the chief of police presiding over such hearing shall
make a finding of fact and conclusion of law as to whether or not there is cause for the alarm system to be disconnected and/or services
discontinued, and shall submit such findings and conclusions to the village clerk within fifteen (15) days of the conclusion of said hearing. If no
hearing is requested within said thirty (30) days of the mailing of the notice, the alarm review officer shall so notify the chief of police.
D. If the alarm user fails to request a hearing, or at the conclusion of a hearing conducted pursuant to subsection C of this section, the alarm review officer
determines that said alarm system should be disconnected and/or service terminated, then the chief of police or his designee shall cause the alarm
system to be disconnected from the police department, its designee and/or DU-COMM and service terminated. (Ord. 2001-07, 1-16-2001)
3-24-10: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), and each
day a violation continues shall be considered a separate violation. (Ord. 2001-07, 1-16-2001)
Chapter 25
FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS
3-25-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and terms shall have the meaning set forth, except where otherwise specifically indicated. Words and terms not defined shall have the
meaning indicated by common dictionary definition.
BACTERICIDAL TREATMENT: The application of any method or substance for the destruction of pathogens and all other organisms, so far as practicable,
and which, in the opinion of the Health Officer, is effective and does not adversely affect the food, drink or equipment with which it comes in contact, or the
health of the consumer of such food or drink.
EMPLOYEE: Any person who handles food or drink during preparation, processing, packaging, storing, handling, transporting or serving, or who comes in
contact with any eating or cooking utensils, or who is employed in a room in which food or drink is prepared or served.
UTENSILS: Any kitchenware, tableware, glassware, cutlery, containers or other equipment with which food or drink comes in contact during storage,
transportation, preparation or serving.
3-25-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
In addition to the matters set forth in Section 3-1-3, an application for a food establishment license shall specify the kinds of foods and beverages intended
to be sold by the licensee, and shall contain such information as may be required by the Health Officer in order to inform him fully as to the size and nature
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 110/702
of the food establishment, the conditions, equipment and facilities for conducting the business therein, the health of the persons to be employed and the
regulations and facilities provided for them.
3-25-3: MOBILE FOOD ESTABLISHMENT, LICENSE APPLICATIONS:
An application for a mobile food establishment license shall be submitted on a form provided by the Village Clerk and shall include, in addition to the
information required under Sections 3-1-3 and 3-25-2, the following information: Number of vehicles to be used in Bartlett, license plate numbers of
vehicles to be used in Bartlett, location of stops, schedule of stops, and food source information. Each application shall be accompanied by 1) certified
copy of health certificate, 2) authorization for investigation, and 3) safety inspection sheet for each vehicle to be used in Bartlett. (1984 Code)
3-25-4: SPECIAL REGULATIONS FOR FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS:
A. The Food Service Sanitation Rules and Regulations promulgated by the Director of Public Health of the State of Illinois in December, 1975, and
amendments thereto, in accordance with the Sanitary Inspection Act,1 the Illinois Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act,2 subparagraph (c) of section 2 of "An
Act in Relation to Public Health"3 and chapter 10 "Compliance Provisions" of the 1976 and subsequent editions of the Food and Drug Administration
"Food Service Sanitation Ordinance", except sections 10-601 and 10-602, are hereby adopted by reference. In addition, each licensee shall comply
with the provisions of: (Ord. 85-42, 4-23-85)
1. "An Act to prevent the preparation, manufacture, packing, storing or distribution of food intended for sale or sale of food, under unsanitary,
unhealthful or unclean conditions or surroundings, to create a sanitary inspection, to declare that such conditions shall constitute a nuisance, and to
provide for the enforcement thereof."4
2. "An Act regulating the handling, processing, labeling, sale and distribution of pasteurized milk and pasteurized milk products."5
3. "An Act in relation to Grade A Milk and Grade A Milk Products, and to repeal a certain Act named herein."6
4. "An Act in relation to milk and milk products for human consumption."7
5. "An Act in relation to the wholesomeness and safety of milk and milk products."8 (1984 Code)
6. The issuance, suspension and revocation of permits to operate retail food establishments, the prohibiting of sale of unsound or mislabeled food or
drink and the enforcement of this Ordinance shall be regulated in accordance with chapter 10 compliance procedures of the 1976 and subsequent
editions of the Food and Drug Administration "Food Service Sanitation Ordinance"; the inspection of food service establishments shall be regulated
in accordance with the current and subsequent Illinois Department of Public Health, "Food Service Sanitation Rules and Regulations" on file with the
Secretary of State; the inspection of retail food stores shall be regulated in accordance with the Illinois Department of Public Health "Retail Food
Store Sanitation Rules and Regulations" on file with the Secretary of State. One certified copy of the Food and Drug Administration "Food Service
Sanitation Ordinance", Illinois Department of Public Health "Food Service Sanitation Rules and Regulations" and the Illinois Department of Public
Health "Retail Food Store Sanitation Rules and Regulations" shall be on file at the office of the Village Clerk. (Ord. 85-42, 4-23-85)
B. All bottles, cans, packages and other containers enclosing milk or any milk pro ducts shall be plainly marked or labeled with the following and only such
other information as may be designated by the Health Officer:
1. On all cans, bottles and other containers of pasteurized or certified milk, the words "not to be sold after" and thereafter the date on which the milk or
milk product is to be sold to the final consumer, the height of the letters of the day of the week to be not less than three-sixteenths inch (3/16") on the
label of single service paper containers or on bottle caps where such are used, and not less than five-eighths inch (5/8") on tags attached to each
container when (contained in cans) the product is marketed in bulk containers.
2. On all cans and other containers of milk and milk products received by pasteurization plants from receiving stations, the day of the week received by
the receiving station.
3. The word "milk" shall not appear or be used on any label, cap, receptacle or container for any products except milk, skimmed milk, buttermilk,
cultured buttermilk, vitamin D milk and any other products designated by the Health Officer.
C. All pasteurized milk, cream, half and half, low fat and skimmed milk shall be sold not later than nine (9) days from the date of pasteurization, and such
maximum time limit shall be designated on the label in accordance with the provisions of subsection B1 above.
D. Any person violating any provision of this Section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and be punished by a fine of not less than ten dollars
($10.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day such violation is committed or
permitted to continue, and shall be punishable hereunder as such.
3-25-5: INSPECTION OF FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS AND RESTAURANTS:
At least every six (6) months the Health Officer shall inspect every food establishment and restaurant located within the Village. In case the Health Officer
discovers the violation of any item of sanitation, he shall make a second inspection after the lapse of such time as he deems necessary for the defect to be
remedied, and the second inspection shall be used in determining compliance with the requirements of this Chapter. If the Health Officer finds, on such
second inspection, the violation to be a serious menace to public health, he may immediately suspend the license. The person operating the food
establishment shall, upon request of the Health Officer, permit access to all parts of the establishment or restaurant, and shall permit copying any or all
records of food purchased.
3-25-6: GENERAL PROTECTIVE MEASURES FOR FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 111/702
A. All food which is received and which is intended to be used and prepared for human consumption, upon being received by any person in any fooddispensing
establishment, shall be so stored, displayed and served as to be protected from dust, flies, vermin, depredation and pollution by rodents,
unnecessary handling, droplet infection, overhead leakage and other contamination.
B. No animals or fowl shall be kept or allowed in any room in which food or drink is prepared or served. This applies to all dogs, except dogs known and
used as seeing-eye dogs.
C. All means necessary for the elimination of flies, roaches and rodents shall be used. Evidence of the presence of rodents, roaches, ants or other vermin
shall be considered as a violation of this Section.
D. Food or drink shall not be stored beneath overhead sewer or drain pipes. Food or drink shall not be stored in areas of the building which are subject to
flooding from sewage backflow.
E. The pouring lips of bottles containing milk or other beverages shall not be submerged in water for cooling.
F. All food and drink shall be handled in such a manner as to minimize the opportunities for contamination.
G. All unwrapped or unenclosed food and drink on display shall be protected by glass or otherwise from public handling or other contamination, except that
approved hand openings for self-service may be permitted on counter fronts.
H. Food dispensers' establishments shall be effectively rodent-proofed.
3-25-7: DISEASE CONTROL:
A. Every person connected with a food establishment or restaurant, whose work brings him in contact with the handling of food, drink, utensils or
equipment, shall, prior to commencing his employment, and at least annually thereafter, obtain a tuberculin test, or a chest X-ray, and a VDRL blood
test taken by an approved laboratory.
B. Any other examination or test which may be deemed necessary by the Health Officer to assure him that the food handler is free from any communicable
disease, or is not a carrier of any disease likely to be transmitted through food, drink or utensils, shall be submitted to by the food handler as requested.
C. No person who is affected with any disease in a communicable form or is a carrier of such disease, shall work in any food establishment or restaurant.
No food establishment or restaurant shall employ any such person or any persons suspected of being affected with any disease in a communicable
form or of being a carrier of such disease. If the person in charge of any food establishment or restaurant suspects that any employee has contracted
any disease in a communicable form, or has become a carrier of such disease, he shall notify the Health Officer immediately. Any food handler finding
it necessary to blow his nose shall use disposable tissues and wash his hands immediately thereafter and before returning to work.
D. When suspicion arises as to the probability of transmission of infection from any food establishment or restaurant employee, the Health Officer is
authorized to require the following measures:
1. The immediate exclusion of the employee from all food establishments and restaurants.
2. The immediate closing of the food establishment or restaurant concerned until no further danger of disease outbreak exists in the opinion of the
Health Officer.
3. Adequate medical examinations of the employee and of his associates, with such laboratory examinations as may be deemed necessary under the
circumstances.
3-25-8: SPECIAL REGULATIONS FOR ITINERANT FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS:
The Health Officer shall approve an itinerant food establishment only if it complies with the following sanitary requirements:
A. It shall be located in clean, sanitary surroundings and be kept in a clean, sanitary condition. It shall be so constructed and arranged that food, drink,
utensils and equipment will not be exposed to insects or to dust or other contamination. Only food and drink which is clean, wholesome and free from
adulteration shall be sold or served. An adequate supply of water of a safe, sanitary quality shall be easily available and used for drinking and for
cleaning of utensils and equipment. Only single-service containers and utensils such as plates, cups, knives, forks and spoons shall be used to serve
food or drink. Hot water with a proper detergent shall be used to thoroughly wash all other utensils and equipment, after which the utensils and
equipment shall be subjected to an approved bactericidal process and be so handled and kept as to be protected from contamination. Adequate
provisions shall be made for refrigeration of perishable food and drink. Ice used in or with food or drink shall be from a source approved by the Health
Officer and so handled as to avoid contamination.
B. Garbage and refuse shall be kept in watertight containers, tightly covered until removed, and shall be disposed of in a place and manner approved by
the Health Officer. Liquid wastes shall be so disposed of as not to create a nuisance.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 112/702
C. No person suffering from any disease transmittable by contact or through food or drink, or who is a carrier of the terms of such a disease, shall be
employed in any capacity. Adequate and satisfactory toilet and hand-washing facilities shall be readily accessible to employees. No person engaged in
handling or serving food or drink shall return to his work after using the toilet without first thoroughly washing his hands.
3-25-9: SPECIAL REGULATIONS FOR MOBILE FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS:
Any food sold from an ambulatory vehicle shall be in the original container or packaged in a sanitary manner and shall be prepared and processed under
regulations of the Health Officer, with the exception of fruits and vegetables in their natural state. No food shall be prepared, packaged or processed in the
vehicle. If necessary, proper refrigeration shall be provided. The vehicle must be constructed and maintained to meet all sanitary requirements of the
Health Officer.
3-25-10: VEGETABLE AND FRUIT STANDS:
All establishments selling fresh vegetables and fruits from stands during the warm months when vegetables and fruits are in season will be given
permission to operate under the following regulations to sell vegetables and fruits in their natural state only:
A. The stands must have a roof, backwall and two (2) end walls, the front of which must be screened with sixteen inch (16") mesh.
B. The floor must be of cement and must be kept clean.
C. A sink with running water must be on the premises for washing fruits and vegetables. A toilet and lavatory with adequate hand-washing facilities must
be available.
3-25-11: UNWHOLESOME OR ADULTERATED FOOD AND DRINK:
A. Samples of food, drink and other substances may be taken and examined by the Health Officer as often as may be necessary for the detection of
unwholesomeness or adulteration. The Health Officer may condemn and forbid the sale of, or cause to be removed or destroyed, any food or drink
which is unwholesome or adulterated.
B. No person shall vend or attempt to vend in the Village any fruit, vegetable or other article of food that may be decayed or partially rotten, or that may
have been taken from any barrel, box or other receptacle for the same, or from any public way in the Village.
3-25-12: UTENSILS AND EQUIPMENT:
A. Construction: All multi-use utensils and all show and display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerating equipment, sinks and other
equipment or utensils used in connection with the operation of a restaurant shall be so constructed as to be easily cleaned and shall be kept in good
repair.
B. Cleaning and Bactericidal Treatment: All equipment, including display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerators, stoves, hoods and
sinks shall be kept clean and free from dust, dirt, insects and other contaminating material. All cloths used by waiters, chefs and other employees shall
be clean. Single-service containers shall be used only once.
All multi-use eating and drinking utensils shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process after each usage.
All multi-use utensils used in the preparation or serving of food and drink shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved
bactericidal process immediately following the day's operation. Drying cloths, if used, shall be clean and used for no other purpose.
No article, polish or other substance containing any cyanide preparation or other poisonous materials shall be used for the cleaning or polishing of
utensils.
C. Storage And Handling: After bactericidal treatment, utensils shall be stored in a clean, dry place protected from flies, dust and other contamination, and
shall be handled in such a manner as to prevent contamination as far as practicable. Single-service utensils shall be purchased only in sanitary
containers, and shall be stored therein in a clean, dry place until used, and shall be handled in a sanitary manner. (1984 Code)
Chapter 26
SCAVENGERS
3-26-1: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
No person or entity shall operate a scavenger service in the Village unless he maintains in effect at all times insurance coverage in accordance with the
following requirements:
Any licensee operating a scavenger service under this Chapter shall defend, indemnify, protect and save harmless the Village, its officials, officers,
employees, agents, consultants and volunteers working on behalf of the Village, from and against liability, losses, physical damage to property, and bodily
injury or death to persons, including payments made under any worker's compensation law, which may arise out of the licensee's operation of its
scavenger service within or without the limits of the Village. Each licensee shall further indemnify and hold harmless the Village, its officials, officers,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 113/702
employees, agents, consultants and volunteers while acting on behalf of the Village, from and against any liability or losses sustained as a direct or indirect
result of the action of the licensee's agents or employees or in any way arising out of the granting of his license. Each licensee shall carry commercial
general liability insurance with an insurance company licensed to do business in the State, said insurance company having a rating of B+:VII or better in
the latest edition of the Best & Co. Insurance Guide. The policy limits for the commercial general liability insurance shall be not less than one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) combined single limit per occurrence for bodily injury, personal injury and property damage with a general aggregate not less than two
million dollars ($2,000,000.00). The policy limits for the business automobile liability insurance shall be not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00)
combine single limit per accident for bodily injury and property damage. Such insurance to be utilized to protect the licensee and the Village, its officials,
officers, employees, agents, consultants and volunteers while acting on behalf of the Village, as their interests may appear, from and against all claims,
demands, actions, judgments, costs, expenses and liabilities, including, without limitation, attorney's fees which may arise or result directly or indirectly
from or by reason of any such liability, loss, injury or damage. Said policy shall contain a provision requiring the insured to notify the Village not less than
ten (10) days prior to cancellation or change of any policy. The Village, its officials, officers, employees, agents, consultants and volunteers while acting on
behalf of the Village, shall appear as additional named insureds under each policy. At least ten (10) days prior to commencing any operations in the
Village, the licensee shall provide the Village with certificates of insurance for each policy. Each licensee shall also carry such insurance as may be
necessary to protect it and the Village from all claims under the worker's compensation laws from time to time in effect that may be applicable to the
licensee. All insurance required by this Chapter shall remain in full force and effect for the entire license period. The certificate(s) of insurance, and, if
requested by the Village Attorney, the policies of insurance, or a certified copy or copies thereof, shall be approved by the Village Attorney and shall be
deposited with and kept on file by the Village Clerk. (Ord. 96-14, 2-6-1995)
3-26-2: SPECIAL REGULATIONS AFFECTING SCAVENGERS:
Any person or entity engaged in the business of collecting garbage in the Village shall provide not less than the following services and employ equipment
and personnel in accordance with the standards hereinafter set forth:
A. Materials: Materials to be collected shall include:
1. All kitchen wastes including cans, bottles, household food, accumulation of animal food and vegetable matter attendant on the preparation, use,
cooking and serving of foods.
2. General household trash and refuse, including ashes, empty cartons, crates, boxes, wrapping materials, newspapers and magazines when securely
and neatly bound in convenient size bundles, cloth materials, empty cans and discarded toys, discarded clothing and similar materials.
3. Discarded furniture including beds, springs, mattresses, overstuffed furniture and other furniture, appliances, bicycles, sleds, swing sets, tools and
comparable items.
4. Yard refuse materials, including leaves, grass clippings, weeds, Christmas trees, bushes, brush clippings and branch clippings (when securely
bound in bundles not exceeding 4 feet in length).
5. Materials to be collected weekly shall be limited to twelve (12) bags, or one cubic yard, whichever is greater, with the exception of small branches
bundled as provided in subsection A4 above. This does not include small amounts of earth and sod when placed in cans and not exceeding twenty
five percent (25%) of the capacity of the can. Building materials resulting from "do it yourself" projects not exceeding one cubic yard in capacity will
be collected when placed at the curb in a neat and orderly manner. (1984 Code)
B. Service:
1. Definitions:
GARBAGE COLLECTOR: A person, firm, corporation or entity who collects garbage for hire in Bartlett.
RECYCLING CONTAINER: A container furnished by the Village of Bartlett for the recycling of garbage and bearing the identification label of a
garbage collector.
2. Curbside Collection Service For Recyclables:
a. No garbage collector shall collect garbage in the Village unless such garbage collector shall provide a special curbside collection service for
aluminum and bi-metal cans, newspapers and glass bottles on the same day as such garbage collector's regular collection.
b. Each garbage collector shall be required to provide curbside recycling pick up service for all of its customers in Bartlett who voluntarily participate
in such recycling program regardless of whether such customers are located in an area of the Village where such garbage collector provides
garbage collection service for a substantial group of customers whose properties are contiguous to, or located near, each other.
c. Garbage collectors shall be entitled to charge all of the customers in the Village for whom they currently provide service an additional fee not to
exceed one dollar forty five cents ($1.45) per month to pay for the cost of providing such recycling service, regardless of whether such residents
participate in the voluntary recycling program. (Ord. 88-108, 11-15-1988)
3. Collection And Removal Of Garbage: Garbage shall be collected and removed from every residential unit in the Village at least once weekly.
Residents shall place containers at curbs, or at rear entrance to dwellings, depending on each resident's choice of service, no earlier than six o'clock
(6:00) P.M. on the day preceding the day of scavenger pickup and the empty garbage containers shall be removed not later than nine o'clock (9:00)
A.M. on the day following the day of scavenger pickup. However, residents desiring rear door service shall place all items described in subsections
A2, 3 and 4 above at the curb, unless the garbage truck can be driven to within ten feet (10') of such items over a hard surface driveway at least ten
feet (10') wide. Residents need not segregate residential trash and refuse, but all food waste shall be wrapped in paper and no liquids may be placed
in trash containers. All other items that do not fit in the containers as well as the containers shall be placed neatly at the curb line, except for rear
door service, subject to the conditions aforesaid. Lids shall be kept on containers when placed outside for collection. In the event the regularly
scheduled pickup falls on a legal holiday, the scavenger shall make garbage pickup on the day following said legal holiday, except when such
holidays falls on Saturday, in which case the garbage pickup shall be made on the day previous to said legal holiday.
4. Office Of Scavenger: The scavenger shall maintain an office and telephone for the receipt of service calls or complaints and shall be available for
such calls on all business days from eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to four thirty o'clock (4:30) P.M. All complaints shall be given prompt and courteous
attention and in the case of alleged missed scheduled collections, the scavenger shall investigate and if such allegations are verified, shall arrange
for the pickup of all disposal materials not collected within a reasonable time after the complaint is received.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 114/702
C. Equipment: The scavenger shall use exclusively: enclosed leakproof packer-type disposal truck bodies, equipped with airtight covers for such portions
as are used for the transportation of garbage.
D. Disposal Facilities: The scavenger shall own, or have a minimum five (5) year lease securing availability of, a suitable garbage incinerator or sanitary
landfill dump site, at which all refuse collected in and removed from the Village may be disposed of and shall stipulate the location and size thereof, in
the license application. The scavenger shall also own and have available for use within the Village, immediately upon issuance of the license, sanitary
refuse disposal truck bodies and equipment as herein specified.
E. Disposal Services: The scavenger shall furnish capable employees for use in the crews of the scavenger performing the disposal service specified in
the agreement. The scavenger shall prohibit any drinking of alcoholic beverages by its drivers and crew members while on duty, or in the course of
performing their duties under said contract. The scavenger shall also cover all such employees with workmen's compensation insurance coverage, with
the Village as an additional named insured, and thereon provide the Village with a certificate or other evidence of insurance.
F. Compliance With Laws: The scavenger shall comply at all times with all applicable State statutes and Village ordinances and regulations. (1984 Code)
3-26-3: FINDINGS OF FACT CONCERNING RECYCLING OF CERTAIN WASTE PRODUCTS:
The corporate authorities have made the following findings of fact:
A. The recycling of certain waste products, including, but not limited to, aluminum and bi-metal cans, newspapers and glass bottles is vital to the
conservation of America's natural resources.
B. The inclusion of aluminum and bi-metal cans, newspapers and glass bottles in the garbage generated by the residents of the Village and other villages
increases the volume of garbage which must ultimately be disposed of in sanitary landfills.
C. The continued disposal of aluminum and bi-metal cans, newspapers and glass bottles generated by residents of the Village and other villages will
exacerbate the shortage of landfills.
D. The Village has determined that the proliferation of sanitary landfills in the Bartlett area will endanger the health, welfare and safety of the residents of
the Village, their children and grandchildren for many years to come.
E. By eliminating aluminum and bi-metal cans, newspapers and glass bottles from the stream of garbage, the capacity of existing landfills to serve the
needs of the Village for the disposal of nonrecyclable garbage will be increased and extended for several years.
F. In the interim, science may find new technological methods for the safe disposition of household garbage without threatening the pollution of our air and
our water supplies.
G. The Village has called upon the private contractors who collect garbage from residences in the Village to provide the Village with a curbside recycling
program for aluminum and bi-metal cans, newspapers and glass bottles on the same day as their regular garbage pickup.
H. The private disposal contractors who provide garbage pickup service in the Village have offered to provide such special recycling service upon the
condition that all of the private contractors who collect garbage in the Village shall provide such recycling service.
I. If some of the private contractors who collect garbage in the Village do not participate in the recycling program, the contractors who do participate in the
recycling program will be at a competitive disadvantage as the result of which they will not be able to provide this vitally needed recycling service. (Ord.
88-108, 11-15-1988)
Chapter 27
MOBILE HOMES AND MOBILE HOME PARKS
3-27-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and terms shall have the meaning set forth, except where otherwise specifically indicated. Words and terms not defined shall have the
meaning indicated by common dictionary definition:
THE ACT: The Mobile Home and Mobile Home Park Act.1
APPLICANT: Any person or entity making application for a license or permit.
BUILDING DIRECTOR: The Building Director of the Village of Bartlett.
CARETAKER: The person in charge of and responsible for the operation and maintenance of a mobile home park.
CLERK: The Village Clerk of the Village of Bartlett.

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 115/702
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Bartlett.

3-27-2: LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
No person shall establish, maintain, conduct or operate a mobile home park in the Village after the effective date of this Chapter, without first obtaining a
license therefor from the Village. Applications for mobile home park licenses shall be made in writing under oath to the Village Clerk, and shall contain the
information set out in the following sections.
3-27-3: ANNUAL LICENSE APPLICATIONS:
The annual application for renewal of a mobile home park license shall contain the following information:
A. Applicant's name, including any business or assumed name used or proposed to be used by applicant.
1. If the applicant is a corporation, the information requested in subsection A must be furnished for each officer, director and shareholder who owns or
controls, directly or indirectly through any other person or entity, twenty five percent (25%) or more of the outstanding stock of such corporation.
2. If the applicant is a partnership, the information requested in subsection A must be furnished for each general and limited partner, indicating which
partners are general and which are limited.
3. If the applicant is a joint venture, the information requested in subsection A must be furnished for each joint venturer.
4. If the applicant is a trust, the information requested in subsection A must be furnished for each trust beneficiary.
B. The name and address of the mobile home park and the telephone number at which its manager, attendant, caretaker or other responsible person in
charge may be contacted at all times in case of emergency.
3-27-4: ORIGINAL LICENSE APPLICATIONS:
In addition to the information specified in Section 3-27-3, the original application for a license to operate a mobile home park shall contain all of the
information required under section 4 of The Act, incorporated herein by reference.
3-27-5: LICENSE FEES:
Each application shall be accompanied by the annual license fee set out in Section 3-1-1 of this Municipal Code.
3-27-6: TERM, RENEWAL:
Licenses will be valid until May 1 of the year following the date of issuance, but will be extended for additional periods of not to exceed one year by the
corporate authorities, provided the licensee is not then in violation of this Chapter.
3-27-7: NONTRANSFERABILITY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 116/702
No license issued under this Chapter shall be transferable without the approval of the corporate authorities, which approval will not be refused if the mobile
home park and the transferee are in compliance with the provisions of this Chapter.
3-27-8: CONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Mobile Home Construction Standards: Every mobile home placed upon a site in the Village after the effective date of this Chapter shall meet the
minimum requirements of the Mobile Home Construction and Safety Standards Act (24 CFR Part 3280, effective March 30, 1979), incorporated herein
by reference.
B. No licensee shall cause or permit a mobile home to be placed on a site in a mobile home park without first filing with the Village Clerk a written
certification from the manufacturer of such mobile home that it meets the minimum requirements of the Mobile Home Construction and Safety
Standards Act.
C. Securing the Mobile Home to the Site: Each mobile home shall be so placed upon a mobile home lot as to secure the superstructure against uplift,
sliding, rotation and overturning, in accordance with the following standards:
1. The mobile home stand shall not heave, shift or settle unevenly under the weight of the mobile home due to frost action, inadequate drainage,
vibration or other forces acting on the structure.
2. The mobile home stand shall be provided with anchors and tie-downs such as cast-in-place concrete "dead men", eyelets imbedded in concrete
foundations or runways, screw augers, arrowhead anchors, or other device securing the stability of the mobile home.
3. Anchors and tie-downs shall be placed at least at each corner of the mobile home stand and each shall be able to sustain a minimum tensile
strength of two thousand eight hundred (2,800) pounds.
3-27-9: FIRE PROTECTION:
No license shall be issued authorizing the operation of a mobile home park which is not located within the corporate limits of the Bartlett and Countryside
Fire Protection District, or other fire protection district which has fire fighting capabilities equal to or greater than the Bartlett and Countryside Fire
Protection District.
A. The licensee shall grant a license to members of all fire departments which respond to emergency calls in the Village to go upon any part of the
licensee's mobile home park for the purpose of fighting and preventing the spread of fire.
B. Fire Extinguishers, Inspections and Report: The licensee shall cause each mobile home to be inspected at least annually to assure compliance with the
requirements of section 9.9 of The Act, incorporated herein by reference, requiring mobile homes to be equipped with fire extinguishers in working
order, one in each end of the mobile home, and shall report the results of such inspection to the Village Clerk annually with the license renewal
application.
3-27-10: POLICE PROTECTION:
The licensee shall grant a license to members of the Bartlett Police Department to go upon any part of the licensee's
mobile home park for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of the Criminal Code of 1961.2
3-27-11: WATER SUPPLY:
Each mobile home park, and each mobile home, shall be served by a water supply which meets the requirements of the IEPA Division of Public Water
Supply. The Village hereby adopts by reference the Illinois Pollution Control Board Rules and Regulations, chapter 6, Public Water Supplies.
A. Copies of each report required to be made by the licensee to IEPA, and all test results and laboratory results required to be filed by the licensee with
IEPA, shall be filed with the Village Clerk at the same time they are required to be filed with IEPA. Copies of all notices and correspondence from IEPA
shall be filed with the Village Clerk within two (2) business days after they are received by the licensee or the custodian.
B. Copies of any of the above materials which indicate that the water supply which serves a mobile home park constitutes an immediate danger to the
health of occupants of such mobile home park shall be delivered to the Village Clerk within one hour after such materials are received by the licensee
or the caretaker.
C. Any mobile home park constructed, developed or expanded after the effective date of this Chapter shall be provided with a water distribution system
which meets the requirements of the Bartlett Subdivision Ordinance. In addition:
1. The diameter of the pipe required shall be proportional to the length of main in accordance with Table I.
Table I
Size of Main Maximum Number of Maximum Length

2. The water distribution system shall be capable of supplying water at a minimum pressure of twenty pounds per square inch (20 psi) during periods of
peak demand and usage.
3. All plumbing shall be installed in accordance with the Illinois State Plumbing Code.
3-27-12: DISPOSAL OF SEWERAGE AND WASTE WATER:
A. All sewerage and waste water from a mobile home park, and from every mobile home, shall be discharged into a sanitary sewer system which is
connected to the waste water treatment facilities of the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago (MSD) if the mobile home or mobile home
park is located in Cook County, or the Village of Bartlett Waste Water Treatment Facility if the mobile home park or mobile home is located in DuPage
County.
B. Sewer connections for each mobile home shall be provided in accordance with section 9.6 of The Act.
C. Any mobile home park constructed, developed or expanded after the effective date of this Chapter shall be provided with a sanitary sewer system which
meets the requirements of the MSD or the Bartlett Subdivision Ordinance, whichever are more stringent, if the mobile home park is located in Cook
County; otherwise, the requirements of the Bartlett Subdivision Ordinance. In addition:
1. Minimum design and slope shall be determined in accordance with Table II.

2. Manholes shall be provided at every change in direction or grade, at the upper end of every main sewer line, at every junction of two (2) or more
branch sewers, and at intervals of not more than four hundred feet (400'). Cleanouts extending to grade may be used instead of manholes on sewer
lines no greater than eight inches (8") in diameter, and shall be at intervals of not more than one hundred feet (100').
3-27-13: DRAINAGE:
A. Adequate drainage shall be provided in accordance with the provisions of section 9.2 of The Act.
B. Mobile home parks constructed, developed or expanded after the effective date of this Chapter shall meet the drainage, detention, retention and storm
sewer construction standards of the Bartlett Subdivision Ordinance.
3-27-14: MINIMUM LOT SIZE, DIMENSIONS, SITING:
Minimum lot size and lot dimensions and the location of a mobile home on an individual zoning lot or site shall be in accordance with the requirements of
Article J of the Bartlett Zoning Ordinance.
No licensee shall cause or permit a mobile home to be placed on a site without first filing with the Village Clerk written notice specifying the lot number and
address of the site on which such mobile home is to be placed.
3-27-15: GARBAGE STORAGE AND DISPOSAL:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 118/702
Provisions for garbage storage and disposal shall be made in accordance with the provisions of section 9.7 of The Act, incorporated herein by reference.
3-27-16: INSECT AND RODENT CONTROL:
Insect and rodent control shall be provided in accordance with section 9.9 of The Act, incorporated herein by reference.
3-27-17: ELECTRICAL DISTRIBUTION:
Any mobile home park constructed, developed or expanded after the effective date of this Chapter shall be provided with an electrical distribution system
which meets the requirements of the Bartlett Subdivision Ordinance and the Bartlett Building Code. Electrical outlets for each individual site shall be
provided and installation shall be in accordance with State Code requirements.
3-27-18: FUEL SUPPLY AND STORAGE:
All handling and storage of natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), fuel oil or other flammable liquid or gases should be installed and maintained in
accordance with applicable State and local government codes and regulations. The Illinois Department of Law Enforcement (Division of Fire Prevention) is
the regulatory State agency for safe fuel storage and handling systems and the applicable regulations are the National Fire Protection Association
Standards, NFPA-31 "Installation of Oil Burning Equipment-1968", NFPA-54 "Installation of Gas Appliances and Gas Piping-1969", and NFPA-58 "Storage
and Handling of Liquefied Petroleum Gases-1969". No LPG or fuel oil container shall be placed in side or beneath any mobile home, storage cabinet,
carport or any other structure. Containers of fuel shall be at least five feet (5') from any mobile home door or exits, and placed on stands constructed of a
noncombustible material.
3-27-19: SERVICE BUILDINGS:
Any service building constructed or altered after the date of this Chapter shall meet the requirements of the Bartlett Building Code.
3-27-20: STREETS:
All streets and driveways in every mobile home park shall be maintained in a passable and reasonably dustproof condition in accordance with section 9.11
of The Act, incorporated herein by reference.
3-27-21: MOBILE HOME PARK MAINTENANCE AND OPERATION REGULATIONS:
A. Caretakers, Duties: Every mobile home park shall comply with the attendant and caretaker requirements of section 9.1 of The Act, incorporated herein
by reference. The caretaker or an assistant caretaker, shall be available to assist police, fire, paramedic and other emergency personnel twenty four
(24) hours a day and a schedule and list of phone numbers of the manager and each assistant manager shall be furnished to the Village Clerk, the
Chief of Police and the Chief of the Bartlett and Countryside Fire Protection District so that immediate communication can be established in case of
emergency.
B. Each licensee shall provide adequate supervision to maintain his, her or its mobile home park in compliance with the Illinois Mobile Home Park Law and
Rules and Regulations for Illinois Mobile Home Parks.
C. Each mobile home park shall be provided with a custodian's office where each mobile home entering such park shall be assigned to a site, given a copy
of the park rules and registered according to any form prescribed by the Department. Such registration shall include the name and address of the
owner and every occupant of such mobile home. The registration records shall be neatly and securely maintained, and no registration records shall be
destroyed until six (6) years have elapsed following the date of registration. The register shall be available at all times for inspection by all law
enforcement officers.
D. Dependent mobile homes shall not be allowed within a mobile home park. (1984 Code)
Chapter 28
COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS
3-28-1: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for a license shall, in addition to the information required in Section 3-1-1, specify the total floor area and be accompanied by a floor plan
showing same.
3-28-2: BUILDING AND PREMISES REGULATIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.

A. Floor area shall be calculated as defined in Section 3-1-2. Total floor area applicable for the determination of the yearly license fee shall include the sum
total of all the floor area in use or reserved for or retained for the use of the commercial establishment or activity, including, but not restricted to,
principal and accessory use floor area, cellars and basements, even though any such floor area may be temporarily or permanently vacant or not in
use. (Ord. 86-19, 3-18-86)
Chapter 29A
MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS
3-29A-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
APPLICANT: Any person or entity seeking a massage establishment business license. If the applicant is a sole proprietorship, the information sought to be
provided shall be for the individual owner; if a partnership, by each general and each limited partner; if a joint venture, by each joint venturer; if a
corporation, by each officer and director, and unless the corporation's stock is publicly traded, by each shareholder owning or holding more than ten
percent (10%) of the outstanding stock in said corporation; if a limited liability company, by each manager and by each member owning or holding more
than a ten percent (10%) membership interest; if an entity is made up of one or more subentities, then the foregoing information shall be provided or for
each subentity. It shall also include the business manager or other person principally in charge of the operation of the business.
CONVICTION: A plea of guilty or nolo contendere, finding of guilty, jury verdict or entry of judgment by sentencing of any crime, including, but not limited
to, convictions, preceding sentences of supervision, conditional discharge or first offender probation under the laws of any jurisdiction of the United States.
EMPLOYEE: Any person over eighteen (18) years of age, employed by or under contract with the owner of a massage establishment, who renders any
service in connection with the operation of a massage business and receives compensation from the operator of the business or its patrons.
LICENSEE: The operator of a massage establishment.
MASSAGE: Any method of pressure on or friction against or stroking, kneading, rubbing, tapping, pounding, vibrating, or stimulating of the external soft
parts of the body with the hands or with the aid of any mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliance, with or without rubbing alcohol, liniments,
antiseptics, oils, powder, creams, lotions, ointments, or other similar preparations used in this practice, under such circumstances that it is reasonably
expected that the person to whom treatment is provided, or some third party on such person's behalf, will pay money or give any other consideration or
gratuity.
MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT: Any establishment having a fixed place of business where any person, corporation, limited liability company, partnership,
limited partnership, joint venture, trust, firm or association that engages in or carries on, or permits to be engaged in or carried on, a business of providing
massages by massage therapists. Massage establishments shall not include bodywork establishments which are defined in and require a separate license
pursuant to chapter 29B of this title.
MASSAGE THERAPIST: Any person who, for any consideration or gratuity whatsoever, engages in the practice of massage, and who holds a massage
therapist license issued by the Illinois department of financial and professional regulation.
OUTCALL MASSAGE SERVICE: Any business, a function of which is to engage in or carry on massages by a massage therapist at a location designated
by the customer or patron rather than at a massage establishment.
PATRON: Any person who is offered or receives a massage under such circumstances that it is reasonably expected that he or she will pay money or any
other consideration for such massage.
SEXUAL OR GENITAL AREA: Genitals, pubic area, anus, or perineum of any person, or the vulva or breasts of a female.
STATE LICENSE: A valid license issued by the Illinois department of financial and professional regulation to a massage therapist pursuant to the Illinois
massage licensing act, 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 57/1 et seq. (Ord. 2015-77, 10-6-2015)
3-29A-2: MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT LICENSE REQUIRED:
A. Massage Establishment License Required: No person or entity shall engage in or carry out the business of massage unless that person or entity has a
valid massage establishment business license issued by the village pursuant to the provisions of this chapter for each and every separate office or
place of business in the village, unless said business is exempt under section 3-29A-19 of this chapter. However, where individuals possessing the
license required in subsection B of this section, perform massage in their own homes, no massage establishment license shall be required for that
home. When a licensee performs massage in his or her own home, in addition to the requirements of this chapter, the requirements of the Bartlett
zoning ordinance pertaining to home occupations shall apply. A person or entity, who or which, prior to the adoption of this chapter, has been issued a
business license in 2015 (with an expiration date of April 30, 2016), to engage in or carry out the business of massage, as a spa, massage therapy or
health club, shall be subject to this chapter, and shall be required to apply for a separate massage establishment license on or before October 31,
2015, but shall not be required to pay an additional massage establishment license fee for the period ending April 30, 2016.
B. State License Required: No person shall engage in massage for compensation, unless the person has a valid state license issued by the Illinois
department of financial and professional regulation pursuant to the massage licensing act, 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 57/1 et seq., or is exempt
therefrom under said act. (Ord. 2015-77, 10-6-2015)
3-29A-3: APPLICATION FOR MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT BUSINESS LICENSE:
Every applicant for a license to maintain, operate, or conduct a massage establishment shall file an application, under oath, with the village of Bartlett upon
a form provided by the village clerk and pay a nonrefundable annual license fee, in the amount set forth in section 3-1-1 of this title. Copies of the massage
establishment business license application shall be forwarded to the building director, the health inspector, and the community development director. Each
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 120/702
such director or inspector, or his or her designee, shall, within thirty (30) days, inspect the premises proposed to be operated as a massage establishment
and upon inspection, each inspector shall file a written report with the village clerk concerning compliance with the applicable regulations. The application,
once accepted, shall also be referred to the police department for investigation. The police department will perform the required criminal record check, if
any. Background investigations of the applicant shall require the submission of fingerprints. The cost of the criminal record check and cost of fingerprint
submissions shall be borne by the applicant. Massage therapists holding a valid state license shall not be required to submit to a criminal background
check if he or she submits a true and accurate copy of his or her state license. Each application shall contain the following information:
A. A definition of service to be provided.
B. The location, mailing address and all telephone numbers where the business is to be conducted.
C. Federal employer identification number (FEIN) and state of Illinois business tax number (IBT).
D. The name and residence address of each applicant (all provisions which refer to applicant include an applicant which may be a person operating as a
sole proprietorship, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, joint venture, or association).
1. If applicant is a corporation, the name, primary residence address, driver's license number, social security number, and fingerprints of each officer,
director and of each stockholder owning more than ten percent (10%) of the stock of the corporation or company, and the address of the corporation
or company itself, if different from the address of the massage establishment. A certificate of good standing from the secretary of state of the state of
its incorporation shall also be submitted.
2. If the applicant is a limited liability company, the name, primary residence address, driver's license number, social security number, and fingerprints
of each manager and of each member that owns greater than a ten percent (10%) membership interest in said company. A certificate of good
standing from the secretary of state of the state of its organization shall also be submitted.
3. If applicant is a partnership, the name, primary residence address, driver's license number, social security number and fingerprints of each partner
including limited partners, and the address of the partnership itself, if different from the address of the massage establishment.
E. The two (2) previous addresses immediately prior to the present address of the applicant.
F. Proof that the applicant is at least eighteen (18) years of age.
G. Individual applicant's height, weight, color of eyes, hair and sex.
H. Copy of driver's license or state identification card.
I. One portrait photograph of the applicant at least one inch by one and one-half inches (1" x 11/2") and a complete set of applicant's fingerprints shall be
taken by the chief of police or his/her agent. If the applicant is a partnership, limited liability company, or corporation, fingerprints of any and all officers,
shareholders, directors, partners, members, managers or agents of the entity (except for massage therapists) along with the fee for each.
J. Business, occupation, or employment of the applicant for the three (3) years immediately preceding the date of application.
K. The massage or similar business license history of the applicant; whether such person, previously operating in this or another municipality, county or
state, has had a business license revoked or suspended, the reason for the revocation or suspension, and the business activity or occupation
subsequent to such action of suspension or revocation.
L. All criminal convictions other than misdemeanor traffic violations, including the dates of convictions, nature of the crimes and place convicted.
Convictions shall mean by plea of guilty or nolo contendere finding of guilty, jury verdict or entry of judgment by sentencing of any crime, including, but
not limited to, convictions or preceding sentences of supervision, conditional discharge or first offender probation under the laws of any jurisdiction of
the United States:
1. That is a felony, or
2. That is a misdemeanor, an essential element of which is dishonesty or that is directly related to the practice of the professions including, without
limitation, the following Illinois offenses, or if found guilty outside the state of Illinois, would constitute the same offense if committed within the state
of Illinois:
a. An offense involving the use of force and violence upon the person of another that amounts to a felony.
b. An offense enumerated in any provision of article 11, entitled "sex offenses", of the Illinois criminal code, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1 et
seq., as amended from time to time.
c. A violation of the Illinois controlled substances act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/100 et seq., as amended from time to time.
d. A violation of the Illinois cannabis control act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq., as amended from time to time.
e. A felony offense enumerated in article 24, deadly weapons, of the Illinois criminal code, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1 et seq., as amended
from time to time, or any other offense that involves the use of weapons.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 121/702
M. The name and address of each massage therapist who is or will be employed in the establishment, including a copy of their respective state licenses as
issued by the Illinois department of financial and professional regulation, and if the business intends to hire any employees or independent contractors
to perform Asian bodywork approaches (see definitions in chapter 29B of this title), or other forms of bodywork (see definitions in chapter 29B of this
title) or modalities that are exempt under section 25 of the massage licensing act1 who are not state licensed massage therapists, a listing of the name,
address, type of bodywork approach or modality that will be practiced for each employee, and for each independent contractor, and if Asian bodywork
approaches or other bodywork approaches will be offered by any person other than a massage therapist or individual exempt under section 3-29A-19
of this chapter, then an Asian bodywork establishment license shall also be required for the business, and each practitioner of an Asian bodywork
approach shall procure an Asian bodywork approach practitioner license as required under chapter 29B of this title.
N. The name and address of any other business owned or operated by any person whose name is required to be given in subsection D of this section.
O. A description of any other business to be operated on the same premises or on adjoining premises owned or controlled by the applicant.
P. Authorization of the village, its agents and employees to seek information and conduct an investigation into the truth of the statements set forth in the
application and the qualifications of the applicant for the license, and to perform criminal background investigations as required by this chapter.
Q. Such other identification and information necessary to discover the truth of the matters required to be set forth in the application.
Applicants, who hold a valid state massage therapist license, are exempt from the fingerprinting and criminal background check requirement, if a copy
of the license is submitted with the application.
Upon the completion of the above provided form and the furnishing of all foregoing information, the village clerk shall accept the application for the
necessary investigations. The holder of a massage establishment license shall notify the village clerk of each change in any of the data required to be
furnished by this section within ten (10) days after such change occurs. (Ord. 2015-77, 10-6-2015)
3-29A-4: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE FOR A MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT:
The village of Bartlett shall issue a license for a massage establishment if all requirements for a massage establishment described in this chapter are met
unless it finds:
A. The correct license fee or other fees or fines owed to the village of Bartlett have not been tendered to the village; or
B. The operation, as proposed by the applicant, if permitted, would not comply with all applicable laws, including, but not limited to, the village's building,
zoning, and health regulations; or
C. The applicant or its employees, other than massage therapists, have been convicted by plea of guilty or nolo contendere, finding of guilty, jury verdict or
entry of judgment by sentencing of any crime, including, but not limited to, convictions or preceding sentences of supervision, conditional discharge or
first offender probation under the laws of any jurisdiction of the United States:
1. That is a felony, or
2. That is a misdemeanor, an essential element of which is dishonesty or that is directly related to the practice of the professions including, without
limitation, the following Illinois offenses, or if found guilty outside the state of Illinois, would constitute the same offense if committed within the state
of Illinois:
a. An offense involving the use of force and violence upon the person of another that amounts to a felony.
b. An offense enumerated in any provision of article 11, entitled "sex offenses", of the Illinois criminal code, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1 et
seq., as amended from time to time.
c. A violation of the Illinois controlled substances act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/100 et seq., as amended from time to time.
d. A violation of the Illinois cannabis control act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq., as amended from time to time.
