https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 529/702
8. Certification by the county clerk that all general real estate taxes have been paid in full. (See section 11-12-1, "Appendix A; Plat Certificates", of this
title.)
9. Certification by the county recorder. (See section 11-12-1, "Appendix A; Plat Certificates", of this title.)
10. Notice that a special service area has been established for the property herein subdivided by the final plat. (See section 11-12-1, "Appendix A; Plat
Certificates", of this title.)
11. Certification that each of the public utility companies have reviewed and approved the location of utilities within the subdivision. (See section 11-12-
1, "Appendix A; Plat Certificates", of this title.)
12. The village of Bartlett public utility easement provisions. (See section 11-12-1, "Appendix A; Plat Certificates", of this title.)
13. Certification that the county public health department has reviewed and approved the subdivision for individual sewage disposal systems (if
applicable). (See section 11-12-1, "Appendix A; Plat Certificates", of this title.)
F. Additional Requirements:
1. Public Improvements Completion Agreement: An agreement in the form set forth in section 11-12-6, "Appendix F; Completion Agreement, Bonds
And Letters Of Credit", of this title requiring the construction and completion of the public improvements for the subdivision and payment of the cost
thereof in full, signed by the owner/developer, shall be submitted with the final subdivision plat.
2. Performance And Payment Bond: Completion of the public improvements for the subdivision, and payment of the cost thereof in full, shall be
guaranteed by the deposit with the village clerk of cash, a completion and payment bond or a letter of credit in the form set forth in section 11-12-6,
"Appendix F; Completion Agreement, Bonds And Letters Of Credit", of this title after the final plat of subdivision has been approved, but before it is
recorded.
3. Surface Water Statement: Certified grading mylar submitted to community development which shall include the village of Bartlett's surface water
statement signed and sealed by an Illinois registered professional engineer and the signature of either the owner of the property or duly authorized
attorney. (See section 11-12-1, "Appendix A; Plat Certificates", of this title.)
4. Site Development Checklist: Completion of all the items on the site development checklist as amended from time to time. (See section 11-12-5,
"Appendix E; Site Development And Early Earthwork Checklists And Hold Harmless Agreement", of this title.)
5. Surveyor's Sealed Letter: The surveyor's sealed letter granting permission to the village clerk to record the final plat. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
Chapter 4
PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENT PROCEDURES
11-4-1: CONCEPT PLAN REVIEW:
Prior to submitting a request for approval of a preliminary PUD plan a petitioner may request a concept plan review from the village technical staff which
may include some or all of the following staff: village administrator, community development director, village planner, building director, public works director,
village engineer and village attorney. Application for the concept plan review shall be made on the approved application form and submitted to the
community development department and accompanied by the appropriate fees.
A. Information To Be Submitted By The Petitioner For The Concept Plan Review: A concept plan drawn to scale and showing lot and block arrangement,
street pattern and location, proposed detention and open space areas, connection to existing village street system and utility needs. It is not intended
that the concept plan be completed as a precisely engineered plan but it must contain sufficient detail to permit a technical and planning review. At this
stage the petitioner should expect the technical staff to identify planning and design issues, and recommend major changes in the concept plan if they
are deemed necessary.
B. Number Of Copies And Submittal Deadline: Five (5) copies of the concept plan shall be submitted to the community development department at least
fourteen (14) days prior to the technical staff meeting at which it is to be reviewed.
C. Review Time And Report: The technical committee will complete their review of the concept plan within thirty (30) days of the applicant's submittal. After
the technical staff has met and reviewed the concept plan, the applicant will be informed of the technical and planning issues identified as well as the
recommended major changes. At this time the applicant may choose to prepare and submit a complete preliminary PUD plat application, revise the
concept plan according to the technical staff's review, resubmit the concept plan and meet with the staff or request to meet with the technical staff to
discuss the items and issues raised by the staff. If the petitioner makes a complete preliminary PUD plan application immediately after their concept
plan review, the technical staff will prepare concept plan review comments that will be included in the subsequent preliminary PUD plan report to the
Bartlett plan commission.
D. Fee: A concept plan review fee and consultant fees to cover the costs of the village attorney and village engineer shall be submitted with the
application. (See section 11-5-7, table 1 of this title.) (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-4-2: PRELIMINARY PUD PLAN:
The procedures for the preparation and filing of a preliminary PUD plan are as follows:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 530/702
A. Application: The applicant shall file with the community development department a completed application form with all required submittals as set forth
on said application form, which may be amended from time to time for approval by the corporate authorities of the proposed preliminary PUD plan with
the number of copies as specified in the application form, and a preliminary engineering report as defined herein, accompanied by the appropriate fees
(see chapter 5, "Fees", of this title) at least forty five (45) days prior to the regular meeting of the corporate authorities at which they are to be
considered for referral to the plan commission.
When the applicant wishes to develop only a portion at a time of the property proposed for a planned unit development, the preliminary PUD plan shall
include the proposed general layout and all information required for the preliminary PUD plan for the entire property ultimately to be developed. The
part which is proposed to be developed (subdivided) first shall be designated unit 1, and subsequent phases designated sequentially on the preliminary
PUD plat in order to illustrate clearly the method and sequence of development which the applicant intends to follow. Each subsequent portion of the
subdivision shall be self-contained and shall follow the preliminary PUD plat.
B. Scale And Size Of Plan: Preliminary PUD plans shall be drawn at the following scales:
Parcels up to 20 acres 1 inch = 50 feet
Parcels 20 to 100 acres 1 inch = 100 feet
Parcels over 100 acres 1 inch = 200 feet
on a sheet at least twenty four inches by thirty six inches (24" x 36"), and not larger than thirty inches by thirty six inches (30" x 36"), and shall include
all of the data required under this section except engineering plans, which may be shown on separate sheets.
In the event that the indicated scale is not conducive to depicting accurately the size and shape of the parcel to be developed while still maintaining a
workable size drawing, the applicant may request a waiver of the scale from the technical staff.
C. Required Information: The preliminary PUD plan shall include the following information:
1. Proposed Name: The proposed name of the PUD.
2. Legal Description: The legal description of land to be developed under the proposed PUD plan.
3. Names And Addresses: The names and addresses of the owner of record of the land proposed to be developed (including all of the beneficiaries of
any land trust which holds title to such land together with a certified copy of the trust agreement and all amendments thereto), the developer and the
designer who prepared the preliminary PUD plan.
4. Dates: The date of the preliminary PUD plan and any revision dates.
5. North Point; Scale: The north point and scale.
6. Existing Conditions: The preliminary PUD plan shall show all the following information and any additional data that is pertinent to existing conditions
which are relevant to the development of the proposed PUD:
a. The boundary lines of the land proposed to be developed indicated by solid heavy lines, and the approximate total acreage encompassed thereby.
b. The locations, widths and names of all existing or prior platted streets or other public ways, railroad and utility rights of way, parks and other public
open spaces, public and private easements, permanent buildings or structures, section lines and village boundary lines, within, and within one
hundred feet (100') adjacent to, the land proposed to be developed.
c. The boundary lines of adjacent tracts of subdivided or unsubdivided land, shown in relation to and within one hundred feet (100') of the parcel
being proposed to be developed, including those areas within one hundred feet (100') of the far right of way lines of adjoining streets and roads.
d. The existing zoning of the land proposed to be developed and adjacent tracts within one hundred feet (100'), including those areas within one
hundred feet (100') of the far right of way line of adjoining streets and roads.
e. Contours at one foot (1') intervals showing streams, rivers, lakes, ponds, swamps, wetlands and other low lying natural detention areas on the
parcel proposed to be developed and within one hundred feet (100') of all of its boundaries.
f. The layout and widths of proposed streets, walkways, bike paths and easements.
g. Such additional technical data as may be required in the preliminary engineering report.
7. Proposed Conditions: (See chapter 6, "Subdivision And PUD Design Standards", of this title.)
a. The layout of buildings (and lots, with lot numbers, if the property is to be divided into lots) with dimensions to the nearest foot.
b. A schedule of the floor areas for each building (and lot areas, if the property is to be divided into lots), and areas of outlots, common areas, and
public use areas.
c. Building setbacks, showing dimensions. (Typical setback diagrams may be used.)
d. Easements to be provided for drainage and any and all public utilities which will not be located within dedicated streets, to the extent that they
reasonably can be expected to be described in the preliminary PUD plan phase. Proper continuity for public utilities within the proposed PUD and
with existing and future adjoining areas shall be maintained.
e. The layout and labeling (i.e., Street A, Street B) of public streets, right of way widths and connections with adjoining existing platted streets and/or
planned streets and roads.
f. The identity of parcels of land, including their acreage, intended to be dedicated, preserved or otherwise set aside for public use and enjoyment or
for the use of the owners of lots in the PUD, including any natural environmental features or significant cultural features which will be retained on
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 531/702
the site such as detention, retention/detention areas, park sites, school sites, bike paths, nature trails, wetlands, and other open space areas. All
such parcels and areas shall be identified by lot or outlot number.
g. Such additional technical data as may be required in the preliminary engineering report.
h. A traffic management study may be required by the community development director.
8. Preliminary Engineering Report: A preliminary engineering report shall be submitted along with the preliminary PUD plan to provide supplemental
engineering data regarding factors that will affect the final design of the PUD. Items to be specifically addressed in the final PUD plan shall be those
items specified in subsection 11-3-2C8 of this title.
D. Public Hearing Notice Requirements: The following shall be completed prior to a public hearing being conducted by the plan commission:
1. The applicant shall prepare and deliver to the community development department a list of all surrounding property owners within two hundred fifty
feet (250') of the subject property as part of the application submittal.
2. The community development staff shall prepare the public notice, submit such notice to the local newspapers for publication and provide the
applicant with a copy of such notice. Such notification shall be in the form required by the Bartlett zoning ordinance, including the name of the owner,
the name of the petitioner, a legal description of the property proposed to be developed, its PIN, street address or other common description, and a
general description of the zoning amendments, variations, special uses and any other zoning relief sought, and a general description of the proposed
PUD, and a list of all nearby property owners required to be notified. See section 10-13-10 of the Bartlett zoning ordinance.
3. The community development department/village clerk shall cause notice of the public hearing on the proposed preliminary PUD plan to be published
not less than fifteen (15), nor more than thirty (30) days prior to the hearing date in a newspaper circulated in the village. All fees for this publication
of the public notice shall be paid by the petitioner at the time of application.
4. The applicant shall notify surrounding property owners as required by the zoning ordinance.
5. The applicant shall post notice of the public hearing on the subject property as required by the zoning ordinance.
E. Preliminary PUD Plan Review And Approval Procedures: The following procedures shall govern the processing of a preliminary PUD plan:
1. Village Board Committee Review: The village board committee of the whole will review the proposed preliminary PUD plan and shall recommend
that the petitioner proceed to the plan commission for a public hearing or that the development requires changes to be made prior to its referral to the
plan commission. This review will take place within forty five (45) days of submittal of a complete application.
2. Plan Commission Hearing: The plan commission shall hold a public hearing at which the owner/developer or their representative shall present and
describe the proposed preliminary PUD plan and members of the public will be given an opportunity to comment thereon.
3. Plan Commission Review: The plan commission shall then review the proposed preliminary PUD plan and all evidence, testimony, exhibits and
written submissions and shall recommend its approval or disapproval within the time specified by the corporate authorities for the review of such
plan, but in no event more than one hundred twenty (120) days from the date of the application or the filing by the applicant of the last item of
required supporting data, whichever date is later, unless such time is extended by mutual consent.
4. Conformance To Plat Act, Thoroughfare Plan And Applicable Ordinances: During the review process the plan commission or the president and board
of trustees may require such changes or revisions as may be required so that the preliminary PUD plan will conform to the plat act, thoroughfare
plan, the subdivision ordinance, zoning ordinance and other applicable ordinances of the village.
5. Village Engineer Review; Preliminary Engineering Report: The village engineer shall review the preliminary engineering report for the proposed PUD
prior to the plan commission reviewing the preliminary PUD plan. During the review process, the village engineer may require such changes or
revisions as may be required so that the engineering design for the public improvements for the PUD will conform to the subdivision ordinance and
other applicable ordinances of the village.
6. Submittal Of Village Engineer Review Comments: The village engineer shall submit review comments to the community development department
and to the corporate authorities as to the adequacy of the water system, stormwater management plan, sanitary sewer system, street system, bike
paths, sidewalks, street lighting, parkway trees and other appurtenant public improvements described in the preliminary engineering report for the
proposed PUD. The village engineer's review comments shall be submitted prior to the review of the preliminary PUD plan by the plan commission.
7. President And Board Of Trustees Approval Or Disapproval: The president and board of trustees, upon receipt of recommendations from the plan
commission, the village engineer, the community development department and the village board committee of the whole will then approve or
disapprove the preliminary PUD plan.
F. Disapproval Of A PUD Preliminary Plan: The PUD shall not be approved if it fails to meet the requirements of this title and the Bartlett comprehensive
plan, the thoroughfare plan, and, if the land is within the corporate limits or the territorial jurisdiction of the village, the Bartlett zoning ordinance.
G. Approval Of A Preliminary PUD Plan:
1. The approval of a preliminary PUD plan by the plan commission and the president and board of trustees indicates only the general acceptability of
the layout of the proposed PUD as submitted.
2. Approval of a preliminary PUD plan shall be effective for a maximum period of one year from the date of adoption of the ordinance approving said
plan. The president and board of trustees may grant an extension upon application for such an extension by the applicant. If the final PUD plan has
not been approved within such time limit, or as it may be extended by the corporate authorities, the preliminary PUD plan must be resubmitted for
review and approval. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-4-3: FINAL PUD PLAN:
The procedures for the preparation, filing, review and approval of a final PUD plan shall be as follows:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 532/702
A. Application: After approval of the preliminary PUD plan by the president and board of trustees and the fulfillment of the requirements of these
regulations, the applicant shall submit its proposed final PUD plan to the community development department with all required submittals as set forth
on said application form which may be amended from time to time, accompanied by the appropriate fees.
1. The original copy of the final PUD plan tracings drawn in ink on such media as accepted by the county or corporate authority in which the PUD plan
must be recorded, supplementary reproducible copies and blue line copies in the quantities specified in the application and the final engineering
plans shall be submitted to the community development department within one year of the date of approval of the preliminary PUD plan. A time
extension may be granted by the corporate authorities, at least forty five (45) days prior to the regular meeting of the corporate authorities at which
the final PUD plan and other such submittals as may be required are to be considered for referral to the plan commission. The final PUD plan shall
be accompanied by a current title commitment showing ownership, liens and encumbrances and protective covenants which meet with the approval
of the village attorney.
2. When the applicant wishes to develop only a portion at a time of the property proposed for planned unit development, the part which is proposed to
be developed first shall be designated as unit 1, and if the subdivision consists of more than one unit, each subsequent phase and all lots shall be
designated sequentially with the unit number preceding the lot number (i.e., unit 1 may contain lots 1-101, 1-102, etc., unit 2 may contain lots 2-400,
2-401, etc.) in order to illustrate clearly the method and sequence of development which the applicant intends to follow. Each subsequent portion of
the PUD shall be self-contained and shall follow the approved preliminary PUD plan and the same procedure until the entire property shown on the
preliminary PUD plan is developed.
B. Required Information: The final PUD plan shall include the following information:
1. The name of the PUD.
2. The legal description of the land proposed to be developed.
3. The names and addresses of the owner of record of the land proposed to be developed (including all of the beneficiaries of any land trust which
holds title to such land) together with a certified copy of the trust agreement and all amendments thereto, the developer, and the designer who has
prepared the final PUD plan.
4. The date of the final PUD plan and any revision dates.
5. Permanent index number (PIN).
6. A scale of one inch to fifty feet (1" = 50'), shown graphically and numerically on a sheet twenty four inches by thirty six inches (24" x 36"), and not
larger than thirty inches by thirty six inches (30" x 36"). If the plan is computer generated, such plan shall be accompanied by a disc in DXF format
containing the subdivision calculations for use in updating the village's mapping system. In the event that the indicated scale is not conducive to
depicting accurately the size and shape of the parcel to be developed while still maintaining a workable size drawing, the applicant may request a
waiver of the scale from the community development department.
7. The north point.
8. Point of beginning and point of commencement if it is utilized in the legal description.
9. The boundaries of the proposed PUD based on an accurate transverse with angular and linear dimensions.
10. The exact location, width and names of all streets within and adjoining the PUD. Proposed street names shall be reviewed by the village clerk's
office, or with the appropriate county official when county roads are involved or when the project falls under the county's jurisdiction.
11. The distances to the nearest established street lines and official monuments which shall be accurately described in the plat. A minimum of two (2)
monuments are required.
12. Township and section lines accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distances and angles.
13. The radii, internal angles, points of curvature, tangent lengths and bearings and lengths of all arcs.
14. All easements for public services, drainage and utilities which do not fall within dedicated rights of way.
15. All lot and boundary lines, with accurate dimensions in feet and hundredths.
16. Accurate outlines and legal descriptions of any areas to be dedicated or reserved for public use, with the purposes indicated thereon and of any
area to be reserved by deed for the common use of all lot owners within the PUD.
17. Building setback lines accurately shown with dimensions.
18. Square footages labeled on each lot or as set forth on a table.
C. Final PUD Plan Review And Approval Procedures:
1. Village Board Committee Review: The village board committee of the whole will review the proposed final PUD plan and shall recommend that the
petitioner proceed to the plan commission or that the development requires changes to be made prior to its referral to the plan commission. This
review will take place within forty five (45) days of submittal of a full application.
2. Plan Commission Review: The plan commission shall then review the proposed final PUD plan and all evidence, testimony, exhibits and written
submissions and shall recommend its approval or disapproval within the time specified by the corporate authorities for the review of such plan, but in
no event more than one hundred twenty (120) days from the date of the application or the filing by the applicant of the last item of required
supporting data, whichever date is later, unless such time is extended by mutual consent.
3. Conformance To Plat Act And Applicable Ordinances: During the review process the plan commission, or the president and board of trustees may
require such changes or revisions as may be required so that the final PUD plan will conform to the plat act and the subdivision, zoning and other
applicable ordinances of the village and substantially comply with the approved preliminary PUD plan.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 533/702
4. Village Engineer Review; Final Engineering Plans: The village engineer shall review the final engineering plans for the proposed PUD prior to the
plan commission's review of the final PUD plan. During the review process, the village engineer may require such changes or revisions as may be
required so that the engineering design for the public improvements for the PUD will conform to the subdivision and other applicable ordinances of
the village.
5. Submittal Of Village Engineer Review Comments: The village engineer shall submit review comments followed by an approval letter once all the
engineering comments have been addressed to the community development department and to the corporate authorities as to adequacy of the
water system, stormwater management plan, sanitary sewer system, street system, sidewalks, bike paths, street lighting, parkway trees and other
appurtenant public improvements described in the final engineering report for the proposed PUD. The village engineer's approval letter shall be
submitted prior to the approval of the final PUD plan by the president and board of trustees.
6. President And Board Of Trustees Approval Or Disapproval: The president and board of trustees, upon receipt of recommendations from the plan
commission and the village engineer, will then approve or disapprove the final PUD plan.
D. Disapproval Of A PUD Final Plan: The final PUD plan shall not be approved if it does not substantially comply with the approved preliminary PUD plan
and if it fails to meet the requirements of this title, the Bartlett comprehensive plan, the thoroughfare plan and, if the land is within the territorial
jurisdiction of the village, the Bartlett zoning ordinance.
E. Certificates: Refer to subsection 11-3-3E, "Certificates", of this title.
F. Additional Requirements:
1. Public Improvements Completion Agreement: An agreement in the form set forth in section 11-12-6, "Appendix F; Completion Agreement, Bonds
And Letters Of Credit", of this title requiring the construction and completion of the public improvements for the PUD and payment of the cost thereof
in full, signed by the owner/developer, shall be submitted with the final PUD plan.
2. Performance And Payment Bond: Completion of the public improvements for the subdivision, and payment of the cost thereof in full, shall be
guaranteed by the deposit with the village clerk of cash, a completion and payment bond or a letter of credit in the form set forth in section 11-12-6,
"Appendix F; Completion Agreement, Bonds And Letters Of Credit", of this title after the final PUD plan has been approved, but before it is recorded.
3. Surface Water Statement: Certified grading mylar submitted to the community development department which shall include the village of Bartlett's
surface water statement sealed by an Illinois registered professional engineer. (See section 11-12-1, "Appendix A; Plat Certificates", of this title.)
4. Site Development Checklist: Completion of all the items on the site development checklist as amended from time to time.
5. Surveyor's Sealed Letter: The surveyor's sealed letter granting permission to the village clerk to record the final plat. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
Chapter 5
FEES
11-5-1: APPLICANT:
An applicant for a subdivision plat or PUD plan approval shall pay to the village fees sufficient to cover the costs reasonably anticipated to be incurred by
the village for the services of its planning, engineering and legal consultants and for the administrative expenses reasonably anticipated to be incurred by
the village in providing the expertise of its own community development, public works, building department, finance and their administrative support
personnel, in connection with the review of concept plats or plans, preliminary subdivision plats and PUD plans and final subdivision plats and PUD plans.
These fees shall also include payment for the review of final detailed engineering plans, specifications and cost estimates, and field observation fees of the
construction and installation of the public improvements for these subdivisions and PUDs. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-5-2: CONCEPT PLAN REVIEW FEES:
An administrative fee for a concept plan review shall be made with each request. The concept plan review fee shall accompany the application and be in
accordance with section 11-5-7, table 1 of this chapter. In addition to the administrative review fees, all village consultant fees incurred by the applicant
during the concept plan review will be billed directly to the applicant and shall be their responsibility to pay prior to the completion of this review phase.
(Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-5-3: PRELIMINARY SUBDIVISION PLAN REVIEW FEES:
An administrative fee for a preliminary subdivision plan review shall accompany the application and be in accordance with section 11-5-7, table 1 of this
chapter. In addition to the administrative review fees, all village consultant fees incurred by the applicant during the preliminary plat review will be billed
directly to the applicant and shall be their responsibility to pay prior to the approval of the preliminary plat. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-5-4: FINAL SUBDIVISION PLAT REVIEW FEES:
An administrative fee for the final subdivision plat review shall accompany the submittal of the application and be in accordance with section 11-5-8, tables
2 through 4 of this chapter. In addition to the administrative review fees, all village consultant fees incurred by the applicant during the final subdivision plan
review will be billed directly to the applicant and shall be their responsibility to pay prior to the approval of the final plat. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-5-5: PUD PLAN REVIEW FEES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 534/702
An administrative fee for the review of a PUD plan shall accompany the application and shall be in accordance with section 11-5-7, table 1 of this chapter.
In addition to the administrative review fees, all village consultant fees incurred by the applicant during the PUD plan review will be billed directly to the
applicant and shall be their responsibility to pay prior to the approval of the PUD plan. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-5-6: CONSULTANT FEES:
The village of Bartlett uses an attorney, an engineer and from time to time a planner as consultants during the concept, preliminary and final subdivision
plan/plat reviews and PUD plan reviews. These consultant fees are based on the time spent by the individual consultant in the review of each phase of the
development. All consultant fees will be billed directly to the developer by the village and shall be paid prior to the completion of each review phase. (Ord.
95-24, 4-4-1995)

11-5-9: ON SITE/OFF SITE IMPROVEMENTS REVIEW FEES:
From time to time a development may require the addition of on site and/or off site improvements. Typically these improvements are for lift stations,
extensions of water and sewer mains or bicycle paths. The review fees for these types of improvements are required to be paid as part of the subdivision
or PUD review process and are in addition to the administrative review fees and consultant review fees.
A. On site review fees shall be paid by the applicant when a determination is made that these improvements are necessary and cause the village
consulting engineer to include this review in the overall review of the subdivision or PUD. The on site review fees will be billed directly to the applicant
by the village and will be the amounts detailed in table 5 of this section.
B. Off site review fees shall be paid by the applicant when a determination is made that these improvements are necessary and cause the village
consulting engineer to include this review in his overall review of the subdivision or PUD. The off site review fees will be billed directly to the applicant
by the village and will be the amounts detailed in table 6 of this section.

Note: Fees For Additional Reviews: Additional plan reviews made after the issuance of the plan approval letter, that are necessary due to field
conditions encountered during construction activities, shall be paid by the applicant at the current hourly rate of the village engineer. In the event
an approved subdivision/PUD is not constructed within twelve (12) months of the issuance of the approval letter, a rereview of the plans at the
current hourly rate of the village engineer will be required at the time the construction activities begin. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-5-10: FIELD OBSERVATION FEES:
Field observation fees in the amounts or percentages of costs hereinafter specified shall be paid to the village to reimburse it for expenses incurred for the
services of its village engineer and its building department in connection with the field observation of the construction and installation of public
improvements and semipublic improvements, and wetland protection and mitigation, during the construction of the public improvements for each
subdivision and PUD. The fees shall be paid at the times designated in the following subsections:
A. Subdivisions: A field observation fee shall be paid to the village on the basis of one and one-half percent (11/2%) of the approved cost estimates for all
"public improvements", defined as follows:
1. All earthwork within the subdivision, including street rights of way, public and private open space, building pads, lots, common areas, undercuts and
all other appurtenant earthwork, demolition, well sealing, and the abandonment of existing facilities included in the subdivision, except excavations
for building foundations.
2. Public sidewalks and/or bike paths.
3. Parkway restoration.
4. Driveway approaches.
5. Street lighting.
6. Stormwater management systems, including storm sewers, swales and drainage ditches and detention/retention areas, including release structures,
underdrains, erosion protection, outfall pipes, seeding, topsoil, sod and paved inverts or other special landscaping treatment ("stormwater
management systems").
7. Sanitary sewer systems, including lift stations and force mains ("sanitary sewer systems").
8. Water distribution systems, including any pumping facilities, supply sources or storage facilities ("water distribution systems").
9. Wetland construction, reconstruction or mitigation.
10. Traffic signals.
11. Water and sanitary sewer services within the rights of way of public streets or easements.
12. All off site water and sanitary sewer services within public streets or easements.
13. All off site improvements required to make the subdivision operational.
B. Planned Unit Developments ("PUDs"): A field observation fee shall be paid to the village of Bartlett on the basis of one and one-half percent (11/2%) of
the approved estimate of cost for the following project improvements:
1. All earthwork within development, including street rights of way, public and private open space, building pads, lots, common areas, undercuts and all
other appurtenant earthwork, demolition, well sealing, and the abandonment of existing facilities included in the development, except excavations for
building foundations.
2. All sidewalks intended to be maintained by the village or an association.
3. All restoration and landscaping intended to be maintained by the village or an association.
4. All driveways and parking areas intended to be maintained by the village or an association.
5. All street lighting intended to be maintained by the village or an association.
6. All stormwater management systems intended to be maintained by the village or an association.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 537/702
7. All sanitary sewer systems intended to be maintained by the village or an association.
8. All water distribution systems.
9. All traffic signals.
10. All water and sanitary sewer services within public streets or easements.
11. All off site water and sanitary sewer services within public streets or easements.
12. All off site improvements required to make the PUD operational.
C. Commercial, Industrial And Office/Research Site Plans: A field observation fee shall be paid to the village on the basis of an estimated fee in
conjunction with the building permit application fee to cover the field inspection of public improvements in commercial, industrial and office/research
projects that are not part of a subdivision or PUD. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
Chapter 6
SUBDIVISION AND PUD DESIGN STANDARDS
11-6-1: GENERALLY; CONFORMITY WITH VILLAGE PLANS AND ORDINANCES:
A. Generally: The plans for every subdivision and PUD within the territorial jurisdiction of the village shall meet the planning design standards herein as
well as the standards for required public improvements set forth in chapter 7 of this title.
B. Conformance Required: The subdivision and planned development of land in the village of Bartlett shall further the goals and objectives of the village as
stated in the comprehensive plan, other plans and policies of the village, and all applicable codes and ordinances, including, but not limited to, the
zoning ordinance, the stormwater, floodplain and wetland ordinance, the stormwater management ordinance, the donation ordinance, and the building
code. In the event that a proposed subdivision is not in conformance with the plans, policies, and ordinances of the village, it shall be so modified that it
conforms. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-6-2: PLATTING:
All lots shall be designed in accordance with good planning practice.
A. Arrangement: Lots shall be laid out in an efficient and uniform manner to avoid the creation of unusable remnants of land.
B. Lot Sizes: Lot width and area shall conform to the regulations of the Bartlett zoning ordinance. Corner lots shall be of sufficient size to provide for
building lines on each street frontage not less than the depth of the required front yard and corner side yard specified in the Bartlett zoning ordinance.
C. Double Frontage Lots: Double frontage lots are not permitted except where lots back upon a collector and/or arterial street, and in such instances,
vehicular access between the lots and the thoroughfare is prohibited. Such lots must have an additional depth of at least ten feet (10') in order to allow
for a protective screening. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-6-3: STREET AND BLOCK LAYOUT:
All streets shall be arranged in accordance with the standards detailed in this section.
A. Lots To Abut On Publicly Dedicated Streets: All lots shall abut on a publicly dedicated street for at least fifty feet (50') (60 feet at the building line) unless
an approved modification is granted by the corporate authorities.
B. Side Lot Lines To Be At Right Angles Or Radial To Street Lines: Side lot lines of lots shall be approximately at right angles or radial to street lines.
C. Streets And Blocks To Be Laid Out Logically: Streets and blocks shall be laid out in a clear, logical manner. Forked streets, streets that double back on
themselves, and streets that change direction shall be avoided. The street pattern and the building numbering system should enable emergency
vehicles to reach a destination quickly and without undue confusion.
D. Measurement Of Irregularly Shaped Lots: The width of irregularly shaped lots shall be measured along a line drawn parallel to the front lot line at a
distance from the front lot line determined by the required front yard setback. In the case of a curved front lot line, the lot width shall be measured as
the length of the arc which is parallel to the front lot line at the building setback.
E. Block Lengths: The maximum length of blocks shall be one thousand two hundred feet (1,200') unless the village board determines that a greater length
is required to avoid or reduce a traffic hazard. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 538/702
11-6-4: VEHICULAR CIRCULATION:
Streets within the proposed subdivision shall be arranged to provide efficient vehicular circulation.
A. Traffic Impact Studies: Every application for subdivision/PUD shall be accompanied by a traffic management study prepared by a qualified traffic
engineer unless deemed unnecessary by the village engineer. (Refer to section 11-12-4, "Appendix D; Traffic Management Ordinance", of this title.) No
subdivision/PUD plat shall be approved if its development will increase traffic to the extent that a lower level of service results, unless the proposal
includes measures to fully mitigate such increased traffic. The maximum amount of traffic that will be permitted in the village shall be that which is
served by level of service C as established by the Institute of Traffic Engineers.
B. Streets And Public Lands: Wherever the comprehensive plan shows a street running through or along any boundary line of the land owned or controlled
by the subdivider/developer, or any land planned for school, park or fire station sites therein, that information shall be shown on the preliminary plat and
any conceptual land use plans for the subdivision or planned development of any part of that land. The precise layout of streets shall be considered in
relation to existing and planned streets, topographical conditions, public convenience and safety, and in relation to the proposed use of the land to be
served by such streets.
C. Continuation Of Existing Streets: All existing streets which terminate at the boundary of the proposed subdivision/PUD shall be continued into the
subdivision/PUD and be incorporated into the street pattern.
D. Continuation Of Streets: If the corporate authorities determine that it is necessary for the public safety to continue a street located within the proposed
subdivision/PUD to a street outside the subdivision/PUD, the village may require the acquisition of right of way which lies on land not owned by the
developer. In that instance the village may take such action as may be required to acquire such off site right of way, and the developer shall pay such
acquisition costs, including legal and other condemnation expenses, as well as the costs of the required off site improvements as a condition of
subdivision/PUD plat approval.
E. Perimeter Streets: When it is determined by the corporate authorities that a street should be located along a boundary line of a proposed
subdivision/PUD to connect with existing or proposed village streets designated on the comprehensive plan, it shall be incumbent upon the developer
either to dedicate the land for such street, obtain dedication of such land by the adjoining owner, or dedicate land for a half street in accordance with
this title. If the developer proposes to dedicate a half street the developer must demonstrate to the corporate authorities that the developer cannot
dedicate sufficient right of way on its property to maintain the alignment with existing or proposed streets, and that it has exhausted all reasonable
efforts to acquire the required right of way from the adjoining landowner. If such off site right of way is within the village, the corporate authorities may
require the developer to agree to pay the cost of acquiring such right of way by condemnation, including legal fees and other expenses, as a condition
precedent to plat approval.
F. Completion Of Minimum Right Of Way Dedication: When any subdivision/PUD, or any part of a subdivision/PUD, is adjacent to only one side of an
existing right of way whose width is less than the minimum width required under this title, the developer shall dedicate such additional right of way as
may be required to meet the minimum width requirements of this title.
G. Offsets: Streets with centerline offset less than one hundred twenty five feet (125') shall be prohibited unless required to conform to the comprehensive
plan, or when they intersect a street with a curbed or barrier median. Eyebrow streets are not considered offset streets.
H. Visibility: Clear visibility at intersections shall be achieved by keeping them clear of foliage or structures within the vision triangle as defined in the
Bartlett zoning ordinance at each corner. Except for traffic control devices, utility poles, fire hydrants and street signs, no structure or plant materials
which will exceed thirty inches (30") in height above the top of curb (or centerline elevation of the street in the event there is no curb) when they mature
shall be permitted within this area in order to provide adequate sight distance.
I. Alleys: Alleys shall not be permitted.
J. Intersection Of Streets: Streets shall be so laid out that they intersect as nearly as possible at right angles. The minimum allowable angle of intersection
of two (2) streets is seventy degrees (70°). Whenever possible, the intersection of more than two (2) streets shall be avoided.
K. Spacing Of Collectors: Collectors carrying traffic in the same direction shall be spaced, whenever possible, at intervals not more than one-fourth (1/4)
mile apart.
L. Cul-De-Sac Lengths: The maximum length of a cul-de-sac shall be six hundred feet (600'). No cul-de-sac shall serve more than twenty (20) lots/dwelling
units. Modifications may be granted by the corporate authorities.
M. Corner Clearance: Entrances to commercial properties shall be located at least fifty feet (50') from intersections to ensure adequate corner clearance
and prevent cars from crossing queues of vehicles at such intersections.
N. Pedestrian Circulation: Sidewalks and/or bike paths shall be required within public rights of way at a distance one foot (1') from the property line, on
both sides of said public right of way.
O. Bicycle Circulation: Bike paths shall be installed in a subdivision/PUD in accordance with the village's bike path plan.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 539/702
P. Access Easements: Access easements may be required at appropriate locations through the center of blocks longer than six hundred feet (600') to
provide safe and convenient pedestrian and bicycle access to schools, parks, or similar destinations when determined to be required for public safety
by the corporate authorities. Access easements shall be a minimum of ten feet (10') wide. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-6-5: STREET DESIGN STANDARDS:
Every subdivision/PUD shall be provided with a system of public streets which meets the engineering design standards set forth in section 11-7-6 of this
title and the following standards:
A. Street Plans: The location and design of the streets and roads, including their arrangement, character, extent and width, for any subdivision or PUD,
shall conform to the village's comprehensive thoroughfare plan in effect at the time of the filing of the application for approval of the preliminary plat or
plan of such subdivision/PUD and shall be considered in relation to existing and planned streets, topographical conditions, public convenience and
safety, and the proposed use of the land to be served by such streets.
B. Minimum Rights Of Way Widths: All rights of way for streets and sidewalks shall conform to the following minimum dimensions:
Arterial streets 100 feet
Bike paths2 15 feet
Collector streets 80 feet
Cul-de-sac streets1 66 feet
Frontage street 50 feet
Industrial service street 55 feet
Local streets 66 feet
Minor street 66 feet
Public sidewalks2 10 feet
Notes:
1. With not less than a 60 foot radius on the bubble of such cul-de-sac. The approach radius to the cul-de-sac shall not be less than 20 feet.
2. Which are not located in a street right of way shall be not less than 10 feet in width.
C. Acceleration/Deceleration Lanes For Commercial Properties: In front of areas zoned or designated for nonresidential use, the street width and the
roadway widths shall be increased on the side or sides on which the property for nonresidential use is located by a merging lane at least fifteen feet
(15') wide and adequate length to ensure the free flow of traffic without interference by vehicles entering or leaving parking areas. This is not to be
considered a part of the required parking area herein elsewhere required. Additional right of way shall be dedicated when acceleration and deceleration
lanes are constructed, so that the street complies with the street width standards of subsection B of this section. It is intended that where the abutting
property on both sides of a street is developed for nonresidential use, there shall be two (2) such lanes in addition to the minimum required street width
if deemed necessary by the village board.
D. Street Names: The name of each street in the subdivision/PUD shall be submitted to the village clerk's office for review and approval on a copy of the
proposed final subdivision plat or PUD plan at least thirty (30) days prior to submittal of the final plat or plan, in order to give the clerk an opportunity to
confer with the police department and the fire protection district and to develop a street numbering system for the subdivision/PUD. No street name
shall be used which duplicates or may be confused with the name of any existing street. Existing street names shall be used wherever possible. All
street names shall be subject to approval by the corporate authorities. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-6-6: PHASED CONSTRUCTION:
When a subdivision/PUD is proposed to be developed in phases over a period of time the corporate authorities may permit the developer to complete the
public improvements for the subdivision/PUD in phases; provided, that the construction of all public improvements shall be completed to each boundary of
the phase of unit proposed to be developed, the plan for phasing is approved in conjunction with the first final plat approval. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-6-7: HEALTH AND SAFETY CONTROLS:
A. Control Of Environmental Pollutants: All proposed subdivisions/PUDs must comply with the Illinois environmental protection act1 and state of Illinois
rules and regulations title 35, subtitle G, "Waste Disposal".
B. Private Sewage Disposal System: The use of septic systems for disposal of sewage shall not be permitted, unless a special exemption is granted by the
village board. Private sewage disposal systems shall meet the requirements of the county health department or other agency having jurisdiction in the
county in which the site is located. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 540/702
Chapter 7
REQUIRED PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS FOR ALL SUBDIVISIONS AND PUDs
11-7-1: STANDARDS:
Every subdivision and PUD within the territorial jurisdiction of the village shall be improved with the following public improvements: a water distribution
system, a sanitary sewer system, a stormwater management system, streets with curbs and gutters, sidewalks, streetlights, and parkway landscaping
("public improvements") and facilities for the distribution of electric, gas, telephone and cable television service ("public utilities"), except as hereinafter
expressly provided. No subdivision or PUD shall be approved by the corporate authorities until the village engineer certifies that the engineering plans and
specifications for the public improvements for such subdivision or PUD meet the minimum requirements specified in the following sections of this title:
Required Public Improvement Section
Site grading
Erosion control
Sanitary sewers and appurtenances
Stormwater management system (chapter 8 of this title)
Water system and appurtenances
Streets
Streetlights
Sidewalks
Bicycle paths
Driveway approaches
Landscaping
Public utilities
Utility and drainage easements
Floodplain protection
Wetland protection
A. Additional Standards: No private streets, water mains, sanitary sewers, or storm sewers will be permitted within any subdivision. Private sidewalks and
streetlights shall not be permitted within the dedicated rights of way or easements for the public street system.
B. Working Drawings And Specifications: Before considering the approval of the final subdivision plat or final PUD plan for any subdivision or PUD, the
plan commission shall require that complete working drawings and specifications for the public improvements and public utilities for such subdivision or
PUD be submitted to the village engineer to determine whether they meet the requirements of this title.
C. Review By Village Engineer: The village engineer shall review such plans and specifications and report his findings to the corporate authorities. Should
revisions be recommended by the village engineer in order for the plans to conform to the requirements of this title, the applicant shall revise their plans
and/or specifications and resubmit them directly to the village engineer for his review and recommendations. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-7-2: SITE GRADING PLAN:
The subdivider/developer shall supply the village with engineering plans and specifications on a site grading plan showing the following:
A. Bench mark elevations,
B. Centerline road elevations at front lot corners,
C. Top of house foundations,
D. Lot corner elevations with drainage arrows showing direction of drainage,
E. Break points at which the drainage changes direction,
F. Drainage structures with frame elevations,
G. Typical footprint of the pad area in which the house or building will be built,
H. Special treatment of embankments,
I. Retaining walls. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-7-3: MINIMUM/MAXIMUM YARD GRADES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 541/702
The minimum and maximum grades for yards within a lot, or at a lot line, shall be as follows: Side lot line grades shall be greater than one percent (1%)
but not greater than ten percent (10%). Front lot line grades (those parallel to the street) shall have minimum and maximum grades equal to the street on
which they front. If the front lot lines parallel a private cluster driveway area, then the minimum and maximum grades shall be "0.6 percent and seven
percent (7%) respectively". Rear lot lines shall have a minimum slope of one percent (1%). If the grade differential between adjoining rear yards cannot be
accommodated, then a retaining wall shall be incorporated into the grading plan.
A. Foundation Elevation Differences: The difference in elevations between adjacent building's top of foundations shall not exceed five percent (5%) of the
horizontal distance of the building separation (e.g., based on a 71/2 foot side yard on each lot the permitted maximum elevation difference between the
adjoining foundation elevations would be 5 percent times 15 feet or 0.75 feet).
1. In the event that the adjoining foundation difference (at the side yards) is more than five percent (5%), based on the horizontal building separation,
special consideration shall be given to the side yard treatment to accommodate drainage. Special consideration may include, but not be limited to,
retaining walls, stepped foundations, dropped siding, special landscaping techniques or greater separation of buildings.
2. Overflow routes designed to accommodate the 100-year intensity flood shall be defined on the grading plan. Where an overflow route is designed to
go between homes, a typical section shall be shown in section view for the overflow route. Design calculations shall be provided on the grading plan
next to each respective section identifying the required capacity of the overflow route.
Depth of flow and the width of flow. Side slopes for such channels shall not be steeper than four foot (4') horizontal to one foot (1') vertical.
The capacity of the overflow route shall be calculated using either broad crested weir or channel formula.
The runoff rate for the 100-year overflow route shall be calculated at the runoff rate for the detention volume or 4.5 cfs/ac whichever is greater.
B. General Drainage Direction: General drainage direction shall be identified as being carried along property lines or at the toe of slopes, all within
appropriate drainage easements.
C. Grading Plan Compliance: Grading plan compliance shall be provided prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-7-4: SANITARY SEWER SYSTEMS:
Except as provided in subsection E of this section, all subdivisions and PUDs shall have a sanitary sewer system connected to the village sanitary sewer
system sized in accordance with the village's master sanitary sewer plan, and designed and constructed in accordance with the following standards:
A. General Requirements For Sanitary Sewers: The sanitary sewer system for each subdivision/PUD shall meet the following general requirements:
1. Sanitary and storm sewer systems shall not be combined, and sanitary sewer systems shall be protected from infiltration of stormwaters.
2. Sanitary sewer service lines shall be constructed with service stubs located at the center of, and extended at least ten feet (10') into, each lot in the
subdivision/PUD.
B. Sanitary Sewer Materials And Testing; Pipe Materials: Any of the following materials may be used for sanitary sewer pipe within the village of Bartlett:
1. Poly (vinyl chloride) pipe ("PVC") in conformity with ASTM D-3034, type PSM for size six inches (6") through twelve inches (12") and ASTM D-3093,
type PSP for size fifteen inches (15") and larger, all having a minimum size dimension rate (SDR) of 26. Laying length shall not be less than twenty
feet (20') unless conditions require a shorter length. Each joint shall consist of a bell that is an integral part of the pipe, stiffened to securely lock a
solid cross sectional rubber ring into position. A "home" mark shall be provided on the spigot end of the pipe. The joint shall be able to withstand an
internal hydrostatic pressure of twenty five (25) psi and any leakage shall be considered a failure of the test and the joint.
2. Reinforced concrete pipe ("RCP") in conformity with ASTM C-76. Lifting holes shall not be permitted. The joint shall be an "O" ring self-centering
type rubber gasket conforming to ASTM C-361. The bell and spigot end of the pipe shall be formed by a steel ring securely welded to the inner
reinforcing and shall be suitable to accepting the rubber gasket. A two (2) coat interior epoxy coating (14 mils) shall be required on all RCP pipes
unless calculations show that the formation of a sulfide condition will not be a problem to the structural integrity of the sewer system. If this is proven,
then the coating can be omitted.
3. Ductile iron pipe ("DIP") in conformity with ANSI/AWWA-C151/A21.51 and ANSI/AWWA-C111/A21.11 with push-on or mechanical joints class 52
pipe. The pipe shall have a cement mortar lining. Ductile iron pipe will be required for sanitary sewers deeper than eighteen feet (18'), locations
where future access may be limited, or as directed by the village engineer. All force mains shall be ductile iron pipe.
C. Manholes: Manholes shall be precast reinforced concrete with monolithic bottoms, manhole steps, and cast iron frames and lids marked "Sanitary".
(Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
D. Testing Sanitary Systems: Air testing, infiltration testing or exfiltration testing, may be utilized as acceptable testing methods to demonstrate the integrity
of the sanitary sewer system. All tests shall be performed with capped sanitary sewer services and manholes in place. Air testing shall be performed in
accordance with the "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer Main Construction In Illinois", as amended from time to time. Infiltration and
exfiltration test results shall not exceed two hundred (200) gallons per inch diameter per day per mile of pipe. All PVC sanitary sewer lines shall also be
tested for deflection (mandrel test) in accordance with the "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer Main Construction In Illinois".
All sanitary sewers shall be closed circuit television inspected prior to acceptance by the village. The sewer shall be thoroughly cleaned prior to
televising. High quality VHS videotape (or other approved medium) and a written report of all television inspections shall be submitted to the village.
The report shall indicate all sags, connections, leaks and defects. All defects and corrective work required as the result of such inspection shall be
performed by the developer. Upon completion thereof, the sewer shall be retelevised and taped by the developer. (Ord. 2004-148, 10-19-2004)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 542/702
E. Exception: For subdivisions outside the corporate limits where no public sanitary sewer system is available within one hundred feet (100') of the
property owned or controlled by the subdivider/developer, the village will consider approving the use of individual sewage disposal systems or septic
systems to serve lots that have an area of one acre (43,560 square feet) or larger, provided: 1) such systems meet the minimum requirements of the
IEPA and the appropriate county health department, 2) a covenant running with the land effectively obligates future owners of lots within the
subdivision: a) to discontinue using such system, b) to connect their residences to the village sanitary sewer system whenever a village sanitary sewer
line is located within one hundred feet (100') of the property on which their residences are located, and c) to extend the village sanitary sewer to the
farthest boundary line of such property within the right of way or easement designated by the village. All test data required by the agency(ies) having
jurisdiction over the subdivision/PUD shall be submitted to the village and to such agency(ies) for review and approval. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
F. Sanitary Sewer Lift Station: Should the lay of the land be such that a sanitary sewer lift station is required, said lift station shall be built at the sole
expense of the developer. The lift station shall be on a separate lot dedicated to the village of Bartlett. The size of the lot shall be a minimum of fifty by
one hundred feet (50 x 100'). Lift stations shall be built to current "Village Of Bartlett Specifications For Sewerage Lift Station", available from the village
engineer. Required improvements shall include, but are not limited to, brick construction control building, generator, controls, pumps, and flowmeter.
A plan for the sanitary sewer lift station site shall be included as part of the preliminary engineering plans. The plan shall at a minimum include:
1. Lot dimensions,
2. Street accessible drives,
3. Proposed grading,
4. Proposed utilities,
5. Location of control/generator building, wet well, valve vaults, flowmeter vault, and other appurtenances,
6. Construction details,
7. Title commitment and plat of survey (at time of final plat). (Ord. 2004-148, 10-19-2004)
11-7-5: WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS:
Except as provided in subsection G of this section all subdivisions and PUDs shall have a water distribution system capable of supplying all of the lots in
the subdivision/PUD with village water, sized in accordance with the village's water main system master plan, and designed and constructed in accordance
with the following standards: (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
A. Water Main Sizing And Looping: Water mains shall not be less than eight inches (8") in diameter, conforming to the village water main system master
plan, available from the village engineer, and shall be so arranged that the entire system is looped. Shutoff valves shall be provided at each branch
main connection and at such additional locations so that: 1) not more than eight hundred feet (800') of water main, or 2) that length of water main which
serves not more than twenty (20) detached single-family residences, whichever is greater, will be shut down for the performance of maintenance work.
(Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995; amd. Ord. 2004-148, 10-19-2004)
B. Water Main Materials: Water main pipes shall be made of ductile cast iron with a cement mortar lining and a working pressure of one hundred fifty (150)
psi. All fittings shall be ductile cast iron with a cement mortar lining and suitable for a working pressure of two hundred fifty (250) psi. Water main lines
and fittings shall be specified by class for the appropriate laying depth but not less than class 52. All material shall comply with the following ASA
specification:
1. ASA A21.51: Ductile cast iron all joint types (centrifugally cast in metal molds or sand lined molds for water or other liquids).
2. ASA A21.4: Cement mortar lining for pipes and fittings.
3. ASA A21.50: Use to determine wall thickness for ductile cast iron underground pipes.
4. ASA A21.1: Determine class thickness for 18/40 strength gray cast iron pipe fittings.
C. Valves: All valves used in the water distribution system shall be Waterous resilient wedge gate valves. Gate valves shall be cast iron body, bronze stem
and stem nut, rubber seated type with nonrising stem and O-ring packing, and conforming to the latest revised requirements of AWWA specification C-
509. The resilient rubber seat shall be bonded to the gate or wedge with the bond proved by requirements of ASTM D-429 testing procedures. All
valves shall be counterclockwise opening and shall be supplied with two inch (2") square operating nuts.
D. Valve Vaults: All valves shall be installed in precast valve vaults sized as follows:
Water Main Diameter Vault Diameter
10 inches or less 4 feet
10 - 12 inches 5 feet
12 inches or more Sized to accommodate valve
All vault frames and closed lids shall be marked "Water".
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 543/702
E. Fire Hydrants: Fire hydrants shall be installed at not more than four hundred foot (400') intervals and so all points of every building in the
subdivision/PUD can be covered by a swing of two hundred fifty foot (250') radius about any given hydrant. All fire hydrants shall have six inch (6")
barrels with two (2) 21/2-inch standard hose connections and one 41/2-inch steamer connection. All hose connections shall have national standard
threads. Each fire hydrant shall have a six foot zero inch (6'0") laying depth, have a breakaway flange and include an auxiliary valve and valve box. Fire
hydrants shall be Waterous Pacer WB67.
F. Water Main Testing: All newly laid water main pipe, or any valved sections of such newly laid pipe, shall be tested as specified herein and shall comply
with the requirements of this title.
Each section of pipe to be tested shall be filled with water to an initial pressure of not less than one hundred fifty (150) psi. Filling of the water main
shall be accomplished by the use of a pump, gauges and water meter (all to be furnished by the contractor) to a pressure in excess of one hundred fifty
(150) psi, all connected in a manner acceptable to the village engineer. Before applying the test, all air shall be expelled from the test section. The test
section shall be allowed to stabilize at one hundred fifty (150) psi before the test commences. The test shall start at one hundred fifty (150) psi and run
for a two (2) hour period. At the end of the two (2) hour period, the system shall be pumped back up to the original pressure (150 psi) and the volume of
water required to restore the original pressure shall be measured. The allowable water loss shall be no greater than ten (10) gallons per inch diameter
per mile of pipe per day, adjusted to the duration of the test in hours or fractions thereof.
G. Exception: For subdivisions outside the corporate limits where no public water supply system is available within one hundred feet (100') of the property
owned or controlled by the subdivider/developer, the village will consider approving the use of private wells when conclusive evidence is presented by
the applicant in the form of suitable tests and surveys that demonstrate that an adequate, underground water supply of potable water is readily
available for the development of lots with private wells, and the applicant has secured the approval of the appropriate county health department. (Ord.
95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-7-6: STREET DESIGN STANDARDS:
Every subdivision/PUD shall be provided with a system of public streets which meets the planning standards of section 11-6-3 of this title and the following
engineering standards:
A. Street Improvement Standards: All materials, workmanship, equipment and testing shall comply with the current state of Illinois "Standard Specifications
For Road And Bridge Construction". Terms used herein shall have the meanings set forth in section 11-2-2 of this title.
B. Minimum/Maximum Street Grades: All street grades shall be in accordance with the limits set forth in table 1 of this subsection.

D. Soils Reports Shall Be Required: A profile of the subsurface soil conditions shall be provided to a distance of ten feet (10') below the proposed grade

strength, ground water data and frost susceptible material. IBR values shall be made available to the village engineer for checking the roadway design.
E. Determining Traffic Volumes: (Also see section 11-12-4, "Appendix D; Traffic Management Ordinance", of this title.)
1. When the subdivider/developer is improving existing streets, current traffic data shall be secured from responsible agencies or field counts shall be
taken.
2. When the ultimate size of the subdivision/PUD will be less than one hundred (100) acres, traffic projections for the structural integrity of the arterial
and collector streets for residential land uses, and all streets in other land uses, shall be determined on the basis of the following standards:
a. For subdivision/PUDs of detached and attached single-family residences, ten (10) trips per day per unit.
b. For commercial, industrial, office/research and institutional uses, traffic projections shall be made by a traffic engineer and submitted to the village
engineer for approval.
The breakdown of traffic by categories of passenger car (PC), single unit (SU) or multiple unit (MU) trucks shall be eighty percent (80%) PC,
nineteen percent (19%) SU and one percent (1%) MU for all residential type land uses. The division of traffic for all other land uses shall be in
accordance with the recommendations of a traffic engineer which have been submitted for review by the village engineer and approved by him.
3. When the ultimate size of the subdivision/PUD will be more than one hundred (100) acres, traffic projections made by a traffic engineer shall be
submitted for review and approval by the village engineer for all street classifications and land uses.
F. Structural Design Of Streets: All subbase, base and surface designs for streets for all land uses shall be done in accordance with the manuals for the
structural design of bituminous and Portland cement concrete pavements then currently being used by IDOT's bureau of local roads.
1. Minimum Thicknesses Of Base And Surface Courses For Bituminous Surface Streets: All surface and base course materials indicated in table 3 of
this subsection will be permitted for the construction of bituminous surfaced streets within the village's territorial jurisdiction. No roadway shall be built
with less than the specified thicknesses, regardless of the number of projected movements or the IBR values of the soil.
