Notes:
1. Standard Reinforcing: Standard reinforcing in 6 inch and 7 inch thick pavements will not be required if transverse contraction joints are spaced
no greater than 20 feet apart. Standard reinforcing will be required in pavements 8 inches or more in thickness.
2. Granular Subbase Material: A granular subbase material shall be required to replace all soils under concrete pavement where the soil IBR is 2
or less. The depth of subbase material shall be as recommended by a professional soils engineer whose report has been submitted to the
village engineer for his review and approved by him.
3. Illinois Bearing Ratio (IBR) Values: No street (rigid or flexible) will be built on an IBR value of 2 or less. All such soil and other suitable material
shall be removed and replaced with acceptable materials or a subbase material as directed by a professional soils engineer whose report has
been submitted to the village engineer for his review and approved by him.
4. Minimum Radii At Returns: Streets shall be constructed with the minimum radii specified in table 5 of this subsection.
TABLE 5
TABLE OF MINIMUM RADII
Type Of Intersection Minimum Radii
Cul-de-sac to minor street 25 foot
Minor street to minor street 25 foot
Cul-de-sac to collector street 30 foot
Minor street to collector street 30 foot
Collector street to collector street 30 foot
Minor street to arterial street 30 foot
Cul-de-sac to arterial street 30 foot
Collector street to arterial street 40 foot
Arterial street to arterial street 40 foot
(Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
G. Concrete Curbs And Gutters: Concrete curbs and gutters shall be required on all streets. The curb shall be depressed at all driveways and intersections
to accommodate handicapped accessible sidewalks. The curb shall be B-6.12 curb and gutter (refer to section 11-12-8, "Appendix H; Standard Details
For Public Improvements", of this title).
H. Excavation And Preparation Of Subgrade: All roadways shall be excavated and the street subgrade prepared in accordance with the most current IDOT
"Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction", current edition. A proof roll test shall be conducted prior to the placement of base
material. Soft and yielding materials encountered in the subgrade shall be removed and replaced with granular material or other fill material compacted
to ninety five percent (95%) of optimum laboratory density. (Ord. 2004-148, 10-19-2004)
I. Materials Inspections: Subgrade compaction and all materials incorporated into the roadway section shall be tested by a competent testing laboratory to
be provided at the subdivider/developer's expense. Tests shall be made in compliance with current state of Illinois recommendations, except that plant
inspections will not be required in concrete or blacktop plants continuously during production. However, one random test shall be made daily on all
material used. Results of all tests conducted shall be forwarded to the village engineer for his review and approval. No acceptance of work will be
recommended without such test results being submitted to the village engineer.
The subdivider/developer shall be required to provide cores on the roadway system prior to the placement of the final surface course in order to verify
binder course and/or base thicknesses. Cores shall be taken at five hundred foot (500') intervals or as directed by the village engineer. In the event that
cores do not meet at least ninety five percent (95%) of the total required thickness of the binder and/or base course, additional thickness of surface
course will have to be placed to compensate for the inadequate thicknesses. The adjustment in thickness will be based on the IDOT local roads
structural numbers assigned to each respective material type for which the adjustment needs to be made.
J. No Building Permits: No permit will be issued for the construction of any building in any subdivision or PUD until curbs and gutters are in place and
street pavements have been partially completed to meet the following standards:
1. Bituminous concrete streets: The base course and first lift of bituminous pavement must be in place.
2. Concrete streets: The concrete pavement must be in place.
K. Cutoff Date For Placing Bituminous Materials: No bituminous concrete base or surface course work shall be placed later than November 15 of any
calendar year without special written permission from the village engineer, which may be given on a week by week basis after November 15.
L. Street Ditch Sections: In the event that the corporate authorities permit the use of a roadway ditch section as part of the roadway cross section, the ditch
section shall conform to the following minimum requirements:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 546/702
1. Minimum shoulder width: Six feet (6').
2. Minimum and maximum side slopes: Six to one (6:1) minimum and four to one (4:1) maximum.
3. Minimum and maximum ditch depth: Minimum depth is 2.0 feet below roadway centerline elevation and maximum depth is 3.0 feet below roadway
centerline elevation.
4. Ditch bottom width: Can vary from zero to 2.0 feet wide at bottom of slope.
5. Ditch bottom slope: Minimum slope is one percent (1%) and maximum slope is five percent (5%).
M. Temporary Street Name Signs: During the construction of the public improvements in a subdivision or PUD the subdivider/developer shall erect
temporary street name signs with lettering at least three inches (3") high and waterproofed to facilitate easy delivery of materials and provide ample
direction for emergency equipment.
N. Permanent Street Sign Fees: Prior to final subdivision plat or PUD plan approval, the subdivider/developer shall pay to the village a fee to cover the
estimated cost of purchasing the street name signs for the subdivision/PUD, plus eighty percent (80%) of such cost to cover the estimated cost of the
village installing the street name signs. The village will use these funds to purchase and install street name signs upon completion of street and
underground improvements. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-7-7: STREETLIGHTS:
Streetlights shall be provided in all subdivisions and PUDs in accordance with the following standards:
Streetlights shall be provided on all streets. On arterial and collector streets, the lights shall be located at all intersections and at mid block locations. On
local streets, streetlights shall be installed: a) at all intersections, b) on all street curves unless the radius is such that, in the opinion of the village engineer,
a streetlight is not needed for safety, and c) at the ends of all cul-de-sac streets.
A. Streetlight Placement: Streetlight standards shall be mounted on a base three feet six inches (3'6") behind the curb, except where the distance between
curb and sidewalks prohibits this location, or three feet six inches (3'6") back of shoulder when no curb and gutter exists.
B. System Type: The following street lighting systems will be acceptable:
1. A central control system with circuits from one control panel connected to each light by means of buried electrical conductors, type RR six hundred
(600) volt insulation direct burial. No conductor shall be smaller than #6 ASG copper with a voltage drop from the control center to the farthest light
not to exceed five percent (5%). All voltage on the system shall be two hundred forty (240) volt.
2. Each light can be connected individually to a Commonwealth Edison riser or transformer and turned on and off by means of a photocell. The wire
from the light standard to the Commonwealth Edison riser shall be two - one conductor #6 copper direct burial cable for power and one - one
conductor #6 copper bare stranded for ground.
C. Streetlight Intensities: Streetlight intensities shall be in accordance with the minimum illuminated standards as follows (foot-candles):
MINIMUM ILLUMINATION INTENSITIES
(MEASURED AT STANDARD LOCATION ON PAVEMENT SURFACE)
Location Arterial Street Collector Street Local Streets
Residential 0.4 0.2 0.2
Institutional, commercial and office/research 1.2 0.4 0.4
Industrial 0.6 0.4 0.2
D. Streetlight Mounting Heights:
Location Arterial Street Collector Street Local Streets
Residential 25 feet 25 feet 15 feet
Institutional, commercial and office/research 25 feet 25 feet 25 feet
Industrial 25 feet 25 feet 25 feet
E. Streetlight Standards: Streetlight standards shall be round aluminum poles, Hapco Co. series 77 or equal with flange base for fifteen foot (15') top
mounting height and series 30 with flange base and a minimum eight foot (8') truss style arm with a twenty five foot (25') mounting plate, pedestal or
transformer base and tempered to a T-6 temper. A five-eighths inch by ten foot (5/8" x 10') ground rod shall be installed at each standard location and
connected to the pole with a #8 standard copper wire.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 547/702
F. Luminaires: Luminaires shall be General Electric as shown in section 11-12-8, standard detail nos. 38 through 41 of this title. All luminaires shall provide
high output white mercury vapor and provide IES type III distribution. Luminaires installed at intersections shall be type II four-way refractors.
Luminaires shall be made of heat resistant borosilicate glass.
G. Ballasts And Lamps: Ballasts and lamps shall be so designed as to operate an individual sixty (60) cycle mercury vapor lamp on a multiple circuit with a
minimum voltage and electrical characteristics as follows:
Regulation type, one hundred seventy five (175) watt, two hundred forty (240) volt, ninety seven percent (97%) PF, plus or minus thirteen percent
(±13%) allowable primary voltage variations, with twenty degree Fahrenheit (20°F) starting temperature on collector, minor and cul-de-sac streets. On
arterial streets, an eight hundred (800) watt unit shall be used with all remaining requirements as listed above.
H. Decorative Streetlighting (Downtown Style): Refer to section 11-12-8, "Appendix H; Standard Details For Public Improvements", of this title for
manufacturer information.
I. Conductors: Conductors shall be buried a minimum of thirty six inches (36") below grade and two feet zero inches (2'0") back of curb (or 2 feet 0 inches
off edge of shoulder). Where conductors cross under existing streets or private drives, they shall run in PVC schedule 40 conduit not smaller than two
inch (2") internal diameter and extend a minimum of four feet (4') on each side of all streets and driveways.
J. Streetlight Bases: All standards shall have a bolt down base extending a minimum of five feet (5') deep and shall include a two inch (2") piece of conduit
with a typical radius. Where soil conditions require, the dimension of the base shall be changed. These conditions shall be determined by the village
engineer. Bases shall be twenty four inches (24") in diameter or as approved by the village engineer. Concrete shall be a six (6) bag mix and shall be a
cast in place. The bases shall contain four (4) #4 vertical reinforcing rods and #3 reinforcing rings at twelve inches (12") on center. The length shall be
determined by manufacturer's specifications. Standards shall be mounted plumb. The base of the standards shall be set two inches (2") above the
finished adjoining grade, top of curb or edge of shoulder, whichever is highest.
K. Service And Control Center: Service centers, if used, shall be established at such points as are found feasible for the area to be serviced. The final
selection of a service and control center shall be approved by the village engineer and the Commonwealth Edison Co. At each service center, the
service switch and circuit breaker shall be mounted in a weatherproof cabinet made of rust resistant metal or aluminum and shall be marked "Street
Lighting". This cabinet shall be equal to a Crouse Hinds #27394 adapter.
1. The cabinet shall be mounted on an eighteen inch (18") diameter concrete base four feet zero inches (4'0") deep cast in place consisting of four (4)
vertical rods and #3 rings twelve inches (12") on center for reinforcing. The top of the base shall be two and one-half inches (21/2") (.1/2") above the
finished adjoining grade, the top of curb, or edge of shoulder, whichever is highest. The base shall include a two inch (2") feeder conduit with
standard radius and one and one-half inch (11/2") service conduit connected directly to the meter socket as required by Commonwealth Edison Co.
All feeder and supply conduit shall enter the cabinet from the bottom.
2. The service center distribution cabinet shall be securely grounded by driving into the ground a three-fourths inch by ten foot (3/4" x 10') copper weld
ground rod inside the concrete base of a cabinet and connected to control panel ground terminal. On the back of the control center shall be mounted
the meter socket for the mounting of the service meter. The control center cabinet shall be provided with a secure locking facility and duplicate keys
must be provided for same.
L. Operation Of Lights: Streetlights shall be so controlled by a photocell (mounted on the top of the luminaire on the pole nearest to the service center
when a control center is used) as to turn on at dusk and off at dawn. The wires connecting the photocell to the control which it is to operate shall be a
minimum of #10 THW. Any part of such control wires that runs underground must be suitable for direct burial and connections shall be made with split
bolt connectors in the base of the lighting standard where it connects with the wire from the photocell. A diagram of the control cabinet components
shall be submitted to the village engineer for his approval prior to assembly. The magnetic contactor shall be GE CR 105 or approved equal of one
hundred (100) amperes' minimum capacity. This contactor shall be controlled by the photocell. A manual switch shall be provided to permit testing of
the components or allow automatic operation. It shall be marked "Manual-Off-Automatic". Each service center shall have a duplex one hundred twenty
(120) volt receptacle, Aubbell #5242, or approved equal, mounted on the inside of the cabinet.
If a control center is not used, then a photocell shall be mounted on the top of each luminaire turning the light on at dusk and off at dawn.
M. Electrical Service: Electrical service to the controller for the street lighting system shall be run in a trench three feet (3') deep from the Commonwealth
Edison service source to the service center. The service load shall determine the size of the service wires. Service wires shall be six hundred (600) volt
THW type and shall be pulled in a minimum one and one-half inch (11/2") hot dipped rigid conduit which shall have a continuous run from the service
cabinet to the Commonwealth Edison service source. The minimum size service wires that can be used shall be #3 copper conductors.
In cases where streetlights are independently connected to a Commonwealth Edison service source, the connecting wire shall be no smaller than #8
AWG copper, direct burial with a six hundred (600) volt insulation from the light standard to the Commonwealth Edison service source. The conductor
shall be buried a minimum of three feet (3') deep.
A five foot (5') easement granted to the village shall be provided on each side of a common lot line where such conductors are to be buried.
N. Junction Boxes: Where indicated, an underground junction box, to accommodate two (2) or more feeder lines for the lighting circuits, shall be of ample
dimensions to accommodate the cables and their wires without undue crowding. Junction boxes shall be concrete, twenty four inch by twenty four inch
by eighteen inch (24" x 24" x 18") with frame and cover. The concrete used shall be of the same mix as that used for the standard bases. The conduits
protecting the cables shall be brought into the box from the bottom. A manufactured elbow shall be used at the bottom of the trench and a nipple shall
connect the box with the elbow. Sealtight shall be used to seal off the cables in the box.
O. Testing: All underground feeders shall be tested for grounds and shorts before being connected to the ballast or pole feed. A megger shall be used for
these tests, imposing a voltage on the cable under test not in excess of the voltage for which the cable was designed as tested by the underwriter's
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 548/702
label. Maximum leakage to ground of cable under test is dependent on lengths of cable and shall conform to IES standards for street lighting cable
buried underground. All testing shall be done in the presence of the public works director or his duly appointed representative. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-7-8: SIDEWALKS:
Sidewalks shall be required in all public rights of way and in other locations as determined by the village. Sidewalks shall extend through all driveways.
(Ord. 2004-148, 10-19-2004)
A. Standards: Standards for sidewalks are as follows:
1. Materials: All sidewalks in public rights of way or easements dedicated to the village shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete (6 bag mix)
conforming to section 424 of the "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction". (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
2. Width; Thickness: Sidewalks shall be a minimum of five feet (5') in width, a minimum of five inches (5") in thickness, and shall be placed on a
minimum four inch (4") thick layer of crushed stone (IDOT, CA-6 gradation). (Ord. 2004-148, 10-19-2004)
B. Waiver Of Sidewalk Requirements: The president and board of trustees may waive the requirements for public sidewalks for subdivisions or PUDs with
residential lots one acre or more in area, or wooded areas, or where a bicycle path is provided in lieu of a sidewalk along certain public rights of way.
C. Handicapped Accessible Sidewalks: All sidewalks shall be provided with ramps from streets to sidewalks at all intersections to accommodate the
handicapped. Slopes for such ramps shall not exceed five percent (5%). The surface of the sidewalk ramp shall have a diamond pattern texture finish.
D. Sidewalk Transverse Slope: All sidewalk sections shall be sloped from the property line side of the walk to the street side of the walk at one-fourth inch
(1/4") per foot. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-7-9: BICYCLE PATHS:
Bicycle paths shall be required within or adjacent to a subdivision or PUD where a bicycle path shown on the village's bike path plan runs through all or
part of, or adjacent to, such subdivision or PUD. Bicycle paths may be installed in lieu of sidewalks with the permission of the corporate authorities.
A. Standards for bicycle paths shall be as follows:
1. Materials: All bicycle paths shall be constructed of a crushed gravel base course (CA-6) and a bituminous surface course (class I, type 3) conforming
to the requirements of the state of Illinois "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction". The excavation shall be lined with
geotechnical fabric prior to the installation of the aggregate base course.
2. Width; Thickness: Bicycle paths shall have a minimum width of ten feet (10'), a minimum base course thickness of eight inches (8") and a minimum
surface course thickness of three inches (3"). (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-7-10: DRIVEWAY APPROACHES:
A paved driveway approach will be required between the curb and sidewalk (or between the curb [or edge of pavement where there is no curb] and
property line where sidewalks are waived) for each lot before a certificate of occupancy is issued. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
A. Minimum Driveway Approach Widths:
1. The required width of driveway approaches for residential lots shall be determined per the Bartlett building code.
2. The required width of the driveway approach for nonresidential uses shall be determined per the approved site plan.
B. Materials: All driveway approaches for residential uses shall be standard reinforced PC concrete, conforming to the Bartlett building code. All driveway
approaches for nonresidential uses shall be constructed of six inch (6") standard reinforced PC concrete.
Placement of the material shall be in accordance with the current IDOT "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction". (Ord. 2004-148,
10-19-2004)
C. Slope Of Drive Approaches: All drive approaches shall have a minimum slope of one percent (1%) and a maximum slope of eight percent (8%) with
drainage from the property line to the street. Slope from the street to the property line will be permitted only if it can be demonstrated that stormwater
runoff can be intercepted within the rights of way and carried by the street or storm sewer system. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
D. Depressed Curb: A depressed curb shall be provided at all driveways either by forming during construction of the curb, cutting, or full depth removal
and replacement. Cutting shall be performed with a "Kotkurb" or similar curb cutting machine. Removal and replacement of the curb shall be prohibited
after the final pavement surface has been installed. The limits of the depressed curb section shall be equal to the width of the apron at the back of curb.
The profile of the cut curb shall conform to village of Bartlett standard details. (Ord. 2004-148, 10-19-2004)
11-7-11: LANDSCAPING:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 549/702
All parkways within dedicated street rights of way and all other public use areas shall be graded with six inches (6") of black topsoil and seeded or sodded
in accordance with the specifications set forth in section 11-12-8, "Appendix H; Standard Details For Public Improvements", of this title. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-
1995)
A. Parkway Trees: Parkway trees shall have a minimum trunk diameter (measured 12 inches above the grade) of not less than two and one-half inches
(21/2") and shall be planted in all parkways by the subdivider/developer throughout the entire subdivision or PUD and along existing rights of way
abutting the proposed development if trees are missing. Parkways trees shall be spaced not less than forty feet (40') nor more than sixty feet (60')
apart. Parkway trees shall be centered within parkways between the curb and sidewalk or bike path. No parkway trees shall be planted within fifty feet
(50') of the intersection, measured from the lot corner of the two (2) intersecting lot lines adjacent to the public rights of way. Reasonable effort shall be
made to keep parkway trees from obstructing the view of cross traffic at intersections, and from interfering with upright utilities, such as fire hydrants
and streetlights. Tree planting locations are to be staked for review and approval by the village arborist prior to planting.
B. Acceptable Varieties: Acceptable varieties of parkway trees are identified in the "Bartlett Tree List", available from the public works department. Tree
varieties are to be mixed on an approximately equal basis throughout the subdivision, with no more than twenty percent (20%) of any one genus or ten
percent (10%) of any one species. Columnar or pyramidal species of each variety should be used in narrow parkways six feet (6') wide or less. No
more than four (4) trees of any one variety shall be planted in a row. A parkway tree planting list shall be submitted to the village for approval prior to
planting parkway trees. Any questions about the suitability of any trees for parkway planting should be directed to the village of Bartlett arborist. (Ord.
2004-148, 10-19-2004)
11-7-12: UNDERGROUND PUBLIC UTILITIES:
All subdivisions and PUDs shall be provided with a complete system of public utilities including telephone, electric, gas service and cable television. All
such utility lines shall be placed underground in rear lot line easements with minimal utility installation in public rights of way and side yard areas. When
cables or conduits are placed within easements or public rights of way, they shall be so placed that they will not conflict with the village's public
improvements. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-7-13: EASEMENTS FOR DRAINAGE AND PUBLIC UTILITIES:
Easements for drainage and public utilities shall be provided on all side and rear lot lines.
A. Such easements shall be not less than five feet (5') wide on each side of common side and rear lot lines, or ten feet (10') wide in cases when a five foot
(5') easement cannot be acquired from the adjoining property or properties. If it is determined by the corporate authorities on the basis of the village
engineer's recommendation that additional easements or wider easements are required, the developer shall provide such wider easements.
1. In cases where rear or side lot lines abut an existing subdivision/PUD an easement of sufficient width shall be provided to create an easement ten
feet (10') wide.
2. Easements on newly subdivided lots shall, whenever possible, be aligned and continuous with easements on adjoining lots.
3. No obstruction shall be placed in an easement that would prohibit or alter the natural flow of stormwater through the drainage easement.
4. No structures except fences shall be permitted within a drainage or public utility easement.
5. On days of extensive rain events stormwater may be present in drainage easements up to forty eight (48) hours.
6. Impermeable surfaces shall not be placed on drainage easements.
7. When cables or conduits are placed within easements or public right of way they shall be so placed that they will not interfere with the village's
sanitary and storm sewer and water lines and their appurtenant structures.
8. All transformer boxes, junction boxes, and risers shall be so located as not to be unsightly or hazardous to the public.
9. Residential development adjacent to utility communications equipment shall be discouraged, and in no case shall any part of any residential
structure be located within twenty feet (20') of a communications tower. Utility easements in which communications towers are located shall not be
used for recreational purposes. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
Chapter 8
STORMWATER MANAGEMENT
11-8-1: STORMWATER MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS, EROSION CONTROL, WETLAND PROTECTION, FLOODPLAIN
PROTECTION AND PROTECTION OF RIPARIAN ENVIRONMENTS:
Every subdivision, planned unit development ("PUD"), planned development ("PD") and/or development within the corporate limits of the village of Bartlett,
and any subdivision, PUD, PD and/or development located within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits of the village of Bartlett in
unincorporated areas of DuPage, Cook and Kane Counties, Illinois, shall be provided with a stormwater management system, erosion control, wetland
protection, floodplain protection and protection of riparian environments in accordance with the standards and requirements set forth in the DuPage
County countywide stormwater and flood plain ordinance adopted by the DuPage County board on September 24, 1991, revised June 14, 1994, April 23,
1996, November 12, 1997, June 22, 1999, June 13, 2000, March 25, 2003, January 27, 2004, June 8, 2004, March 8, 2005, February 28, 2006, March 25,
2008, April 24, 2012, with revisions effective April 25, 2012, and general certifications for chapter 15 of the DuPage County code, DuPage County
countywide stormwater and flood plain ordinance adopted by the DuPage County board on April 24, 2012, and effective April 25, 2012, and last revision
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 550/702
dated April 23, 2013, with revisions effective April 23, 2013 (the "DuPage County regulations"), whether or not such subdivision, PUD, PD or development
is located in DuPage County, and the DuPage County regulations are hereby expressly made applicable to subdivisions, PUDs, PDs and developments
within the corporate limits of the village located in DuPage, Cook and/or Kane Counties, and to unincorporated areas in DuPage, Cook and/or Kane
Counties that are within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits of the village of Bartlett, and/or to properties that are otherwise within the
extraterritorial jurisdiction of the village of Bartlett that are not located within the corporate limits of any other municipality and/or which may be annexed to
the village of Bartlett. The DuPage County regulations as so enacted, and as they may be amended from time to time, are expressly made part of the
Bartlett municipal code by this reference just as if they were fully set forth herein. Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary of this title or title 9 of the
Bartlett municipal code, or in the DuPage County regulations aforesaid, floodplains within the village and within its extraterritorial jurisdiction shall be as
delineated in the updated floodplain insurance studies ("FISs") and the flood insurance rating maps ("FIRMs") as prepared and approved by the
department of homeland security federal emergency management agency ("FEMA"). Exhibit 2 to the DuPage County regulations is amended and
supplemented to add the following current FEMA floodplain insurance studies ("FISs") and flood insurance ratings maps ("FIRMs") and profiles:

The foregoing FIS and FIRM panels shall be used for insurance purposes in DuPage County as the village of Bartlett is a multicounty community, however,
for development in regulatory floodplains as depicted on regulatory flood maps and DuPage County's latest D-FIRM in effect for regulatory purposes, the
date of the DuPage FIS and DuPage panels shall be December 16, 2004.
D. The foregoing FISs and FIRMs are hereby approved, but shall automatically be amended from time to time to incorporate updated FISs and FIRMs as
approved by FEMA from time to time.
E. The base flood or 100-year flood frequency elevations for the SFHAs of Poplar Creek, Brewster Creek, Country Creek, the west branch of DuPage
River and all tributaries to the referenced rivers, creeks and streams shall be delineated on the 100-year flood profiles in the countywide FISs prepared
by FEMA for Cook County dated August 19, 2008, for Kane County dated August 3, 2009, and for DuPage County dated December 15, 1980, for
insurance purposes, and December 16, 2004, for regulatory purposes, in effect as of the date of the adoption hereof, and such amendments to such
FISs and FIRMs as may be prepared and approved by FEMA for each of said counties from time to time.
F. The general certifications for chapter 15 of the DuPage County code, DuPage County countywide stormwater and flood plain ordinance enacted by the
DuPage County board on April 24, 2012, as its ordinance OSM-002-12, effective April 25, 2012, expressly incorporated herein by reference are titled
and numbered as follows:
1. Construction of accessory structures in a flood plain (GC no. 1),
2. Construction of boardwalks (GC no. 2),
3. Construction of boat lifts and piers in a flood plain, buffer and/or wetland (GC no. 3),
4. Construction of a deck in a flood plain or buffer (GC no. 4),
5. Demolition of structures in a flood plain, buffer, and/or wetland (GC no. 5),
6. Construction of posts, fencing, and guard rails in a flood plain or buffer (GC no. 6),
7. Construction of recreational facilities not located in a wetland (GC no. 7),
8. Construction of sidewalks, trails, patios and driveways outside of wetlands (GC no. 8),
9. Construction of storm sewer outfalls and outlet channels located in a floodway, flood plain, buffer, and/or wetland (GC no. 9),
10. Construction of shoreline or stream bank stabilization measures (GC no. 10),
11. Construction of topsoil and sand restoration in a flood plain, floodway or buffer, but not within a wetland (GC no. 11),
12. Construction of utilities (GC no. 12),
are hereby approved and made a part of the DuPage County regulations, as amended by the 2013 revisions approved by DuPage County ordinance
OSM-001-13, and are hereby made applicable to every subdivision, PUD, PD and proposed or actual development located within the corporate limits
of the village of Bartlett, or which is located within one and one-half (11/2) miles of its corporate limits that is not within the corporate limits of another
municipality, and/or which impacts or which will impact waters of DuPage, waters of Cook, or waters of Kane, located within the corporate limits of
the village of Bartlett. (Ord. 2013-59, 7-23-2013)
11-8-1-1: DUPAGE COUNTY REGULATIONS AMENDMENTS:
The following sections of the DuPage County regulations are amended to clarify and supplement said regulations as follows:
A. Appendix A of the DuPage regulations entitled "Acronyms, Initialisms And Definitions" is amended to add the following definitions:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 552/702
Department: The DuPage County department of economic development and planning, except for properties in Cook County that are not within the
DuPage County watershed planning areas, "department" shall mean the metropolitan water reclamation district of Greater Chicago ("MWRD"), and
for properties in Kane County that are not within the DuPage watershed planning areas, "department" shall mean the Kane County water resources
division.
Flood Profile: Graphical representations of the elevations of the water surface of the 10-year, 50-year, 100-year and 500-year rain fall event along
the water course.
Freeboard: An increment of elevation added to the base flood elevation to provide a factor of safety for uncertainties in calculations, unknown
localized conditions, wave action, and unpredictable effects such as may be caused by ice or debris jams.
Jurisdictional Wetlands: Wetlands substantially connected to navigable waters and/or waters of the United States as defined in the regulations
promulgated under the clean water act ("CWA") and case law interpreting the jurisdiction of the USACE over wetlands and determined in accordance
with the USACE's most recent Wetland Delineation Manual.
Waters Of Cook: Waters of the United States as defined in federal regulations promulgated under the clean water act ("CWA") that are located in
Cook County and which are not defined as waters of DuPage, including:
a. All waters such as lakes, rivers, streams (including intermittent streams), mudflats, wetlands, sloughs, wet meadows, or natural ponds.
b. All impoundments of waters not otherwise defined as waters of Cook under the definitions.
c. Tributaries of waters identified above.
d. Jurisdictional wetlands adjacent to waters identified above.
For clarification, water treatment systems, including treatment ponds or lagoons designed to meet the requirements of the CWA (other than cooling
ponds as defined in 40 CFR 123.11(m) which also meet the criteria of this definition) are not waters of Cook. It should also be noted that the following
waters are generally not considered to be waters of Cook. However, the administrator reserves the right on a case-by-case basis to determine that a
particular water body located within Cook County within these categories of waters is a water of Cook.
a. Drainage and irrigation ditches excavated on dry land.
b. Artificially irrigated areas that would revert to upland if the irrigation ceased.
c. Artificial lakes, ponds or wetlands created by excavating and/or diking dry land to collect and retain water and which are used exclusively for
such purposes as stormwater storage, stock watering, irrigation, settling basins or sediment traps.
d. Artificial bodies of water created by excavating and/or diking dry land to retain water for primarily aesthetic reasons.
e. Waterfilled depressions created in dry land incidental to construction activity and pits or quarries excavated in dry land for the purpose of
obtaining fill, stone, aggregate, sand or gravel unless and until the construction or excavation operation is abandoned for a period of five (5) years
or more and the resulting body of water located in Cook County meets the definition of waters of Cook.
Waters Of Kane: Waters of the United States as defined in federal regulations promulgated under the CWA that are located in Kane County and
which are not defined as waters of DuPage, including:
a. All waters such as lakes, rivers, streams (including intermittent streams), mudflats, wetlands, sloughs, wet meadows, or natural ponds.
b. All impoundments of waters not otherwise defined as waters of Kane under the definitions.
c. Tributaries of waters identified above.
d. Jurisdictional wetlands adjacent to waters identified above.
The presence of farmed wetlands shall be determined by the national resources conservation service (the "NRCS") of the U.S. department of
agriculture.
For clarification, water treatment systems, including treatment ponds or lagoons designed to meet the requirements of the CWA (other than cooling
ponds as defined in 40 CFR 123.11(m) which also meet the criteria of this definition) are not waters of Kane. It should also be noted that the following
waters are generally not considered to be waters of Kane. However, the administrator in a partial waiver community reserves the right on a case-bycase
basis to determine that a particular water body located in Kane County within these categories of waters is a water of Kane.
a. Drainage and irrigation ditches excavated on dry land.
b. Artificially irrigated areas that would revert to upland if the irrigation ceased.
c. Artificial lakes, ponds or wetlands created by excavating and/or diking dry land to collect and retain water and which are used exclusively for
such purposes as stormwater storage, stock watering, irrigation, settling basins or sediment traps.
d. Artificial bodies of water created by excavating and/or diking dry land to retain water for primarily aesthetic reasons.
e. Waterfilled depressions created in dry land incidental to construction activity and pits or quarries excavated in dry land for the purpose of
obtaining fill, stone, aggregate, sand or gravel unless and until the construction or excavation operation is abandoned for a period of five (5) years
or more and the resulting body of water located in Kane County meets the definition of waters of Kane.

11-8-4: SPECIAL MANAGEMENT AREAS:
Applications for stormwater management permits for development in any special management area shall be submitted to the "director" (at DuPage
County) for review and certification of compliance with the provisions of the DuPage County regulations. After the director certifies the application for
development in such special management area, the village of Bartlett may issue the stormwater management permit if the application meets the more
stringent of the requirements of the DuPage County regulations or this title, as applicable. Development of special management areas outside DuPage
County shall be approved by the Illinois department of transportation, division of water resources, the U.S. army corps of engineers and the Illinois
environmental protection agency. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
