2,500 students 65
C. Location: School sites shall be located in the Village in accordance with plans theretofore or hereafter adopted by U-46. If U-46 has not planned a
school site within the proposed subdivision, PD, PUD, and/or development, or in the neighborhood in which such subdivision, PD, PUD, and/or
development is located, the school site shall be located in the Village and so as to be readily accessible to the greatest number of children projected for
such neighborhood. For purposes of any cash contribution in lieu of land and for the development of school grounds under this chapter, schools located
within the corporate limits of the Village, or within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits of the Village (the "Village's planning
jurisdiction"), shall be considered to be in the Village, provided that any such schools must actually serve Village students, and to the extent practicable
used for land acquisition or to improve school grounds of schools that will serve the proposed development.
D. Site Suitability: The subdivider or developer, at its own cost or expense, shall provide U-46 soil boring data, soil compaction test results and such other
engineering studies, data and information pertaining to the proposed school site which U-46 may request to enable it to determine the suitability of the
proposed to-be-dedicated land for school site purposes without extraordinary improvement costs. U-46 shall have the right to reject any site which the
school district determines, in accordance with sound engineering practice, is not suitable to school site purposes.
E. Improvements: Each school site shall be located on a fully improved street with curbs, gutters, sidewalks, street lights, storm sewer, electricity, gas and
telephone available at the property lines. Sanitary sewer and water mains shall be extended to the furthest boundary line of each school site within
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 568/702
right-of-way or easement designated by the Village. Sidewalks shall be provided along all street frontages. The site shall have direct access to such a
fully improved street across at least twenty percent (20%) of the distance of its perimeter. At least two (2) access routes or easements shall be
provided. Any pedestrian access route shall be at least thirty feet (30') wide and any vehicular access route or easement shall be at least sixty six feet
(66') wide. Any pedestrian access route less than fifty feet (50') wide shall be fenced with fencing material approved by the school district. The site shall
be developed to the standards set forth in subsections 11-10-7A, D, E and F of this chapter, except that the references to park site and park district
approval or notice in such subsections shall be read to mean school sites and approval or notice by the school district.
F. Cash Contribution: When the development is small and the resulting site is too small to be practical, or when the Corporate Authorities determine that
the available land is inappropriate for a school site, the Village shall require the developer to pay a cash contribution in lieu of the land dedication in
accordance with section 11-10-9 of this chapter. (Ord. 2017-101, 8-15-2017)
11-10-5: CASH DONATIONS FOR SCHOOL CONSTRUCTION:
A. Criteria And Formula: The amount of cash required to be donated to provide the necessary funds for the development of school grounds, including land
or site improvements, which includes school building or other infrastructure, including technological infrastructure necessitated and specifically and
uniquely attributed to the proposed subdivision, PD, PUD and/or development for the construction or expansion of elementary school facilities, middle
school facilities and high school facilities in the Village for the use of the children who will be generated by a proposed subdivision, PD, PUD and/or
development, shall be determined by: 1) multiplying the estimated ultimate number of elementary school age children to be generated by the proposed
subdivision, PD, PUD, and/or development determined on the basis of the demographic information set forth in section 11-10-16, table 1 of this
chapter, times two thousand eight hundred thirty seven dollars fifty four cents ($2,837.54); plus 2) multiplying the estimated ultimate number of middle
school age children to be generated by the proposed subdivision, PD, PUD, and/or development determined on the basis of demographic information
set forth in section 11-10-16, table 1 of this chapter, times four thousand three hundred eight dollars thirty one cents ($4,308.31); plus 3) multiplying the
estimated ultimate number of high school age children to be generated by the proposed subdivision, PD, PUD, and/or development, determined on the
basis of demographic information set forth in section 11-10-16, table 1 of this chapter, times five thousand six hundred eighty five dollars ninety one
cents ($5,685.91). The two thousand eight hundred thirty seven dollars fifty four cents ($2,837.54), the four thousand three hundred eight dollars thirty
one cents ($4,308.31), and the five thousand six hundred eighty five dollars ninety one cents ($5,685.91) are school construction donation factors
based on the most recent costs incurred by the U-46 School District in building an elementary, middle or high school, respectively that it has furnished
to the Village. These costs shall be adjusted for inflation and divided by the total capacity. The resulting per student cost shall be reduced according to
three (3) factors: 1) the proportion of school revenue attributable to property taxes; 2) the proportion of property taxes attributable to residential
property; and 3) an equity adjustment factor. These figures shall be reviewed, and if warranted by said review, adjusted on a regular basis. The
amounts set forth above by which the number of school age children from section 11-10-16, table 1 of this chapter have been multiplied by, and which
are then added together, are figures derived from section 11-10-16, table 3 of this chapter (the "2017 Donation Table").
B. Restrictions: All funds collected by the Village pursuant to subsection A of this section shall be used solely for construction or improvement of schools in
the Village of Bartlett, whether by the Village or U-46, and only for elementary, middle and/or high school purposes and not for pre-school or
administrative purposes. "Construction or improvement of schools" shall mean and include: 1) school site improvements, 2) new building design and
construction, 3) design and construction of building additions and improvements, 4) on site and off site school infrastructure improvements located in
the Village, including monies to provide or improve water, sanitary sewer, storm sewer and adjacent roadways to serve schools located in the Village of
Bartlett, and 5) instructional and classroom equipment incorporated into the school buildings or grounds so as to become fixtures. "Fixture" shall mean
such instructional and classroom equipment which is permanently affixed or attached to a school building, or imbedded in school grounds, by means of
cement, plaster, nails, bolts, screws, or other similar method, such that said equipment is not removable without damage to the building or land.
"Schools located within the Village of Bartlett" shall mean elementary, middle and/or high school buildings and grounds which are physically located
within the Village of Bartlett or within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits of the Village of Bartlett, except that as to the latter, any
monies collected hereunder shall be subject to the limitations hereinafter set forth in this subsection B. In no event shall such funds be used for
salaries, personnel expenses, operating expenses, furniture, books or equipment (unless such equipment is incorporated into the school buildings or
grounds so as to become a fixture) or for improvements of schools located outside of the Village of Bartlett. If any portion of such funds is not expended
for the purposes set forth in this paragraph within ten (10) years from the date of their receipt, then they shall be refunded to the subdivider or
developer who donated them. Any developer donation requested by U-46 to be used for expenditures permitted under this subsection B at any school
outside, but within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits of the Village, shall be limited to an amount determined by multiplying the full
amount of the donation by the number of students with Bartlett addresses in attendance at such a school divided by the official enrollment of the school
as of the date closest to the date on which the school district makes application for release of the donation. (Ord. 2017-101, 8-15-2017)
11-10-6: PROCEDURES FOR PAYING DONATIONS TO SCHOOL DISTRICT:
Funds contributed by a subdivider or developer for school purposes, including cash donations for school construction paid pursuant to section 11-10-5 of
this chapter, cash donations in lieu of land paid pursuant to section 11-10-9 of this chapter, or cash donations paid in combination with the dedication of
land pursuant to section 11-10-10 of this chapter, shall be deposited with the Village Treasurer to be held in the Developer Donation Fund and paid to U-
46, only upon the occurrence or satisfaction of the following conditions precedent to payment:
A. Indemnification For Past Payments: U-46 shall have executed and delivered to the Village a written agreement agreeing to indemnify, defend and hold
the Village harmless from any costs and expenses incurred by the Village related to said school district's use of developer donations previously paid to
U-46 by the Village under prior Village of Bartlett donation ordinances.
B. Indemnification Against Claims Arising Out Of This Chapter: U-46 shall have executed and delivered to the Village an Indemnification Agreement, in
form shown on Exhibit A on file in the Village agreeing to indemnify and hold the Village harmless from any causes of action brought against the Village
as a result of the passage or enforcement of this chapter, and/or Village ordinances 1996-63, 1998-40, 2000-57, 2000-129, 2001-143, 2003-72, 2007-
50, 2013-69, and 2017-101, including, but not limited to, challenges to the use of said funds paid to U-46.
C. Village Approval: The Corporate Authorities of the Village of Bartlett shall approve the requested payment of said donation funds to U-46 within sixty
(60) days after receipt of the school district's request based on its determination, made in the Village Board's reasonable discretion, that the school
district has sufficiently demonstrated that the funds have been used only for the limited purposes allowed in, and otherwise in accordance with, this
chapter. Each request for donation funds shall be accompanied by documentation evidencing the amount of such expenditure, the nature of each
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 569/702
expenditure (e.g., land improvements, construction, repair, type of equipment, etc.) and the specific school for which the expenditure was made. The
60-day period for the Village to approve a request for funds shall begin to run when the school district has furnished such documentation to the Village.
Within thirty (30) days of such request, the Village may require, in the exercise of its reasonable discretion, the school district to submit additional
documentation to assist the Village in determining that the school district has used the funds for the limited purposes allowed in, and in accordance
with, this chapter. If additional documentation is required, the Village shall make its final determination within sixty (60) days after receipt of the
additional documentation from the school district. (Ord. 2017-101, 8-15-2017)
11-10-7: CRITERIA FOR PARK AND SCHOOL LAND DEDICATION:
A. Philosophy Of Acceptance: The land or site for park and recreation land dedication must be suitable for the purpose for which it is intended. Land set
aside by developers for parks, recreation, and conservation purposes shall not be what has been left over after residential, commercial and industrial
development, or contain or include any floodplain, floodway, riparian ways, wet bottom detention basin, retention pond, or wetland.
B. Requirement And Population Ratio: The ultimate density of a proposed development shall bear directly upon the amount of land required for dedication.
The total requirement shall be ten (10) acres of land per one thousand (1,000) of ultimate population dedicated to active use in accordance with the
following classification:
Types Of Recreation Area Size Range
Minimum Acres
Per 1,000 People
Play lot Minimum 1 acre 0.5
Neighborhood park Minimum 5 acres 2.0
Community wide recreation park Minimum 15 acres 7.5
Total 10.0 acres of land per 1,000 people
"Active park areas" shall be defined as those areas specifically adapted and planned for a wide range of physical activity such as group games, physical
education, sports, and athletics. Facilities usually include, but are not limited to, playfields, game courts, rinks, ball diamonds, pools, tennis courts,
community centers, and play apparatus. Active areas shall not include any areas designated for water management, such as floodplain, floodway,
retention, detention or "wetland" areas.
C. Location: The Bartlett Park District Comprehensive Master Plan (the "park plan") as amended from time to time, shall be used as a guideline in locating
sites, or if none, as determined by the applicable park district on a case by case basis. A central location which will serve equally the entire
development is most desirable and whenever feasible, the site shall be in close proximity to elementary school sites. In large developments, these sites
can be located throughout the development according to established standards for park area distance.
D. Improvements: Each park site shall be located on a fully improved street with curbs, gutters, street lights, storm sewer, electricity, and gas available at
the property lines. Sanitary sewer and water mains shall be extended to the furthest boundary line of each park site within the right-of-way or easement
designated by the Village. Sidewalks shall be provided along all street frontages. The site shall have direct access to a fully improved street across at
least twenty percent (20%) of the distance of the perimeter. At least two (2) access routes or easements shall be provided. Any pedestrian access route
shall be at least thirty feet (30') wide and any vehicular access route or easement shall be at least sixty six feet (66') wide. Any pedestrian access route
less than fifty feet (50') wide shall be fenced along both sides with fencing material approved by the park district. Off street parking of three (3) spaces
per one thousand (1,000) people projected to be generated by the proposed development up to a maximum of four (4) spaces, shall be constructed for
any neighborhood park (including 1 handicapped space) and four (4) spaces per one thousand (1,000) people shall be constructed for any community
wide park including one handicapped space.
E. Topography And Grading: Each park site designated on the park plan as an "active park area" shall have sufficient level areas, uninterrupted by
streams and drainage ditches, to permit its development for football and baseball fields without the infields overlapping the football fields.
1. Slope:
a. Should not vary greatly in appearance from existing and adjacent slopes.
b. Optimum slopes range from two percent (2%) minimum to five percent (5%) maximum. No less than two percent (2%) slope is acceptable under
any circumstances.
c. Maximum allowable slope is ten percent (10%), except under special conditions where greater slopes are desirable to enhance recreation and
leisure utilization (i.e., sled hill).
d. That on-site drainage patterns be designated and constructed to:
(1) Insure flow toward swales.
(2) Insure drainage away from active recreation areas.
2. Grading:
a. Rough grading shall be completed at time of rough grading of adjacent contiguous areas.
b. Grading shall comply with Village and park district approved plans.
c. Subgrade shall be graded and compacted so it will be parallel to the finished grade.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 570/702
d. Subgrade material shall be loosened and fine graded to a depth of two inches (2") to four inches (4"). All stones over four inches (4") in size,
sticks, rubbish, and other foreign substances shall be removed.
e. Finished grades should be uniform in slope between points for which elevations have been established.
3. Soils:
a. Soils shall not differ from those occurring naturally.
b. Soils shall not offer any restriction to proposed recreation and leisure utilization.
c. Topsoil shall be spread evenly and lightly compacted to a minimum depth of six inches (6") over the entire site.
d. Topsoil will be good, friable soil, with good tillage, and shall be without any admixture of subsoil, gravel, stones, refuse, sand or other subsurface
elements.
e. Topsoil shall not be placed in a muddy or frozen condition.
f. Topsoil shall contain no toxic substances which may be harmful to plant growth.
g. Topsoil shall be spread no later than the placement of topsoil on the first lot adjacent to the park site.
4. Seeding:
a. All proposed park areas shall be seeded and an acceptable stand of grass established prior to dedication of the area to the park district.
b. Seeding to utilize Village and park district approved ground covers and grasses.
c. Seeding to be completed during desirable fall and spring planting times, dependent upon recommended seed planting specification for seed.
d. Seeding to be done on moderately dry soil on a seed bed which will easily accept and nurture germination of seeds.
e. Developer will be responsible for making necessary reparations to the site caused by erosion. Reparations will be completed prior to acceptance
by the park district.
5. Soil Conditions: Soil conditions shall meet the following requirements:
a. On sites (or those portions of the sites) not requiring fill, the soils shall have a bearing of no less than three thousand (3,000) pounds per square
foot for building areas, parking lot areas and other areas that will be required to support structures. All open space areas that will be used for sport
fields, dry bottom detention facilities or other open space uses, the soils shall have a bearing of no less than two thousand five hundred (2,500)
pounds per square foot. No minimum soil support values are required for areas that will accommodate wetlands, floodplains, riparian ways or wet
bottom detention facilities.
b. On sites (or portions of the sites) requiring fills, only clean clay soil materials with an unconfined compression strength of two thousand five
hundred (2,500) pounds per square inch (prior to compaction) ("clean clay fill") shall be placed in compacted layers of not more than twelve inches
(12") each within five feet (5') of the approved subgrade for the site as determined by the final engineering plans therefor approved by the Village
Engineer. For fill below said five feet (5') of compacted clay, only clean clay fill or "clean construction or demolition debris" as defined in section
3.160 of the Illinois Environmental Protection Act1 may be used to fill the said site, except that in no event shall reclaimed asphalt materials be
used as fill material. The fill materials shall be compacted to a minimum of:
(1) Ninety five percent (95%) of modified proctor for those areas of the site that will support buildings, parking lots and other structures,
(2) Ninety percent (90%) of modified proctor for sport fields, dry bottom detention facilities or other open space uses,
(3) Fills shall be placed in lifts no greater than twelve inches (12") thick,
(4) One compaction test will be required for each twelve inch (12") lift of fill and for every ten thousand (10,000) square feet of surface area filled,
(5) The Village shall receive copies of the compaction tests for each lift prior to the placement of the next lift, and
(6) The filled area shall be graded in a uniform manner in order to provide a surface that will drain freely and not pocket water.
The park district shall notify the Village within sixty (60) days of the park district's receipt of notice of the location of the park site on the
preliminary plat of the areas to be improved in accordance with these compaction requirements.
F. Term Defined: Water management areas shall be defined as those properties set aside as retention, detention, or wetland. The park district shall have
no obligation to accept the donation of said parcels, or any parcels lying in a floodplain or floodway as determined by the latest applicable County FIRM
or DFIRM maps. The park district may determine on a case by case basis whether or not any water management area should be accepted by the
district, in addition to the active park area described within subsection B of this section.
G. Cash Contribution: When the development is small and the resulting site is too small to be practical, or when the Corporate Authorities determine that
the available land is inappropriate for a park site, the Village shall require the developer to pay a cash contribution in lieu of the land dedication in
accordance with section 11-10-9 of this chapter. (Ord. 2017-101, 8-15-2017)
11-10-8: SCHOOL AND PARK PLAT REVIEW:
Copies of each subdivision plat, PD, PUD plan, boundary survey and topographical survey shall be transmitted to U-46, the park district, the fire protection
district, and the appropriate library district for their written recommendations at the same time as they are transmitted to the Bartlett Plan Commission, but
nothing therein contained shall be construed as requiring receipt of a recommendation prior to action by the Corporate Authorities of the Village. (Ord.
2017-101, 8-15-2017)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 571/702
11-10-9: CRITERIA FOR REQUIRING CASH CONTRIBUTIONS IN LIEU OF LAND DONATIONS:
A. Park Donations: Whenever the land dedication required by this chapter is determined by the Corporate Authorities to be unsuitable on the basis of:
1. Size;
2. Usefulness for park, recreation or open space purposes;
3. Inability to meet the requirements of section 11-10-7 of this chapter; or
4. Incompatibility with implementation of the park plan;
the Village shall require the subdivider or developer to pay a cash contribution in lieu of the land dedication required.
B. School Donations: Whenever the land dedication required by this chapter is determined by the Corporate Authorities to be unsuitable on the basis of:
1. Size;
2. Usefulness for school purposes;
3. Inability to meet the requirements of section 11-10-4 of this chapter and/or the applicable provisions of section 11-10-7 of this chapter; or
4. Incompatibility with implementation of the school plans;
the Village shall require the subdivider or developer to pay a cash contribution in lieu of the land dedication required calculated using the fair market
value set forth in subsection F of this section.
C. Use Of Funds: All funds collected by the Village for school land acquisition purposes, and any and all interest earned thereon, shall be used by U-46
solely for the purchase of a school site or sites in the Village of Bartlett to serve the immediate or future needs of the children from the proposed
subdivision, PD, PUD, and/or development, and for the improvement of such sites, whether by the Village or U-46. For purposes of any cash
contribution under this chapter, schools located within the corporate limits of the Village or within the Village's planning jurisdiction shall be considered
to be in the Village, provided that any such schools must actually serve Village students.
D. Use Of Cash Contribution: The cash contribution to be paid in lieu of land donations for school sites shall be held by the Village or other public body
designated by the Village, solely for use in the acquisition of a school site in the Village to serve the immediate or future needs of children from the
proposed subdivision, PD, PUD, and/or development, or for the improvement of any existing school site in the Village which predominantly serve such
needs.
E. Refund: If any portion of a cash contribution in lieu of: 1) park or recreational land donations is not expended for the purposes set forth in subsection A
of this section, or 2) school site donations are not expended for the purposes set forth in subsection B of this section, within ten (10) years from the
date of its receipt, it shall be refunded to the subdivider or developer who made such contribution, upon the written request of said subdivider or
developer.
F. Fair Market Value: The cash contributions in lieu of land shall be based on the "fair market value" of the acres of land in the area that otherwise would
have been dedicated as park and recreation and school sites and improved as provided in subsection 11-10-4E of this chapter with respect to school
sites and subsections 11-10-7D, E, and F of this chapter with respect to park sites. It has been determined that the present "fair market value" of such
vacant, improved and graded land in the Village is one hundred twenty five thousand dollars ($125,000.00) per acre based on the "Appraisal Report &
Real Estate Market Study for the Village of Bartlett Developer Land & Cash Donation Ordinance" with an effective date of April 28, 2017, prepared by
McCann Appraisal & Consulting, LLC, incorporated herein by this reference (the "McCann Report"), in which Illinois State certified general real estate
appraisers Michael McCann and James P. Foley opined that the fair market value of one acre of vacant subdivision tract in Bartlett, with all off-site
infrastructure and utilities extended to the property line of the tract, is presently one hundred twenty five thousand dollars ($125,000.00) per acre. In the
event a subdivider or developer files a written objection to the "fair market value", the developer shall submit an appraisal showing the "fair market
value" of such land in the area of his development or other evidence thereof, and final determination of said "fair market value" per acre of such
improved land shall be made by the Corporate Authorities based upon such information submitted by the subdivider or developer and from other
sources which the Village may procure or which may be submitted to the Corporate Authorities by the park district, U-46, or others. Submittal by a
developer or subdivider of the raw land cost of the development tract shall not be sufficient to establish the fair market value of one acre.
G. Cash Donation Restriction: Nothing contained in this section shall allow the developer to elect to make a cash donation in lieu of land if the Corporate
Authorities reasonably determine, based on the criteria set forth in subsections A and B of this section, that a land donation or land donations are made
necessary for school and/or park purposes by the development and the development will receive a direct and material benefit therefrom, and the land
donation requirement is necessitated by and specifically and uniquely attributable to the proposed subdivision, PD, PUD, and/or development. (Ord.
2017-101, 8-15-2017)
11-10-10: COMBINED LAND AND CASH DONATIONS:
There may be situations with respect to proposed subdivisions, PDs, PUDs, and/or developments when the Corporate Authorities may determine that a
combination of land dedication and a cash donation in lieu of land are both necessary. These occasions may arise when:
A. Only a portion of the land to be developed is proposed as the location for a park or school site. That portion of the land within the subdivision falling
within a planned park or school site shall be dedicated as a site as aforesaid, and a cash donation in lieu thereof shall be required for any additional
land that would have been required to be dedicated.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 572/702
B. A major part of the park or school site which will serve the residents of the proposed development has already been acquired (or will be acquired by
other developers) and only a small parcel of land is needed from the development to complete the site. The remaining portions shall be donated by
other developers, and a cash donation equal to the difference between the fair market value of the land donated and the fair market value of the land
required to be donated under sections 11-10-4 and 11-10-7 of this chapter shall be made. (Ord. 2017-101, 8-15-2017)
11-10-11: CONVEYANCE OF LAND:
A. Environmental Audit And Indemnification: Prior to conveyance to the Village, park district, U-46 of any land, the intended grantee shall be furnished with
an environmental risk audit prepared by an environmental professional meeting the minimum requirements of 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/22.2(j)(6)
(E)(iii) certified to and acceptable to the grantee assuring the grantee that there are no "hazardous substances" (as hereinafter defined) on, under, to or
from the property. Said environmental audit shall be what is commonly referred to as a Phase I environmental audit, which shall meet the minimum
requirements for a pre-acquisition audit as set forth in 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/22.2(j)(6)(E)(v) (the "Phase I audit"). In the event the Phase I
audit does not conclude that there is no presence or likely presence of a release or substantial threat of a release of hazardous substance(s) or
pesticide on, under, to or from the property, the developer shall furnish a Phase II environmental audit which meets the minimum requirements for a
pre-acquisition Phase II environmental audit as set forth in 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/22.2(j)(6)(E)(vi), including a soil toxicity analysis and
recommendation from said environmental professional meeting the minimum requirements of 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/22.2(j)(6)(E)(iii) which
concludes that there is no presence or likely presence of a release or substantial threat of a release of hazardous substances on, under, to or from the
subject property, and certifying that in the judgment of said environmental professional there is no reasonable probability that the land contains any
hazardous substances in violation of any Federal or State environmental standards. In the event said Phase II environmental audit and/or soil toxicity
analysis discloses the presence or likely presence of a release or a substantial threat of a release of any hazardous substances at, on, under, to or
from the land to be conveyed, the developer shall first cause all such hazardous substances to be removed at its sole cost and expense in accordance
with all Federal, State and local environmental laws, rules and regulations and furnish the intended grantee with an unconditional "No Further
Remediation Letter" (i.e., without restriction or reference to a site safety plan for future excavation and/or construction of and removing soil
contamination on the site) from the governmental agencies having jurisdiction over the clean up prior to conveyance of any of the land to the intended
grantee. Prior to the conveyance of the land, the subdivider or developer, as the case may be, and the owner of the land to be conveyed, shall execute
and deliver to the intended grantee an Environmental Indemnification Agreement in form approved by the Village Attorney, agreeing to defend,
indemnify and hold the Village, its President and Board of Trustees, officers, officials, employees, agents, successors and assigns, and the park district
and/or U-46, as the case may be, and their respective officers, officials, employees, agents, successors and assigns, harmless from and against any
and all liability, claims, damages, causes of action and expenses arising out of the presence of any hazardous substances (hereinafter defined) in,
under or upon said land to be conveyed prior to the date of conveyance.
The term "hazardous substance" includes, without limitation:
1. Those substances included in the definitions of "hazardous substances", "extremely hazardous substances", "hazardous materials", "toxic
substances", "toxic chemicals", "toxic wastes", "hazardous chemicals", "hazardous wastes", "solid waste", or "pesticides" in CERCLA, RCRA, SARA,
HSWA, TSCA, OSHA, FWPCA, Illinois Pesticides Act, Illinois Responsible Property Transfer Act, and the Hazardous Materials Transportation Act,
49 USC section 1801, et seq., as amended and as they may be amended in the future, and in the regulations promulgated pursuant to said laws.
2. Those substances defined in section 1003 of the Illinois Environmental Protection Act and in the regulations promulgated pursuant to said Act or
other Illinois laws pertaining thereto.
3. Those substances listed in the United States Department of Transportation table (49 CFR 172.101 and amendments thereto) or by the
Environmental Protection Agency (or any successor agency) as hazardous substances (40 CFR part 302 and amendments thereto).
4. Such other substances, materials, and wastes which are or become regulated under applicable local, State, or Federal law, or the United States
government, or which are classified as hazardous or toxic under Federal, State or local laws, ordinances or regulations.
5. Any material waste or substance which is: a) asbestos, b) polychlorinated biphenols, c) designated as a "hazardous substance" pursuant to section
311 of the Clean Water Act, 33 USC section 1251 et seq. (33 USC section 1321) or listed pursuant to section 307 of the Clean Water Act (33 USC
section 1317), d) explosives, or e) radioactive materials.
B. Title Insurance, Survey, Assessment Plats: Each deed or other instrument conveying land to the Village, the school district or the park district shall be
accompanied by: 1) a written commitment issued by a title insurer licensed to do business in Illinois to insure the grantee's title to such real estate in an
amount equal to its value computed pursuant to subsection 11-10-9F of this chapter, with extended coverage over the general exceptions to title and
subject only to: a) Real Estate Taxes not yet due and payable, b) covenants, conditions and restrictions which do not prohibit the use of the subject real
estate for school or park use, c) utility easements located within twenty feet (20') of the boundary lines of the subject real estate (except where
approved in the final engineering plans approved by the Village Engineer), d) drainage ditches, feeders, and laterals, and e) acts done or suffered by or
judgments against the grantees (collectively, the "permitted exceptions"); 2) a current plat of survey meeting the minimum standard detail requirements
update for ALTA/NSPS land title surveys effective February 23, 2016 with the following optional survey responsibilities and specifications from table A
thereto: Nos. 1, 2, 3, 4, 7a, 8, 9 and 21, certified to the grantee by a licensed Illinois land surveyor to be in compliance with said standards and
specifications, showing no encroachments; and 3) except in instances where the real estate is to be conveyed is a separate lot in a recorded
subdivision, an assessment plat and tax division petition in form acceptable to the appropriate County authorities so that the land to be conveyed can
be assigned its own permanent real estate index number for exemption purposes. In addition, monuments must be established and the land staked
immediately prior to dedication or conveyance of the property. The subdivider or developer shall pay for the cost of: a) owner's title insurance in an
amount calculated by multiplying the acreage of the parcel to be dedicated or conveyed times one hundred twenty five thousand dollars ($125,000.00)
per acre, b) the ALTA/NSPS land title survey, c) the assessment plat if required hereunder, and d) any and all costs in connection with the tax division if
required hereunder.
C. Real Estate Tax Escrow: The developer shall pay the general Real Estate Taxes on the land not yet due and payable as of the date of transfer, and
shall deposit a sum of money in escrow with the intended grantee's attorney or a title company licensed to do business in Illinois prorated as of the date
of transfer, on the basis of one hundred ten percent (110%) of the Tax Assessor's latest assessed valuation, the latest known equalization factors and
the latest known tax rate on the land. In the event that the previous tax information or the previous tax bill includes other property, then the amount to
be deposited in escrow shall be adjusted ratably based on the net acreage of the land compared to the net acreage of other parcels covered by said
tax bills. After the land has been divided for Real Estate Tax purposes and has been conveyed to the intended grantee, the grantee shall proceed with
due diligence to apply for Real Estate Tax exemption on the land. (Ord. 2017-101, 8-15-2017)
11-10-12: FIRE PROTECTION, LIBRARY AND VILLAGE CASH DONATIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 573/702
A. On the basis of demographic and fiscal impact analyses set forth above, the Corporate Authorities have determined that in order to provide the Village
with funds to defray the increased cost of providing police protection and the Village services, the fire district to provide fire protection services, during
the development and home building process of the subdivision, PD, PUD and/or development, and police protection and other Village services, fire
protection services, and to provide library facilities and services to residences after an occupancy permit has been granted, but before proportionate tax
revenues are generated by such new subdivision, PD, PUD, and/or development, a cash donation is required to be made by the developers based on
the following standards:
Fire protection district $199.78 per capita
Police Department 332.10 per capita
Village service 710.54 per capita
Library district 144.50 per capita
B. Funds contributed by a subdivider or developer for these purposes shall be deposited in accordance with the developer cash equivalents table in
section 11-10-16, table 3 of this chapter, and expressly made a part hereof, with the Village Treasurer to be held in the Developer Donation Fund and
paid without interest to the above districts on a semi-annual basis, except for payments to the school district, which shall be made in accordance with
the provisions of subsection 11-10-6C of this chapter.
C. These donations will be adjusted periodically to reflect increases or decreases in the cost of providing services, based upon changes in the budget
expenditures in each taxing body's most recently approved budget furnished to the Village. (Ord. 2017-101, 8-15-2017)
11-10-13: PAYMENT OF DONATIONS:
All cash donations, including cash in lieu of land, shall be prorated on a per building unit cost and paid prior to issuance of a building permit. (Ord. 2017-
101, 8-15-2017)
11-10-14: ANNEXATIONS:
The donation of land and/or cash donations as required by this chapter shall also be required as a condition to the annexation of any land to the Village
and provisions therefor shall be incorporated in any annexation or preannexation agreements governing such land. Whenever land is annexed to the
Village, if not already within a park district, library district or fire district, the landowner shall prepare the necessary plats, petitions for annexation and
documents, at his/her/its expense, for annexation to the Bartlett Park District, the Bartlett Fire Protection District, (or the South Elgin Fire Protection District
in Kane County), and either the Bartlett Library District or the Gail Borden Public Library District, as the case may be; provided said property is then
contiguous to each said district. In the event a parcel is contiguous to both the Bartlett Library District and the Gail Borden Public Library District, the
property sought to be annexed shall be annexed to the Bartlett Library District. (Ord. 2017-101, 8-15-2017)
11-10-15: SUCCESSORS:
In the event the Village, U-46, the Bartlett Park District, the Bartlett Fire Protection District and the Bartlett Library District, or any of them, shall cease
being in existence, then this chapter shall be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the successor municipality, school district, park district, fire district or
library district, as the case may be, whose boundaries include the applicable subdivision, PD, PUD, and/or development. (Ord. 2017-101, 8-15-2017)

Chapter 11
GENERAL PROVISIONS
11-11-1: REIMBURSEMENT FOR CONSULTANT FEES:
The subdivider/developer shall be required to reimburse the village for all engineering, planning and legal consultant fees, costs and expenses incurred by
the village in connection with review, approval and recording of any subdivision or PUD plan/plat in addition to the fees stipulated in chapter 5, "Fees", of
this title.
A. The subdivider/developer shall reimburse the village for any and all expenses incurred by it for attorney fees in connection with the subdivision plat/PUD
plan review and approval process, including the cost of preparing or examining the public improvements completion agreement, bonds, letters of credit
and any other agreements, securities and guarantees provided for in this title, furnishing legal opinions, the preparation of bills of sale, deeds or other
instruments of conveyance, or easement grants and agreements, the enforcement of the public improvements completion agreement, and any other
legal expense that may be incurred by the village in connection with the subdivision plat/PUD plan review and approval process.
B. The president and board of trustees may, at their discretion, obtain from its engineering, planning and legal consultants estimates of the cost of the
services they will provide in connection with the review and approval of a subdivision plat/PUD plan, and require a cash deposit from the
subdivider/developer in the amount of such estimate before incurring any such expenses. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-11-2: MODIFICATIONS:
The plan commission may recommend modifications from the requirements of this title in specific cases of hardship which, in its opinion, do not affect the
general plan or the spirit of this title. Such recommendations shall be communicated to the village board in writing with the reasons thereof. The village
board may grant modifications from the requirements of this title in such cases. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-11-3: OCCUPANCY PERMITS:
No permit for the occupancy or use of any structure in a subdivision/PUD shall be issued unless and until all of the public improvements for that
subdivision/PUD except the "second lift" of street pavement, parkway tree planting and restoration, driveway approaches and streetlights have been
completed. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-11-4: ENFORCEMENT:
No plat of subdivision shall be recorded in the office of the recorder of deeds (or registered in the office of the registrar of titles for Cook County property
registered under the Torrens System) or have any validity until it shall have been approved by the president and board of trustees in the manner
prescribed by this title. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-11-5: RECORDING; REGISTRATION:
The village clerk shall cause all approved final plats of subdivision and final PUD plans to be recorded in the office of the recorder of deeds (or registered
in the office of the registrar of titles for Cook County property registered under the Torrens System) of the county in which such subdivision/PUD is
situated. After it has been so recorded or registered, the original copy of such plat/plan shall be returned to the village and filed and kept by the village
clerk among the official records of the village of Bartlett. The village clerk shall invoice the developer for the cost of recording and all required copies
accompanying. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-11-6: OTHER REGULATIONS PREVAIL:
None of the provisions of this title pertaining to permits, bonds, letters of credit, fees, acceptance and approval of public improvements shall be construed
as exempting subdividers, general contractors, sidewalk contractors, cement contractors, paving contractors, building contractors, plumbing contractors or
plumbers, sewer contractors, sewer builders, drain layers, electrical contractors or electricians, or any other contractor or craftsman from any other
ordinance or regulation of the village with respect to licenses, fees, surety, inspection or other control. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)
11-11-7: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
Any person or entity who or which subdivides or develops any real estate under the jurisdiction of the village of Bartlett or constructs any public
improvement thereon, or on any portion thereof, in violation of the provisions of this title shall be, upon conviction, fined in such amount not less than
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 576/702
twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), as the court shall determine, for each offense. A separate offense shall be
deemed to have been committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)

11-12-3: APPENDIX C; EASEMENT ABROGATION REQUIREMENTS:
A. Abrogation Requirements:
ABROGATION REQUIREMENTS
I. Four (4) copies of the Plat of Abrogation shall be submitted to the Community Development Department for review. The Plat must include all items
listed in the Plat of Abrogation Checklist.
II. Proof of Ownership in the form of a copy of a current title insurance commitment or policy issued by a title insurance company licensed to transact
business in Illinois must be submitted.
III. The application fee is $150. The petitioner will be responsible for expenses generated by the Village's Engineering consultants (if required).
IV. Contact J.U.L.I.E. (1-800-892-0123) to locate the existing utilities on the property.
V. The approved mylar signed by the owner and utility companies (if required) shall be submitted to the Community Development Department for the
Village President's and Village Engineer's signatures.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 583/702
VI. The petitioner is responsible for recording the approved Plat of Abrogation and any and all expenses associated with its recording.
NOTE:The Village of Bartlett reserves the right to make review comments and may require revisions to the Plat of Abrogation.

11-12-4: APPENDIX D; TRAFFIC MANAGEMENT ORDINANCE:
A. Purpose And Intent: This section is enacted pursuant to the Illinois municipal code and the zoning regulatory authority granted to the village of Bartlett,
Illinois, by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-13-1, for the purposes of lessening or avoiding traffic congestion, delay and safety hazards arising from
the traffic generated by new developments.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 586/702
In the implementation of this section, the following objectives are established for the protection of the safety of the motoring public, and for the
lessening of traffic congestion on public streets and highways:
1. Incorporating the traffic generation of committed developments within the village of Bartlett, Illinois, into the analysis of traffic impacts.
2. Promoting and protecting the safety and efficiency of public streets and highways.
3. Balancing the traffic demand generated by new developments with the capacity of the external street and highway system.
4. Protecting existing residential streets from the undesirable effects of increased through traffic.
5. Establishing level of service standards for critical intersection operation and performance.
The regulations as set forth herein are deemed the minimum necessary to accomplish the above objectives.
B. Rules And Definitions:
1. Rules: The language as set forth herein shall be interpreted in accordance with the rules of construction as stipulated in chapter 2 of this title.
2. Definitions: The following words and terms shall have the meaning set forth herein, except where otherwise specifically indicated in chapter 2 of this
title. Words and terms not defined herein shall have the meaning indicated by common dictionary definition.
APPROPRIATE HIGHWAY AGENCY: The highway authority having jurisdiction for the operation of a street or highway.
BASELINE LEVEL OF SERVICE: The level of service evaluated under baseline traffic conditions assigned to the existing and committed highway
network.
BASELINE TRAFFIC: Nonsite traffic consisting of existing traffic at the time of development plus projected traffic from committed developments
within the study area.
COMMITTED DEVELOPMENT: A development which has: a) received final plat or building permit approval, or is reasonably close to attaining same;
or b) is under construction or nearly completed, but which may not be fully occupied and generating traffic at the time of development application
under this section.
CRITICAL INTERSECTION: The intersection of any of the following: major arterial streets, minor arterial streets, collector streets, and other
intersections impacted by the proposed development.
DEVELOPMENT: Any construction or expansion of building(s) or structure(s), or any changes in the use of any building(s) or structure(s) or land use
that will generate additional vehicular traffic; or any application for subdivision, zoning variation, zoning amendment, planned unit development,
special use, or building permit within the corporate limits of the village of Bartlett.
EXISTING AND COMMITTED HIGHWAY NETWORK: That system of highway improvements which exist, or are included in an annual capital
improvement program, to be let for construction within the current year, or subsequent calendar or fiscal year.
FLOOR AREA (GROSS): The sum of the gross horizontal areas of the several floors of such building or buildings, as measured from the exterior
faces of exterior walls, or from the centerline of party walls separating two (2) buildings.
FLOOR AREA RATIO (FAR): The numerical value obtained by dividing the gross floor area of a building, or buildings, by the total area of the lot or
parcels of land on which the building or buildings are located.
GROSS RESIDENTIAL ACRES: The total acreage of land proposed and available for residential development, including the land area designated
for schools, parks, floodplain storage compensation, stormwater management facilities, streets, etc.
GROSS RESIDENTIAL DENSITY: The ratio of total existing or planned residential units within a development divided by the gross residential
acreage of the proposed development.
IMPACT FEE PROGRAM HIGHWAY NETWORK: The existing and committed highway network plus those highway improvements anticipated to be
wholly or partially funded with impact fees as authorized by the Illinois road improvement impact fee law within five (5) years from the payment of an
impact fee by the developer.
LEVEL OF SERVICE: The measurement of highway intersection performance based on capacity utilization and delay.
LONG RANGE TRANSPORTATION PLANS: The advisory long range street and highway plans adopted by the Chicago area transportation study,
DuPage County, and other appropriate highway agencies as amended or updated.
PEAK HOUR (A.M.): The one hour period in the morning representing the highest hourly volume of traffic flow on the adjacent public street system.
PEAK HOUR (P.M.): The one hour period in the evening representing the highest hourly volume of traffic flow on the adjacent public street system.
PROGRAMMED HIGHWAY NETWORK: The existing and committed highway network plus those improvements funded in the current five (5) year
capital improvement program for streets and highways as prepared by the Illinois department of transportation, the DuPage County department of
transportation, Illinois state toll highway authority, other appropriate highway agencies and municipalities in DuPage County.
RESIDENTIAL STREET: A street primarily providing land access to adjacent residential land uses and typically classified as a cul-de-sac, local
street, or subdivision collector street.
SITE RELATED IMPROVEMENTS: Improvements necessary for direct ingress/egress to the development in question, and include the following:
a. Site driveways and public/private streets,
b. Right and left turn lanes leading to such access,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 587/702
c. Traffic signal and other control for such access,
d. Acceleration/deceleration lanes or tapers,
e. Median openings/closings,
f. Landscaping, sidewalks, lighting, utilities, berms and other highway appurtenances.
SITE TRAFFIC: Existing or projected vehicular traffic generated by the development.
STUDY AREA: The geographic area containing those critical intersections and connecting highway segments which are impacted by the site traffic
generated by the development.
SYSTEM IMPROVEMENTS: Added lanes, signal improvements, and other roadway improvements not considered as site related improvements.
TRAFFIC IMPACT: The adverse impact of a development on intersection level of service and/or street and highway safety and operations as
determined by the criteria and procedures set forth in subsection D of this section.
TRAFFIC IMPACT ANALYSIS: The analysis of the effect of site traffic generated by a development on intersection level of service and the safety and
operation of the public street and highway system.
TRAFFIC IMPACT MITIGATION MEASURE: Any measure or improvement taken by, or required of, the developer in order to lessen, abate or reduce
the traffic impact of the development on the public street and highway system.
TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM MANAGEMENT: Any of several different operational or management strategies for reducing the peak hour traffic
demand generated by a development, including, but not limited to, carpooling, vanpooling, flex time, staggered work hours and mass transportation.
C. Administration And General Provisions:
1. Traffic Management Ordinance Administration: The authority for administration of this section is hereby vested in the village engineer.
2. Duties Of The Village Engineer: The village engineer shall be responsible for the general administration of this section, and should:
a. Review all proposed development projects to assess their compliance with the provisions of this section.
b. Maintain information on committed developments within the municipality for use in estimating baseline traffic generation in the traffic impact study.
c. Cooperate with state, county and other municipalities and other agencies to facilitate the administration of this section.
d. Maintain for public inspection copies of traffic studies and related documents and records for all developments approved subject to this section.
e. Receive and process all applications for variations, appeals and text amendments.
In the performance of those duties, the village engineer may utilize the professional technical assistance of engineering, planning or other staff to
ensure that reasonable engineering and planning practices and standards are utilized in the review of applications for approval of development
plans. Where, in the opinion of the village engineer, outside professional assistance is required, a professional engineer registered in the state of
Illinois may be retained by the village engineer for the purpose of reviewing a traffic impact analysis for the development. The actual costs incurred
for the services of such professional assistance shall be assigned to the developer.
3. Administrative Review And Appeal Process: If the village engineer reviews a proposed subdivision plat of PUD plan and determines that traffic
impact mitigation is required under subsection D3b of this section, an applicant who disagrees with that determination may appeal the decision to the
zoning board, plan commission, zoning board of appeals, or other committee or board as determined by the corporate authorities. Such appeal shall
be processed on an expedited basis.
4. Review By Plan Commission Or Zoning Board Of Appeals: Consideration of the criteria for traffic impact and traffic impact mitigation as contained in
subsections D and E of this section shall be used to expand upon the zoning review standards utilized by the plan commission or zoning board of
appeals, whichever has jurisdiction, in their review and deliberation of all requests for:
a. Planned unit developments,
b. Special or conditional use,
c. Zoning variation,
d. Zoning amendment.
No additional traffic impact review under subsection D3a of this section shall be required within one year after the adoption of the ordinance granting
a zoning change or a special use permit for a development.
For developments which are to be constructed in phases, no additional traffic impact review under subsection D3a of this section shall be required as
long as construction of the development proceeds in accordance with the phase completion schedule set forth in the ordinance granting a zoning
change or a special use permit for the development.
5. Subdivisions: All developments which involve the subdivision of land and which create a "traffic impact" as defined and determined by this section,
shall be considered and reviewed procedurally as planned unit developments, and shall meet the requirements of subsection C4 of this section.
6. Other Development: All other development of lots of record, including those which may have received previous approval as planned unit
developments, special or conditional uses, zoning variations, or zoning amendments, but which create a "traffic impact", as defined and determined
by this section, shall be considered and reviewed procedurally as a special or conditional use and shall meet the requirements of subsection C4 of
this section.
7. Determination Of Traffic Generation: In the determination of whether a development shall be covered by subsection C5 or C6 of this section, traffic
generation, and resultant traffic impact, shall be based on the maximum allowable floor area ratio or gross residential density and intensity of use
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 588/702
permitted by the underlying zoning. A lower density or intensity shall be used for traffic impact evaluation if the developer agrees to such density
and/or intensity of use as a condition to the issuance of a building permit by the village.
8. Findings: Upon conducting the required public hearing on an appeal, the planning commission or zoning board of appeals, whichever has
jurisdiction, shall set forth to the board of trustees, their recommendation(s) on the development and their findings as they relate to the requirements
and provisions of this section, in addition to other standards for review which may include: a) the desirability of the development as regards physical
development and neighborhood compatibility; b) tax base; and c) the economic well being and general welfare of the community.
9. Conditions And Guarantees: As a condition to the approval of a planned unit development, special or conditional use, zoning variation or zoning
amendment, the plan commission or zoning board of appeals, whichever has jurisdiction, may recommend and the board of trustees may stipulate
such conditions and restrictions upon the establishment, location, design, layout, density, construction and operation of the development as may be
necessary for the mitigation of traffic impact of the development.
In all cases in which developments are approved with traffic impact mitigation measures as conditions, the board of trustees shall require such
evidence and guarantees as it may deem necessary as proof that the conditions stipulated in the connection therewith are being and will be complied
with.
10. Relationship To Other Planning And Zoning Ordinances: The application of this section does not relieve, alter, or otherwise modify the need for the
development to comply with other applicable village ordinances and the official comprehensive plan of the village.
11. Intergovernmental Coordination And Cooperation: In reviewing the traffic impact of developments under this section, the village should coordinate
with other public and private agencies on the implementation of transportation/land use goals and objectives as may be determined by the long
range transportation plans, local and regional land use plans, the local, regional and metropolitan planning process, or other plans and/or programs.
12. Review Of Public Development Plans: All plans for development activities to be undertaken by governmental entities, or public utilities, including
those regulated by the Illinois commerce commission, shall be reviewed by the village engineer for compliance with the provisions and intent of this
section.
D. Traffic Impact Analysis:
1. Overview Of Traffic Impact Analysis: The following criteria shall be used to determine the traffic impact for a development, and to identify the traffic
impact mitigation measures which may be approved by the village as conditions or restrictions on the development for the purpose of lessening or
avoiding traffic impact on the public street and highway system.
Evaluation of the traffic impact of a development with respect to these criteria is dependent on the baseline traffic volume and the geometry of the
public street and highway system in the study area as well as the site traffic generation of the development itself. The extent of traffic impact, and the
resultant traffic impact mitigation, will therefore vary by the particular development proposed at a particular location.
2. Guidelines For Traffic Impact Analysis: Traffic impact analysis required for developments under this section shall be based on the traffic impact
analysis report guidelines as adopted and set forth in subsection G of this section.
In the establishment of intersection level of service, and in the review of traffic impact analysis, as determined below, the village shall consider the
degree of highway capacity utilization by the development and the extent to which capacity is available for future traffic growth.
When future highway improvements, as might be included on either the impact fee program network or programmed highway network (as may be
permitted under subsection E2f of this section) are utilized for traffic impact analysis, the analysis shall include a five (5) year estimate of traffic
growth on streets and highways within the study area to reflect traffic generated by land use development outside the study area.
3. Traffic Impact Criteria: The following criteria are established as the minimum threshold criteria for identification of traffic impact under this section:
a. Level Of Service For Critical Intersections: For developments with site traffic generation greater than one hundred (100) peak hour vehicle trips
(inbound plus outbound) in either of the A.M. or P.M. peak hours, and the Saturday peak hour for certain developments, the traffic impact on level
of service shall be as determined below, for critical intersections where:
(1) Baseline Level Of Service Better Than C: The development causes one or more critical intersections to operate at worse than level of service C
under baseline plus site traffic conditions as assigned to the existing and committed highway network; or
(2) Baseline Level Of Service Worse Than C: The development causes the level of service for one or more critical intersections to worsen by more
than five percent (5%) (as measured by the average delay per vehicle or critical lane volume for signalized intersections, by reserve capacity for
unsignalized intersections under baseline traffic plus site traffic conditions as assigned to the existing and committed highway network).
b. Operational Or Safety Considerations: Traffic impact mitigation shall be required of all developments, regardless of site traffic volume, which might
reasonably be anticipated to create or worsen traffic safety or operational problems related to site access and traffic generation as based on, but
not limited to, the following criteria:
(1) Lack of adequate gaps for site traffic to enter/exit the external highway vehicle stream.
(2) The proposed use involves a drive-through, carryout or other automobile service oriented operation, where automobile stacking or queuing may
affect highway operations.
(3) The development is anticipated to create or worsen safety or operational problems due to "through" traffic increases on residential streets
within the village.
(4) The parking generation and on street or off street parking design characteristics of the development create or worsen conflicts between nonsite
traffic and parked vehicles.
(5) Internal site circulation and access design and related site access improvements deviate from applicable standards and policies for sight
distance, left turn lanes and other design features.
In determining the extent and specific nature of traffic impact related to the general safety and operational criteria listed above, the standards and
policies currently adopted by the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials, the Institute of Transportation Engineers, or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 589/702
the "Illinois Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices", may apply where they are more restrictive than the standards of the appropriate highway
agency.
E. Traffic Impact Mitigation:
1. Requirement For Public Hearing And Review: Developments which create a traffic impact, as determined by the criteria set forth in subsection D3 of
this section, and which are appealed, shall require a public hearing before the plan commission or zoning board of appeals, whichever has
jurisdiction, as provided for in subsections C4 through C6 of this section, to review and consider traffic impact mitigation measures.
2. Traffic Impact Mitigation Measures: Traffic impacts shall be lessened or reduced through the application of one or more of the traffic mitigation
measures that follow:
a. Reduction In Development Density: Reductions in trip generation and resultant traffic impacts can be realized by lowering the density of
development as measured by floor area ratio or gross residential density.
The village may take the following action to reduce traffic impact of the development as it relates to density:
(1) Reduce the allowable floor area ratio or gross residential density for the development otherwise permitted in the existing or proposed zoning for
the property.
(2) Deny or modify a zoning variation or amendment that would increase the floor area ratio or gross residential density of the project.
b. Change To A Less Traffic Intensive Land Use: Reductions in traffic generation and resultant traffic impact can be realized by restricting the
permitted land uses for the property to those which have lower traffic generating characteristics.
The village may take the following actions to reduce the traffic impact of a development as it relates to intensity:
(1) Deny or amend a request for a special or conditional use.
(2) Deny or amend a requested zoning amendment or zoning variations to a higher and more traffic intensive zoning classification for the proposed
development.
(3) Limit or otherwise specify the permitted land uses that may be developed under the existing zoning classification for the proposed development
based on the traffic generating character of those land uses.
c. Transportation Management Strategies: Traffic impact may be mitigated by reducing the number of auto trips, or increasing the occupancy of
automobile trips through the use of operating improvements such as flex hours, carpooling or vanpooling programs, transit related project or
programs, subject to the approval of the village provided that:
(1) The parameters and requirements of the operating program shall be specified in an agreement between the developer and the village recorded
as a restrictive covenant running with the land binding all future owners, providing for annual inspection and monitoring by the village and
penalties for noncompliance, and injunctive relief.
d. Development Phasing: A development may be approved in phases so that site traffic added by the development can be accommodated by site or
system highway improvements included in the traffic impact analysis as mitigation measures. Subsequent phases of the development, however,
shall each be required to comply with the provisions of this section.
e. Site Related Highway Access Improvements: Site related highway access improvements may be utilized to mitigate the traffic impact of a
development subject to criterion listed below, and with the approval of the village and the appropriate highway agency:
(1) Site Improvements: Construction of site related highway improvements which improve the level of service or safety of the public street and
highway system impacted by the development, provided that such improvements are approved by the appropriate highway agency.
f. System Improvements: Developments required to pay an impact fee under the road improvement impact fee law of the state of Illinois shall receive
credit for highway improvements contained on the impact fee highway network as traffic impact mitigation measures.
The village may, however, require that the development be staged or phased over a period of time, that the timing of improvement completion
bears a reasonable relationship to the timing (phasing) of traffic generation from the development.
Construction or funding of system related highway improvements over and above those delineated in the impact fee program highway network
may be used for traffic impact mitigation provided that each of the following criteria are met:
(1) The highway improvements are included on the programmed highway network and the timing of improvement completion bears a reasonable
relationship to the timing of traffic generation from the development.
(2) System improvements over and above the programmed highway network may be approved for traffic impact mitigation provided that such
improvements are consistent with the long range transportation plan for DuPage County and are approved by the appropriate highway agency.
g. Other Methods: Other methods proposed for traffic impact mitigation by the developer, which have been documented and proven to be effective in
mitigating the traffic impacts of development, may be considered by the village.
F. Variations: If the standards imposed by this section place undue hardship on a specific development proposal, the applicant may apply to the village for
a variation. The zoning board of appeals shall review the applicant's request for a variation and shall submit its recommendation to the village board of
trustees.
1. Standards For Considering Variations: No variation shall be granted unless the applicant demonstrates that:
a. The traffic impact mitigation measures contained in subsection E of this section are not practicable, feasible or effective in accomplishing the
stated objectives.
b. An exceptional hardship would result if the variances were not granted.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 590/702
c. The relief requested is the minimum necessary.
d. There will be no additional threat to the public health, safety or welfare.
e. There will be no additional public expense or relief for improvement to streets and highways.
f. The applicant's circumstances are unique and do not represent a general problem.
G. Traffic Impact Analysis Report Guidelines: The following outline is offered as a guideline for the preparation of traffic impact studies prepared to fulfill
the requirements of this section:
1. Introduction:
a. Letter of transmittal identifying the name of the development, purpose of the report and who prepared the report.
b. Description of proposed land use and operating characteristics, zoning (and requested change in zoning if appropriate), building floor space
(specify gross leasable or gross floor area) and floor area ratio or gross residential density of the development.
c. Location and type of proposed access points (site plan should show all existing driveways or streets within 200 feet of proposed drives or within
the limits of proposed highway improvements, whichever is greater).
d. Description and map of study area.
e. Identification of peak hours, and whether weekday and/or Saturday peaks are to be used in the analysis.
f. List specific issues to be addressed by the traffic impact study, based on discussion with local officials and highway agency representatives.
2. Baseline Traffic Conditions:
a. Description of road network and critical intersections in the vicinity of the site (number of lanes, jurisdiction, speed limit, and other pertinent
information).
b. Turning movement counts during the peak hour(s).
c. Prepare gap, queue length of other studies, where appropriate.
3. Site Traffic Generation:
a. Use the Institute of Transportation Engineers' "Trip Generation Manual" (fifth edition as updated). Other rates must be documented based on
local/regional uses of comparable location and characteristics.
All trip generation rates below the level provided in table 1 of this subsection, and all retail "pass-by" factors that exceed the level provided in table
1 of this subsection, must be documented (ITE or local studies are acceptable).

The ITE "Trip Generation Manual" provides a more detailed breakdown of trip generation by square footage for nonresidential uses.
Traffic generation rates used in this report (from ITE or DuPage County studies) assume a base (low intensity) level of bus service (fixed route or
demand responsive) open to the general public. Express bus service or subscription transit service (including carpooling and vanpooling) may be
relocated in adjusted trip generation rates with the appropriate mode split analysis documentation.
b. Traffic generation (inbound and outbound) during the peak impact hours should be based on the maximum allowable density of development
permitted by the underlying zoning, unless lower densities are agreed to by the developer.
c. Average daily traffic generation (and assignments) may be required for pavement structural design purposes.
4. Nonsite Traffic Projections:
a. Define design year (opening of proposed development or other agreed upon point in time).
b. Identify committed developments in the study area which impact critical intersections, and incorporate nonsite traffic into the baseline traffic
volume.
c. Use an appropriate growth rate or other forecasting method to adjust nonsite through traffic volumes where a significant through traffic component
exists (e.g., intercounty trips or trips generated beyond the development).
d. For large scale developments (greater than 500 peak direction trips per hour) traffic assignments from subarea transportation models or
countywide long range traffic assignments should be reviewed.
5. Traffic Assignments:
a. Discuss method for traffic assignment and assumptions used for assignment of traffic to the network.
b. Assign peak period traffic to intersections and access points. Include figures for:
(1) Baseline traffic,
(2) Site traffic,
(3) Total traffic (baseline plus site).
6. Baseline And Future Capacity And Operations Analysis:
a. Minimum Number Of Critical Intersections: The minimum number of critical intersections to be included in the traffic impact study shall be based
on the schematic illustrations contained on figure 1 of this subsection.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 592/702
The village engineer may determine that additional critical intersections be included in the analysis based on review of the trip generation and
distribution parameters of the development, as well as the specific configuration of the affected highway network.
b. Level Of Service Analysis: A level of service analysis should be prepared for every new development which generates one hundred (100) or more
peak hour, peak direction vehicle trips.
The level of service for critical intersections shall be calculated using the "critical movement analysis" procedures of the national cooperative
highway research program special report 210.
The computerized procedures for signalized intersection analysis contained in the highway capacity manual special report 209 may be utilized if
the village engineer believes its use may be more appropriate for analysis of existing or improved signalized intersection conditions.
(1) Baseline Level Of Service: Level of service should be calculated using baseline traffic data and the existing and committed highway network.
(2) Development Generating Five Hundred Or More Vehicles Per Hour: Any development which generates five hundred (500) or more vehicles per
hour during the A.M. or P.M. peak hour shall be considered a large scale development, and shall evaluate traffic conditions projected for the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 593/702
design period used by the appropriate highway agency (normally 20 years) based on traffic assignments approved by the village engineer, and
based on the approved long range plan highway network.
7. Operation Problems: Identify operation problems.
8. Recommended Access Location And Design: Use of arterial corridor development policies and standards or other adopted criteria (where more
restrictive) is recommended.
a. Review site plan:
(1) Internal reservoir at access points.
(2) Parking layout.
(3) Loading dock locations and access, including design truck uses.
(4) Evaluate transit accessibility using the "pace development guidelines".
(5) Recommend changes to site plan.
9. Proposed Traffic Mitigation Measures:
a. Identify proposed traffic impact mitigation measures, including, but not limited to, street and highway widening, intersection traffic control, change
in land use intensity (floor area ratio or use), change in site plan, alternative work schedules, ride sharing, etc.
10. Summary: Summary of findings and recommendations (may be listed in outline form at the beginning of the report). (Ord. 95-24, 4-4-1995)

within six (6) months of the date of this Agreement, except for good cause shown, and unless said time period is extended by the Corporate Authorities
of the Village in its sole discretion.
