(60) days of its written request, be refunded the balance of its deposit under this section, less:
a. Seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), plus
b. All ascertainable costs and expenses incurred by the municipality in connection with the application.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 686/702
B. Other Municipal Costs: All license nonretailer telecommunications providers shall, within thirty (30) days after written demand therefor, reimburse the
municipality for all direct and indirect costs and expenses incurred by the municipality in connection with any modifications, amendment, renewal or
transfer of the license agreement.
C. Construction Permit Fee: Prior to the issuance of a construction permit, the nonretailer telecommunications provider ("the permittee") shall pay a permit
fee equal to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or one and one-half percent (1.5%) of the estimated cost of constructing the telecommunications
facilities, as certified by the applicant's engineer and approved by the village engineer, whichever is greater. This fee is intended to compensate the
municipality for all staff expenses, excluding engineering expenses and attorney fees recovered under subsections A1 and A2 of this section,
associated with reviewing and administering permittee's construction permit application.
1. Any permittee for a construction permit pursuant to article G of this chapter shall reimburse the municipality for all engineering expenses incurred by
the municipality in reviewing permittee's construction permit application.
2. Any permittee for a construction permit pursuant to article G of this chapter shall reimburse the municipality for all attorney fees incurred by the
municipality in reviewing permittee's construction permit application.
3. Any permittee for a construction permit pursuant to article G of this chapter shall reimburse the municipality for any other direct or indirect costs that
the municipality incurs when administering and reviewing permittee's construction permit application, and which the municipality does not recover
under this section.
D. Annual License Fee: Unless otherwise agreed in a license agreement, each nonretailer telecommunications provider grantee shall pay an annual
license fee to the municipality as reimbursement for the municipality's costs in connection with reviewing, inspecting and supervising the use and
occupancy of the public ways on behalf of the public, and existing and future users. In 1997, for telecommunications facilities requiring excavation of
existing rights of way or easements, license grantee shall pay an annual license fee of one dollar ($1.00) per linear foot for each linear foot in which
license grantee's cable, conduit, fiber optic, or other telecommunications facilities occupies municipal property, public streets or public ways. In 1997,
the telecommunications facilities being installed in existing conduit, without the need of disturbing the right of way, license grantee shall pay an annual
license fee of fifty cents ($0.50) per linear foot for each linear foot in which license grantee's cable, conduit, fiber optic, or other telecommunications
facilities occupies municipal property, public streets, or public ways. This fee will be adjusted in five (5) year intervals, based upon cumulative changes
in the consumer price index for urban wage earners in the Chicago region.
E. Attorney Fees: Nonretailer telecommunications providers shall reimburse the municipality for all attorney fees incurred by the municipality including, but
not limited to, attorney fees incurred by the municipality for drafting agreements and any other necessary documents and for reviewing the applicant's
insurance, security submittals, and other necessary documents. In no event shall the municipality recover, under this section, attorney fees for
reviewing an application or attorney fees for reviewing a construction permit application.
F. Interest: In the event that any fees or recomputed amount is not made on or before the applicable dates heretofore specified, interest shall be charged
for such date at an annual rate of two percent (2%) over the price rate announced from time to time by Harris Trust And Savings Bank of Chicago,
Illinois.
G. Regulatory Fees And Compensation Not A Tax: The regulatory fees and costs provided for in this section and any compensation charged and paid for
the public ways and provided for in this section, are separate from, and in addition to, any and all federal, state, local and municipal taxes as may be
levied, imposed or due from a telecommunications carrier or provider, its customers or subscribers, or on account of the lease, sale, delivery or
transmission of telecommunications services.
H. Retail Telecommunications Providers: The terms, conditions, fees and provisions of this section shall not apply in retail telecommunications providers.
(Ord. 97-90, 12-2-1997)
ARTICLE G. CONSTRUCTION
13-3G-1: GENERAL:
No person shall commence or continue with the construction, installation or operation of telecommunications facilities within the municipality except as
provided within this article. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-2: APPLICATIONS:
Applications for permits to construct telecommunications facilities shall be submitted upon forms to be provided by the municipality and shall be
accompanied by drawings, plans and specifications in sufficient detail to demonstrate:
A. That the facilities will be constructed in accordance with all applicable codes, rules and regulations.
B. The location and route of all facilities to be installed on existing utility poles.
C. The location and route of all facilities to be located under the surface of the ground, including the line and grade proposed for the burial at all points
along the route which are within the public ways.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 687/702
D. The location of all existing underground utilities, conduits, ducts, pipes, mains and installations which are within the public ways along the route
proposed by the applicant.
E. The location of all other facilities to be constructed within the municipality, but not within the public ways.
F. The construction methods to be employed, including:
1. Provisions for protection of existing structures, fixtures, and facilities within or adjacent to the public ways.
2. Burial depths, markers, etc.
G. The location, dimension and types of all trees within or adjacent to the public ways along the route proposed by the applicant, together with a landscape
plan for protecting, trimming, removing, replacing and restoring any trees or other areas to be disturbed during construction. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-3: CONSTRUCTION PERMITS:
No person shall install, construct, or operate any telecommunications facilities within the municipality without first obtaining a construction permit.
A. No permit shall be issued to a licensee or franchisee for the construction or installation of telecommunications facilities within the municipality unless the
telecommunications carrier has complied with all liability, indemnification, insurance, and security provisions required under this chapter, unless
otherwise permitted under a license or franchise agreement.
B. No permit shall be issued to a franchisee or licensee for the construction or installation of telecommunications facilities without payment of all applicable
fees established in article F of this chapter, unless otherwise permitted under a license or franchise agreement.
C. No permit shall be issued to a franchisee or licensee for the construction or installation of telecommunications facilities in the public ways unless the
telecommunications carrier has applied for and received a license or franchise pursuant to article C or D of this chapter, unless otherwise permitted
under a license or franchise agreement.
D. No permit shall be issued to any person for the construction or installation of telecommunications facilities within the municipality unless the
telecommunications carrier has filed a registration statement with the municipality pursuant to article B of this chapter, unless otherwise permitted
under a license or franchise agreement.
E. All grantees are required to obtain construction permits for telecommunications facilities as required in this chapter, provided, however, that nothing in
this article shall prohibit the municipality and a licensee or franchisee from agreeing to an alternative plan review or permit and construction procedures
in a license or franchise agreement, provided that the village, in its sole discretion, determines that such alternative procedures provide substantially
equivalent safeguards for the liability, indemnification, insurance, and security provisions required under this chapter, and for responsible construction
practices. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-4: LOCATION OF FACILITIES:
All facilities shall be constructed, installed and located in accordance with the following terms and conditions, unless otherwise specified in a license or
franchise agreement:
A. A grantee shall install its telecommunications facilities within an existing underground duct or conduit whenever excess capacity exists within such utility
facility.
B. A grantee with permission to install overhead facilities shall install its telecommunications facilities on pole attachments to existing utility poles only, and
then only if surplus space is available.
1. All cables and wires or other work shall be installed parallel with existing wires whenever possible.
2. Multiple cable configurations shall be in parallel arrangement and bundled in accordance with engineering and safety considerations.
C. Whenever any existing electric utilities, cable facilities or telecommunications facilities are located underground within a public way of the municipality, a
grantee with permission to occupy the same public way must also locate its telecommunications facilities underground.
D. All wires and cables passing under the roadway shall be installed in conduit.
E. All underground burials shall be located approximately 2.5 feet below the surface unless otherwise agreed to or specified by the municipality.
F. Where not otherwise required to be placed underground by this chapter, the grantee's telecommunications facilities must be placed underground at the
request of the adjacent property owner, provided that the excess cost over arterial location shall be borne by the property owner making the request.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 688/702
G. Whenever any new or existing electric utilities, cable facilities or telecommunications facilities are located or relocated underground within a public way
of the municipality, a grantee that currently occupies the same public way shall relocate its facilities underground within a reasonable period of time,
which shall not be longer than ninety (90) days after the completion of the first underground installation.
H. Whenever new telecommunications facilities will exhaust the capacity of a public street or utility easement to reasonably accommodate future
telecommunications carriers or facilities, the grantee shall provide additional ducts, conduits, manholes and other facilities for nondiscriminatory access
to future telecommunications carriers.
I. The municipality shall have the right to have conduit, fiber optic and/or other communications cable, fixtures and appurtenances thereto necessary for a
municipal communications system collocated and constructed by the grantee within and/or attached to grantee's facilities being so constructed or
installed.
J. In complying with the requirements of subsection I of this section, the actual additional or marginal cost of materials and labor expended by the grantee
over and above that amount which the grantee would have expended solely for its own purposes shall be paid by the municipality. This payment may,
at the option of the municipality, be credited against the compensation payable by the grantee to the municipality.
K. If no space can be created within the requested route(s), the applicant may seek an exception to any requirements set forth in this section by submitting
a written request to the municipality for review. The municipality will consider situations which may warrant a variance, including, but not limited to:
1. Reduced environmental effect.
2. The lack of alternatives for achieving equivalent service.
3. The lack of alternative routing which can be made available.
4. The feasibility of alternative routes. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-5: COMPLIANCE WITH JULIE:
All grantees shall, before commencing any construction in the public ways, comply with all regulations of JULIE. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-6: COORDINATION OF CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES:
All grantees are required to cooperate with the municipality and with each other.
A. By February 1, of each year, grantees shall provide the municipality with a schedule of their proposed construction activities in, around or that may
affect the public ways.
B. Each grantee shall meet with the municipality or other grantees and users of the public ways annually or as determined by the municipality to schedule
and coordinate construction in the public ways.
C. All construction locations, activities and schedules shall be coordinated, as ordered by the municipal engineer or the director of public works, to
minimize public inconvenience, disruption or damages. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-7: CONSTRUCTION CODES:
Telecommunications facilities shall be constructed, installed, operated and maintained in accordance with all applicable federal, state and local codes,
rules and regulations including the national electrical safety code, national electrical code of the national board of fire underwriters, BOCA and the Illinois
administrative code 265 where applicable. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-8: ENGINEER'S CERTIFICATION:
All permit applications shall be accompanied by the certification of a registered professional engineer that the drawings comply with applicable technical
codes, rules and regulations. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-9: TRAFFIC CONTROL PLAN:
All permit applications which involve work on, in, under, across or along any public ways shall be accompanied by a traffic control plan demonstrating the
protective measures and devices that will be employed, consistent with the "Uniform Manual Of Traffic Control Devices", to prevent injury or damage to
persons or property and to minimize disruptions to efficient pedestrian and vehicular traffic. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-10: CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS:
All initial permit applications shall be accompanied by a manual or documents which set forth the specifications, standards and procedures for construction
and installation. Said specifications, standards and procedures shall be consistent with the highest standards of the telecommunications industry and shall
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 689/702
at a minimum, establish procedures to ensure quality work and provide for the safety and protection of residents, employees and property. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-
1996)
13-3G-11: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
Within forty five (45) days after submission of all plans and documents required of the applicant and payment of all applicable fees required under article F
of this chapter, the village engineer, if satisfied that the applications, plans and documents comply with all requirement of this chapter and other applicable
codes and regulations, shall issue a permit authorizing construction of the facilities, subject to such further conditions, restrictions or regulations affecting
the time, place and manner of performing the work as he may deem necessary or appropriate. However, in no event, shall the village engineer issue a
construction permit unless permitted under section 13-3G-3 of this article. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-12: CONSTRUCTION SCHEDULE:
The permittee shall submit a written construction schedule to the municipal engineer ten (10) working days before commencing any work in or about the
public ways. The permittee shall further notify the municipal engineer not less than two (2) working days in advance of any excavation or work in the public
ways. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-13: COMPLIANCE WITH PERMIT:
All construction practices and activities shall be in accordance with the permit and approved final plans and specifications for the facilities. The village
engineer and his or her representatives shall be provided access to the work and such further information as he or she may require to ensure compliance
with such requirements. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-14: DISPLAY OF PERMIT:
The permittee shall maintain a copy of the construction permit and approved plans at the construction site, which shall be displayed and made available for
inspection by the village engineer or representatives at all times when construction work is occurring. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-15: SURVEY OF UNDERGROUND FACILITIES:
If the construction permit specifies the location of facilities by depth, line, grade, proximity to other facilities or other standard, the permittee shall cause the
location of such facilities to be verified by a registered Illinois land surveyor. The permittee shall relocate, at permittee's expense, any facilities which are
not located in compliance with permit requirements. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-16: NONCOMPLYING WORK:
Upon order of the municipal engineer, all work which does not comply with the permit, the approved plans and specifications for the work, or the
requirements of this chapter, shall be removed at permittee's expense. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-17: COMPLETION OF CONSTRUCTION:
The permittee shall promptly complete all construction activities so as to minimize disruption of the municipal ways and other public and private property.
All construction work authorized by a permit within the municipal ways, including restoration, must be completed within one hundred twenty (120) days of
the date of issuance. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-18: AS BUILT DRAWINGS:
Within sixty (60) days after completion of construction, the permittee shall furnish the municipality with two (2) complete sets of plans, drawn to scale and
certified to the municipality as accurately depicting the location of all telecommunications facilities constructed pursuant to the permit. Said maps shall be
updated annually. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-19: RESTORATION:
Upon completion of any construction work, grantee shall, at its sole cost and expense, and in the manner reasonably approved of by the municipality or
the affected property owner in its/their sole judgment and discretion, as the case may be, promptly repair the public way, private property, or improvement
and restore the same to, as nearly as practicable, the condition existing prior to the performance of the work. Such restoration shall be completed within
ten (10) days after the date of commencement of such work.
A. In the event that such public way, private property, or improvement cannot be so repaired, replaced or restored, grantee shall cause the municipality or
the affected owner of the same as the case may be, to be justly compensated.
B. All restoration work within the public ways shall be done in accordance with landscape plans approved by the municipal engineer.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 690/702
C. Where any such destruction, damage or disturbance is not immediately discovered, or where any such restoration effort fails or is otherwise inadequate
or insufficient, grantee shall have a continuing obligation to perform all necessary restoration work, despite the prior termination or expiration of rights
granted.
D. In the event that restoration cannot be completed in the time allowed due to severe weather conditions, the grantee shall notify the municipality of the
locations of all pending restorations so affected. Weather related pending restorations shall be completed as soon as practicable. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-20: FAILURE, NEGLECT, OR REFUSAL TO REPAIR:
In the event of any failure, neglect or refusal by grantee, after ten (10) days' written notice from the municipality, to repair or provide just compensation for
such destruction, damage or disturbance as provided in this chapter, the municipality may, but shall be under no obligation to, do such work, or cause it to
be done, and the actual cost thereof as found and declared by the municipality, shall be paid by the grantee within thirty (30) days after demand therefor. If
the grantee fails to so reimburse the municipality, the municipality may collect the amount due from the security fund established pursuant to this chapter,
with or without court action. In withdrawing any amount due from the security fund under this section, the municipality will comply with subsection 13-3I-5D
of this chapter. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-21: SUBCONTRACTORS:
Any contractor, vendor, or agent assigned to work on the installation, maintenance or repair of the telecommunications system must be property licensed
under laws of the state of Illinois and all local ordinances, and be thoroughly experienced in underground conduit, fiber optic and cable installation,
installation on poles, or in any other capacity for which retained. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-22: INTERFERENCE WITH THE PUBLIC WAY:
No grantee may locate or maintain its telecommunications facilities so as to unreasonably interfere with the use of the public ways by the municipality, the
general public, or by other persons authorized to use or be present in or upon the public ways. All such facilities shall be moved by the grantee,
temporarily or permanently, as determined by the municipal engineer, at the grantee's expense. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-23: PUBLIC SAFETY:
A grantee shall use suitable barricades, flags, flagmen, lights, flares and other measures as required for the safety of all members of the general public
and to prevent injury or damage to any person, vehicle or property by reason of such work in or affecting such ways or property. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-24: NOTICE OF WORK:
Unless otherwise provided in a license or franchise agreement, no grantee, nor any person acting on the grantee's behalf, shall commence any
nonemergency work in or about the public ways of the municipality or other ways, without ten (10) working days' notice to the municipality. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-
1996)
13-3G-25: REPAIR AND EMERGENCY WORK:
In the event of an unexpected repair or emergency, a grantee may commence such repair and emergency response work as required under the
circumstances, provided that the grantee shall notify the municipality as promptly as possible, before such repair or emergency work, or as soon thereafter
as possible if advance notice is not practicable. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-26: MUNICIPAL WORK IN PUBLIC WAYS:
The municipality shall give the grantee no less than seven (7) days' advance written notice of street improvements or other activity which could affect the
telecommunications facilities. All such work shall be done, insofar as possible, in such a manner as not to obstruct, injure or prevent free use and
operation of the grantee's telecommunications facilities. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-27: RELOCATION OR REMOVAL OF FACILITIES:
Upon thirty (30) days' advance notice from the municipality, a grantee shall, at its own expense, temporarily or permanently remove, relocate, change or
alter the position of any telecommunications facilities within the public ways whenever the corporate authorities shall have determined that such removal,
relocation, change or alteration is reasonably necessary for:
A. The health or safety of the public or any person.
B. Correcting an aesthetically unacceptable installation.
C. The construction, repair, maintenance or installation of any municipal or public improvement in or upon the public ways.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 691/702
D. The operations of the municipal or other governmental entity in or upon the public ways. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-28: EMERGENCY REMOVAL OR RELOCATION OF FACILITIES:
The municipality retains the right and privilege to cut or move any telecommunications facilities located within the public ways as the municipality may
determine to be necessary, appropriate or useful in response to any public health or safety emergency at grantee's expense. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-29: AUTOMATIC AMENDMENT OF GRANT:
If ordered by the municipality to locate or relocate its telecommunications facilities into public ways not included in a previously granted license or
franchise, the municipality shall grant an amendment to the license or franchise without further application. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-30: TEMPORARY REMOVAL OF FACILITIES:
At the request of any person holding a valid building permit issued by the municipality or other appropriate governmental authority and upon reasonable
notice, depending on the circumstances, not exceeding thirty (30) days, grantee shall temporarily raise, lower or remove its facilities as may be necessary
to facilitate such move, subject to the payment, in advance, to the grantee, of the direct expenses of such temporary move by the permit holder, including
standby time. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-31: DAMAGE TO GRANTEE'S FACILITIES:
Unless directly and proximately caused by the wilful, intentional or malicious acts by the municipality, the municipality shall not be liable for any damage to
or loss of any telecommunications facility within the public ways of the municipality as a result of or in connection with any public works, public
improvements, construction, excavation, grading, filling, or work of any kind in the public ways by or on behalf of the municipality. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-32: CONSTRUCTION ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
Prior to initiating any construction activity on, over, under or through privately owned property, including utility easements, the grantee shall provide at least
five (5) days' advance notice of such work to the property owner, and if applicable, tenants of the property.
A. Such notice shall include, at a minimum:
1. A thorough description of the construction activity.
2. The date and time such work is expected to commence and the anticipated duration.
3. The name, address, and telephone number for a responsible representative of the grantee capable of answering questions and resolving all potential
disputes with the property owner. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-33: GRANT OF PRIVATE EASEMENTS:
The grantee shall secure the written consent of any subscriber or property owner on whose land or at whose premises the grantee conducts any
construction or installation outside of the easement. All easements, other than utility easements, constructed for the cable communications system shall be
recorded on plats of survey by the grantee. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-34: MINIMAL INCONVENIENCE:
The grantee shall complete all installation or construction to be performed at each subscriber's premises, including any installation of new equipment,
either within or outside a subscriber's premises, in one day. The grantee shall permanently secure and install, pursuant to all applicable local regulations,
including all requirements as to attachment of appurtenances, burial of cable and restoration, all cable drops and reception equipment at a subscriber's
location at the time of installation to the extent practicable. The desire of each subscriber as to the point of entry into their residence, common areas, or
business shall be observed to the maximum extent possible. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-35: TEMPORARY CABLES:
In the event a temporary cable or drop line is required, the grantee must permanently install and bury if necessary, the cable or drop line within ten (10)
days. In the event a temporary cable or drop line is required due to winter related conditions, the grantee must permanently install and bury, if necessary,
the cable or drop line within sixty (60) days of the first date that such installation is possible. At a minimum, all temporary cables or drops remaining from
winter shall be buried prior to Memorial Day weekend. The grantee shall pay the property owner twenty five dollars ($25.00) per day for every day a
temporary cable or drop remains unburied past the deadlines prescribed herein. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-36: APPURTENANCES:
The grantee shall securely attach all appurtenances, including on premises boxes, with sufficient appropriate fasteners so that the appurtenances may not
become loose or be removed without severe force. Location of such appurtenances shall be chosen to be consistent with electrical and telephone
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 692/702
appurtenances and blend with the aesthetics of the building and area whenever possible. No permanent or temporary fixture for the reception of cable
service may be attached to any structure without the express written consent of the owner or legal occupant of the structure. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-37: GROUND WIRES:
All ground wires shall be securely fastened to the building surface and routed in a way to prevent such wires from becoming a safety hazard, and in
compliance with all applicable codes. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3G-38: TREE TRIMMING:
Grantee shall not cut or trim any tree, shrub or vegetation on public property without first obtaining written authorization from the municipality or on private
property without written authorization of the owner of the tree, shrub or vegetation. All such trimming shall be performed in accordance with standard local
horticultural practices. The municipality reserves the option to have its employees perform the trimming, to require the grantee to hire a competent
professional to perform the work, or allow the grantee to perform the work under the supervision and direction of the municipality. Any such work shall be
performed at the grantee's expense. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
ARTICLE H. ADMINISTRATIVE
13-3H-1: BOOKS AND RECORDS:
The grantee shall maintain books and records of its operation within the municipality to show total revenues by service category in sufficient detail,
consistent with generally accepted accounting principles.
A. Grantee shall maintain all books and records required for regulation of rates by the appropriate governmental authority.
B. Grantee shall maintain such books and records for the municipality separate from any other operation, provided, however, that any expenses,
expenditures or revenues which apply to both the system in the municipality and any other operation shall be reasonably allocated between all such
operations.
C. Grantee shall keep appropriate records of all requests for installation of service, service calls, and outages, showing the date completed and any
corrective action taken. A summary of the above listed information shall be submitted to the municipality prior to the annual performance evaluation
meeting.
D. The required books and records shall be made available in the grantee's local office during normal business hours, for inspection and audit by the
municipality within thirty (30) days after such request has been made. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3H-2: DUTY TO PROVIDE INFORMATION:
The grantee shall submit to the municipality copies of all decisions, correspondence and actions by any federal, state and local courts, regulatory agencies
and other governmental bodies relating to its telecommunications operations within the municipality.
A. Copies of the grantee's schedule of charges, contract or application forms, subscriber user services, policies regarding the processing of subscriber
complaints, delinquent subscriber disconnect and reconnect procedures and any other terms and conditions adopted as the grantee's policy in
connection with subscriber or user services shall be filed with the municipality and updated as necessary, and shall be made available for public
inspection in the grantee's local office.
B. Copies of all correspondence, petitions, reports, applications and other documents filed by the grantee with federal or state agencies having jurisdiction
over telecommunications, or the same received from said agencies, shall be furnished simultaneously to the municipality by the grantee.
C. Within ten (10) days of a written request from the municipality, each grantee shall furnish the municipality with information sufficient to demonstrate:
1. That the grantee has complied with all requirements of this chapter.
2. That all municipal sales, message and/or telecommunications taxes or applicable franchise fees due the municipality in connection with the
telecommunications services and facilities provided by the grantee have been properly collected and paid by the grantee.
3. In addition to the annual filing required in section 13-3G-18 of this chapter, all books, records, maps and other documents, maintained by the grantee
with respect to those facilities within the public ways shall be made available for inspection by the municipality at reasonable times and intervals.
(Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
ARTICLE I. LIABILITY, INDEMNIFICATION, INSURANCE, AND SECURITY
13-3I-1: LIABILITY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 693/702
The grantee shall be responsible for:
A. Any damage or loss to any real or personal property of the municipality or any person, and for any injury to or death of any person, or officer, employee
or agent of the municipality arising out of or in connection with grantee's negligence or misconduct in the construction, installation, use, operation,
maintenance, repair, and/or removal of the telecommunications system, or its failure to act in connection therewith, when in the reasonable judgment of
the municipality, grantee should have taken certain action.
B. Grantee shall be liable for the acts or omissions of any entity used by the grantee, including an affiliate, when such entity is involved directly or indirectly
in the construction, installations, use, operation, maintenance, repair, and/or removal of the telecommunications system, as if the acts or omissions of
such entity were the acts or omissions of the grantee. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3I-2: INDEMNIFICATION:
Each license or franchise agreement shall include the following:
A. Grantee shall, and does hereby agree to, save, indemnify and hold the municipality, its corporate authorities, elected and appointed officials, officers,
boards, commissions, legal counsel, employees and agents harmless from any injury, claim, demand, suit, judgment, execution, liability, debt, damages
or penalty (the "claims") arising out of, resulting from, or alleged to arise out of or result from, grantee's negligence, including, but not limited to, its
failure to act, or misconduct in the construction, operation, maintenance, repair or removal of the telecommunications system, or the distribution of any
service over the telecommunications system, whether such acts or omissions are those of the grantee or its officers, employees, agent or contractors
and whether or not any such act or omission is authorized, allowed or prohibited by this chapter.
B. Grantee shall, and does hereby agree to, pay all expenses incurred by the municipality in defending itself with regard to any and all of the claims. These
expenses shall include all out of pocket expenses, such as attorney and expert fees, and shall also include the reasonable value of any services
rendered by any employee of the municipality. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3I-3: RELEASE AND WAIVER OF CLAIMS:
Grantee shall have no recourse against the municipality for any loss, expense or damage resulting from the terms and conditions of this chapter nor
because of the municipality's enforcement thereof. Grantee shall be deemed to expressly agree that it accepts this chapter relying solely upon its own
investigation and understanding of the power and authority of the municipality to grant the rights contained herein and that, in partial consideration of the
grant of such rights, grantee waives and releases the municipality from any and all claims of damages of any kind whatsoever, either known or unknown,
existing or future, which it may have in connection with any matter specified in this chapter, unless such damage is directly caused by the malicious or
intentional acts of the municipality. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3I-4: GRANTEE INSURANCE:
Unless otherwise expressly provided in writing in the license or franchise agreement, grantee shall procure and maintain for the duration of the license or
franchise, insurance against claims for injuries to persons or damages to property which may arise from or in connection with the license, franchise and/or
the performance of the work by the grantee, its agents, representatives, employees or subcontractors. The cost of such insurance shall be borne solely by
the grantee.
A. Minimum Scope Of Insurance: Coverage shall be at least as broad as:
1. Insurance services office commercial general liability coverage "occurrence" form CG 0001 (ed. 11/85) or insurance services office form number GL
0002 (ed. 1/73) covering comprehensive general liability and insurance services office form number GL 0404 covering broad form comprehensive
general liability or the most recent revision.
Please note endorsement CG 21 34 11 88, CG 21 39 11 88 or other such endorsement or policy provision which limits contractual liability shall be
deleted in its entirety.
2. Insurance services office business auto coverage form number CA 0001 (ed. 1/87) covering automobile liability, code 1 "any auto" and endorsement
CA 0029 (ed. 2/88) changes in business auto and truckers coverage forms - insured contract or insurance services office business auto liability
coverage form CG 0001 (ed. 10/90) symbol 01 "any auto".
3. Workers' compensation insurance as required by the labor code of the state of Illinois and employers liability insurance.
B. Minimum Limits Of Insurance:
1. Unless lower insurance limits are permitted under subsection B2 of this section, all grantees shall maintain limits no less than:
a. Commercial General Liability: Five million dollars ($5,000,000.00) combined single limit per occurrence for bodily injury, personal injury and
property damage. If commercial general liability insurance or other form with a general aggregate limit is used, either the general aggregate limit
shall apply separately to this project using the endorsement CG 25 03 11 85 or the general aggregate limit shall be no less than ten million dollars
($10,000,000.00) or the contractor shall furnish an owner's and contractor's protective liability policy ("OCP") meeting the terms and conditions of
this article, including, without limitation, regarding coverages, minimum amounts and types of coverage, acceptability of insureds, additional
insureds, cancellation and modification.
b. Automobile Liability: Three million dollars ($3,000,000.00) combined single limit per accident for bodily injury and property damage including
coverages for owned, hired or nonowned vehicles, as applicable.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 694/702
c. Workers' Compensation And Employers Liability: Workers' compensation limits as required by statute and employers liability limits of one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00) per accident and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per disease.
2. Grantees granted a license or franchise to install its telecommunications facilities only within existing conduit or duct in public ways and/or to run
wires or cables only on existing overhead utility poles shall maintain limits no less than:
a. Commercial General Liability: Three million dollars ($3,000,000.00) combined single limit per occurrence for bodily injury, personal injury and
property damage. If commercial general liability insurance or other form with a general aggregate limit is used, either the general aggregate limit
shall apply separately to this project using the endorsement CG 25 03 11 85 or the general aggregate limit shall be no less than five million dollars
($5,000,000.00) or the contractor shall furnish an owner's and contractor's protective liability policy ("OCP") meeting the terms and conditions of
this article, including, without limitation, regarding coverages, minimum amounts and types of coverage, acceptability of insureds, additional
insureds, cancellation and modification.
b. Automobile Liability: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit per accident for bodily injury and property damage including
coverages for owned, hired or nonowned vehicles, as applicable.
c. Workers' Compensation And Employers Liability: Workers' compensation limits as required by statute and employers liability limits of one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00) per accident and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per disease.
C. Deductibles And Self-Insured Retentions: Any deductibles or self-insured retentions must be declared to and approved by the village. At the option of
the village, either: the insurer shall reduce or eliminate such deductibles or self-insured retention as respects the district, its officers, officials,
employees, volunteers and agents; or the contractor shall procure a bond guaranteeing payment of losses and related investigations, claim
administration and defense expenses.
D. Other Insurance Provisions: The policies are to contain, or be endorsed to contain, the following provisions:
1. General Liability And Automobile Liability Coverages:
a. The village of Bartlett, its officers, officials, employees, volunteers and agents, are to be covered as additional insureds as respects: liability arising
out of activities performed by or on behalf of the grantee, including the insured's general supervision of its grantee; products and completed
operations of the grantee; premises owned, occupied or used by the grantee; or automobiles owned, leased, hired or borrowed by the grantee.
The coverage shall contain no special limitations on the scope of protection afforded to the village, its officers, officials, employees, volunteers and
agents.
b. The grantee's insurance coverage shall be primary insurance as respects the village, its officers, officials, employees, volunteers, and agents. Any
insurance or self-insurance maintained by the village, its officers, officials, employees, volunteers and/or agents shall be in excess of the
contractor's insurance and shall not contribute with it.
c. Any failure to comply with reporting provisions of the policies shall not affect coverage provided to the village, its officers, officials, employees,
volunteers, and agents.
d. The grantee's insurance shall contain a severability of interests/cross liability clause or language stating that the grantee's insurance shall apply
separately to each insured against whom claim is made or suit is brought, except with respect to the limits of the insurer's liability.
2. Workers' Compensation And Employers Liability Coverage: The insurer shall agree to waive all rights of subrogation against the village, its officers,
officials, employees, volunteers, and agents for losses arising from work performed by the grantee for the village and/or in village streets, highways,
public rights of way, utility easements and drainage easements.
3. All Coverages: The liability insurance policies required by this section shall be maintained by the grantee throughout the term of the
telecommunications license or franchise, and such other period of time during which the grantee is operating without a license or franchise, or
engaged in the removal of its telecommunications facilities. Each such insurance policy shall contain the following endorsement:
It is hereby understood and agreed that this policy may not be suspended or canceled, nor the intention not to renew be stated until ninety (90)
days after receipt by the Municipality, by certified mail, return receipt requested, of a written notice addressed to the Municipality of such intent to
suspend, cancel or not to renew.
Within sixty (60) days after receipt by the municipality of said notice, and in no event later than thirty (30) days prior to said suspension, cancellation
or failure to renew, the grantee shall obtain and furnish to the municipality replacement insurance policies meeting the requirements of this section.
E. Acceptability Of Insurers: Insurance is to be placed with insurers with a policy holder rating of no less than A- and a financial rating of no less than X in
the latest edition of the "Best Insurance Guide" and which insurance companies are licensed to do business in the state of Illinois. Each grantee shall
list the name of the insurance company or companies that will be providing such insurance, and the Best's rating thereof, on the license application
form. Failure to list the license applicant's or franchise applicant's insurance company(ies), policy holder rating(s), or financial rating(s) shall render the
license application or franchise application, as the case may be, incomplete.
F. Verification Of Coverage: Grantee shall furnish the village with certificates of insurance naming the village, its officials, officers, employees, volunteers
and agents as additional insureds, and with original endorsements effecting coverage required by this article. The certificates and endorsements for
each insurance policy are to be signed by a person authorized by that insurer to bind coverage on its behalf and shall be submitted in duplicate on
standard Acord forms. All certificates and endorsements are to be received and approved by the village before work commences. The village reserves
the right to require complete, certified copies of all required insurance policies, at any time. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3I-5: PERFORMANCE, CONSTRUCTION, AND PAYMENT SECURITY:
Before a construction permit may be issued pursuant to this chapter, and as necessary thereafter, the grantee shall provide and deposit monies, bonds,
letters of credit or other instruments, in form and substance acceptable to the municipality, to unconditionally guarantee full and complete performance of
the requirement imposed by this chapter, and payment for labor and material in connection therewith, or by an applicable license or franchise agreement.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 695/702
A. Security Fund: Each grantee shall establish a permanent security fund with the municipality by depositing the amount of the lesser of fifty thousand
dollars ($50,000.00) or ten percent (10%) of the estimated cost of constructing the telecommunications facilities, as certified by the applicant's engineer
and approved by the municipal engineer, with the municipality in cash, or an unconditional letter of credit, in form acceptable to the village, from a
federally regulated and federally insured financial institution with at least sixty million dollars ($60,000,000.00) in assets and a capital asset ratio of not
less than six percent (6%).
1. Provide that it shall not be canceled without the prior written consent of the municipality; and
2. Not require the consent of the grantee prior to the collection by the municipality of any amount covered by said instrument; and
3. Shall be maintained at the sole expense of the grantee so long as any of the grantee's telecommunications facilities are located within the public
ways of the municipality; and/or the grantee has acted, or failed to act, in a manner that would permit the municipality to withdraw from the security
fund under subsection C of this section, including, but not limited to, the failure of grantee to make necessary repairs.
B. Purpose: The security fund shall serve as security for:
1. The full and complete performance of this chapter, including any costs, expenses, damages or loss the municipality pays or incurs because of any
failure attributable to the grantee to comply with the codes, ordinances, rules, regulations or permits of the municipality.
2. The payment by grantee of all liens and taxes, and all damages, claims, costs or expenses that the municipality has paid or incurred by reason of
any act or default of the grantee, including, but not limited to:
a. Any restoration work that the municipality must perform itself or have completed as a consequence of grantee's failure to so perform or complete;
or
b. All other payments due to the municipality pursuant to this chapter.
C. Withdrawals: The municipality may withdraw from the security fund under the following circumstances:
1. Grantee fails to make any payment required to be made by the grantee under this chapter; or
2. Grantee fails to pay any taxes or liens relating to the telecommunications system that are due and unpaid; or
3. Grantee fails to pay the municipality any damages, claims, costs or expenses which the municipality has been compelled to pay or incur by reason of
any act or default of the grantee; or
4. Grantee fails to comply with any provision of this chapter that the municipality determines can be remedied by an expenditure of an amount in the
security fund.
D. Notice Of Withdrawal: Before any sums are withdrawn from the security fund, the municipality shall give written notice to the grantee:
1. Describing the act, default or failure to be remedied, or the damages, cost or expenses which the municipality has incurred by reason of grantee's
act or default;
2. Providing a reasonable opportunity for grantee to first remedy the existing or ongoing default or failure, if applicable;
3. Providing a reasonable opportunity for grantee to pay any monies due the municipality before the municipality withdraws the amount thereof from the
security fund, if applicable;
4. That the grantee will be given an opportunity to review the act, default or failure described in the notice with the municipality designee.
E. Replenishment: Grantee shall replenish the security fund within fourteen (14) days after written notice from the municipality that there is a deficiency in
the amount of the fund.
F. Interest: Any and all interest accrued on the amount in the security fund may be withdrawn by the grantee.
G. Closing And Return Of Security Fund: Upon any termination of the rights granted herein, other than a revocation, grantee shall be entitled to the return
of the security fund, or portion thereof as remains on deposit at such termination, and after account is taken for all offsets necessary to compensate the
municipality for the failure by grantee to comply with any provision of this chapter. In the event of any revocation of the rights granted herein, the
security fund, and any and all accrued interest therein, shall become the property of the municipality to the extent necessary to cover any costs, loss or
damage incurred by the municipality as a result of said revocation, provided that any amounts in excess of said costs, loss or damage shall be
refunded to the grantee.
H. Performance And Payment Bonds Or Letter Of Credit: Unless otherwise provided in a license or franchise agreement, the grantee shall furnish the
village prior to performing any work within the public ways, either: 1) a performance bond, and a labor and material payment bond, each cosigned by a
corporate surety licensed to do business in Illinois, with a management rating of at least A- and a financial rating of at least X in the latest edition of the
"Best Insurance Guide"; or 2) an irrevocable letter of credit issued by a federally regulated and federally insured financial institution with at least forty
million dollars ($40,000,000.00) in assets and a capital asset ratio of not less than six percent (6%) in form acceptable to the village, each in an amount
equal to at least one hundred percent (100%) of the estimated cost of constructing grantee's telecommunications facilities within the public ways of the
municipality, naming the village as the primary co-obligee, in form acceptable to the village.
1. The performance bond shall remain in force until sixty (60) days after substantial completion of the work, as determined by the village engineer,
including restoration of public ways and other property affected by the construction.
2. The performance bond or the letter of credit shall guarantee, to the satisfaction of the municipality:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 696/702
a. Timely completion of construction;
b. Construction in compliance with applicable plans, permits, technical codes and standards;
c. Proper location of the facilities as specified by the municipality;
d. Restoration of the public ways and other property, including municipal and private property, affected by the construction;
e. The submission of "as built" drawings after completion of the work as required by this chapter;
f. Timely payment and satisfaction of all claims, demands or liens for labor, material or services provided in connection with the work. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-
1996)
ARTICLE J. GENERAL PROVISIONS; VIOLATION
13-3J-0: COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER LAWS:
Nothing herein shall excuse any person or entity from obligations imposed under any law, including, but not limited to:
A. Generally applicable taxes; and
B. Standards for construction on, over, under, or within, use of or repair of the public rights of way, including standards relating to freestanding towers and
other structures upon the public rights of way, as provided; and
C. Any liability imposed for the failure to comply with such generally applicable taxes or standards governing construction on, over, under, or within, use of
or repair of the public rights of way; and
D. Compliance with any ordinance or provision of this code concerning uses or structures not located on, over, or within the right of way. (Ord. 97-90, 12-2-
1997)
13-3J-1: TECHNICAL STANDARDS:
All telecommunications providers, without limitation, within the municipality, whether located within the public ways, or not, shall, at all times, meet all
applicable standards and/or guidelines of the federal communications commission, and the Illinois commerce commission, and all other applicable federal,
state and community standards for the delivery of video, audio and data signals, whether directly regulated or not.
A. If subsequent regulations do not include these standards, they shall remain in full force and effect as if each were listed here until such time as the
municipality exercises its right hereunder to amend this chapter to require such standards as it shall deem necessary. In no event will subsequent
standards be less stringent than those in effect on the effective date hereof. This section will not apply if the municipality is preempted with respect to
the particular regulation in question by the ICC, FCC, or other governmental agency having authority over the particular regulation in question.
B. The grantee shall give notice to all subscribers at least seventy two (72) hours prior to the commencement of maintenance work in any area where such
activity is likely to cause a service interruption or other inconvenience. Such notice shall state the objectives of the maintenance work, the areas
affected by the maintenance work, the specific day and hours that disruption is possible, and a name and phone number of a person to contact for
further information.
C. All providers shall simultaneously file copies of all reports and correspondence required by all federal and state agencies charged with the oversight of
the grantee. In the event said agencies no longer enforce technical standards, grantee shall file reports with the municipality on a monthly basis
showing compliance with all technical standards. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-2: CONSUMER PROTECTION STANDARDS:
All telecommunications providers, without limitation, within the municipality, whether located within the public ways, or not, shall, at all times, meet all
applicable standards and/or guidelines of the federal communications commission, and/or chapter 1, section 730 of the Illinois administrative code of the
Illinois commerce commission, or subsequent regulations, and all other applicable federal, state and community standards relating to consumer protection,
whether directly regulated or not.
A. If subsequent regulations do not include these standards, they shall remain in full force and effect as if each were listed here until such time as the
municipality exercises its right hereunder to amend this chapter to require such standards as it shall deem necessary. In no event will subsequent
standards be less stringent than those in effect on the effective date hereof. This section will not apply if the municipality is preempted with respect to
the particular regulation in question by the ICC, FCC, or other governmental agency having authority over the particular regulation in question.
B. Unless otherwise agreed to in a license or franchise agreement, all providers within the municipality shall provide reports on a monthly basis showing
compliance with consumer protection standards. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-3: LEASED CAPACITY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 697/702
A grantee shall have the right, subject to applicable laws and regulations, without prior municipal approval, to offer or provide capacity or bandwidth to its
customers; provided:
A. Grantee shall furnish the municipality with a copy of any such lease or agreement.
B. The customer or lessee has complied, to the extent applicable, with the requirements of this chapter, including, but not limited to, the payment of all
applicable fees and taxes.
C. Cable providers shall set aside leased access capacity pursuant to federal law. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-4: AMENDMENTS:
The municipality may, acting in its sole discretion, amend a license or franchise agreement upon application of the grantee, when necessary to enable the
grantee to take advantage of technological advancements which will afford it an opportunity to more efficiently or economically serve its customers or
extend service to customers beyond previously authorized areas. The grantee shall reimburse the municipality for all of its costs, whether direct or indirect,
relating to any amendments sought by the grantee. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-5: ASSIGNMENTS OR TRANSFERS OF GRANT:
A. Except in the event of a merger, consolidation, or reorganization of the grantee, the grantee shall not have the right to assign its rights and privileges
under this chapter, or to otherwise transfer such rights or privileges in any manner whatsoever, without the prior written approval of the village.
B. In the event of a transfer or assignment of the grantee's rights and privileges under this chapter, all provisions of this chapter which are obligatory upon,
or which inure to the benefit of, the grantee shall also be obligatory upon and inure to the benefit of any and all successors and assigns of the grantee.
C. For all transfers or assignments of any right or privilege under this chapter, other than by merger, consolidation, or reorganization, grantee and the
proposed assignee or transferee of the grant or system, or part thereof, shall provide and certify the following information to the municipality not less
than one hundred fifty (150) days prior to the proposed date of transfer.
1. Complete information setting forth the nature, terms and conditions of the proposed transfer or assignment;
2. All information required of a telecommunications license or franchise pursuant to this chapter;
3. Any other information reasonably required by the municipality.
D. No transfer shall be approved unless the assignee or transferee has the legal, technical, financial, and other requisite qualifications to own, hold and
operate the telecommunications system pursuant to this chapter.
E. Unless otherwise provided in a license or franchise agreement, the grantee shall reimburse the municipality for all direct and indirect fees, costs, and
expenses reasonably incurred by the municipality in considering a request to transfer or assign a telecommunications license or franchise.
F. Any transfer of assignment or a telecommunications grant, system or integral part of a system, other than by merger, consolidation, or reorganization by
the grantee, without prior approval of the municipality under this section or pursuant to a license or franchise agreement shall be void and is cause for
revocation of the grant. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-6: TRANSACTIONS AFFECTING CONTROL OF THE GRANT:
Any transaction which singularly or collectively results in a change of ten percent (10%) or more of the ownership or working control of the grantee, of the
ownership or working control of a telecommunications license or franchise, of the ownership or working control of affiliated entities having ownership or
working control of the grantee or of a telecommunications system, or of control of the capacity or bandwidth of grantee's telecommunications system,
facilities or substantial parts thereof, shall be reported to the village, and all information reasonably requested by the village shall be provided by the
grantee. Transactions between affiliated entities are not exempt from this requirement. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-7: RENEWAL:
A grantee that desires to renew its license or franchise agreement shall file an application with the municipality not later than twenty four (24) months prior
to the expiration of its current license or franchise agreement.
A. The municipality shall review the performance of the grantee and assess community needs. A report shall be completed not later than twelve (12)
months prior to the expiration of the current license or franchise agreement.
B. The grantee shall file a preliminary proposal for changes sought in its license or franchise agreement not later than twelve (12) months prior to the
expiration of the current license or franchise agreement.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 698/702
C. During the final twelve (12) months of the current license or franchise agreement, the municipality and the grantee shall hold regularly scheduled
meetings until a final agreement is reached.
D. Any failure by the grantee to provide reasonably requested information in regards to renewal shall result in a denial of the request for renewal.
E. If necessary, the municipality may extend the license or franchise term in six (6) month increments during the renewal process, subject to applicable
law.
F. The grantee shall reimburse the municipality for all of its costs, whether direct or indirect, relating to any renewal proceeding, pursuant to article F of this
chapter. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-8: NONRENEWAL:
Subject to applicable law, if the municipality does not renew the license or franchise, the municipality shall, to the extent permitted by law, have the option
to:
A. Acquire at fair market value, all of the assets of the grantee's operations within the municipality, which value shall exclude any value attributable to the
license or franchise itself; or
B. Require the sale of all such assets to a succeeding grantee at the nonrenewing grantee's expense; or
C. Require removal of all such assets from the municipality at grantee's expense.
The municipality shall exercise such options within one year from the date of the license or franchise expiration. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-9: RENEWAL DETERMINATIONS:
The municipality shall issue a written determination granting or denying the renewal application in whole or in part, applying the following standards:
A. The legal, financial and technical ability of the applicant.
B. The continuing capacity of the public ways to accommodate the applicant's existing facilities, taking into account the quality of the applicant's service
and the ability of the telecommunications system to meet current and future community needs.
C. The applicant's compliance with the requirement of this chapter and the license or franchise agreement.
D. Applicable federal, state and local telecommunications laws, rules, policies and regulations.
E. Such other factors as may demonstrate that the continued grant to use the public ways will serve the community interest. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-10: OBLIGATION TO CURE AS A CONDITION OF RENEWAL:
No license or franchise agreement shall be renewed until any ongoing violations or defaults in the performance of the license or franchise agreement, or of
the requirements of this chapter, have been cured, or a plan detailing the corrective action to be taken by the grantee has been approved by the
municipality. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-11: VIOLATIONS:
The failure to comply with all applicable laws, codes, rules, and regulations of all governmental authorities, or the failure to comply with provisions of this
chapter constitutes a material breach of this chapter. The grantee shall as diligently as possible, but in no event later than thirty (30) days after delivery of
a violation notice by the municipality, correct such violation. If the violation constitutes a potential threat to the public, grantee shall correct the violation
within two (2) days after delivery of a violation notice. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-12: REVOCATION OR TERMINATION OF GRANT:
A license or franchise granted by the municipality to use or occupy public ways of the municipality may be revoked for the following reasons:
A. Construction or operation in the municipality or in the public ways at an unauthorized location.
B. Unauthorized substantial transfer of control of the grantee, assignment of a license or franchise, sale, assignment or transfer of grantee's franchise or
license assets, or a substantial interest therein.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 699/702
C. Misrepresentation or lack of candor by or on behalf of a grantee.
D. Abandonment of telecommunications facilities in the public ways.
E. Failure to relocate or remove facilities as required.
F. Failure to pay taxes, compensation, fees or costs when and as due the municipality.
G. Insolvency or bankruptcy of the grantee.
H. Violation of material provisions of this chapter, or the material terms of a license or franchise agreement.
I. Failure to comply with any applicable laws, rules or regulations. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-13: NOTICE AND DUTY TO CURE:
In the event that the municipality believes that grounds exist for revocation of a license or franchise, the municipality shall give the grantee written notice of
the apparent violation or noncompliance, providing a short and concise statement of the nature and general facts of the violation or noncompliance, and
providing the grantee a reasonable period of time not exceeding thirty (30) days to furnish evidence:
A. That corrective action has been, or is actively and expeditiously pursued, to remedy the violation or noncompliance, or
B. That rebuts the alleged violation or noncompliance, or
C. That it would be in the public interest to impose some penalty or sanction less than revocation. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-14: HEARING:
In the event that a grantee fails to provide evidence reasonably satisfactory to the municipality, the corporate authorities shall provide the grantee with
notice and a reasonable opportunity to be heard concerning the matter. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-15: STANDARDS FOR REVOCATION OR LESSER SANCTIONS:
If persuaded that the grantee has violated or failed to comply with material provisions of this chapter, or of a franchise or license agreement, the
municipality shall determine whether to revoke the license or franchise, or to establish some lesser sanction and cure, considering the nature,
circumstances, and the extent and gravity of the violation as reflected by one or more of the following factors:
A. Whether the misconduct or violation was flagrant.
B. Whether the misconduct or violation was intentional.
C. Whether substantial harm resulted.
D. Whether there is a history of prior violations.
E. Whether the violation was voluntarily disclosed, admitted or cured. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-16: TRESPASSING FACILITIES:
Any grantee, telecommunications carrier, or other person that owns, controls or maintains any unauthorized telecommunications system, facility or related
appurtenances within the public ways of the municipality shall be considered a trespassing facility under the following circumstances:
A. Upon expiration or termination of the grantee's license or franchise.
B. Upon abandonment of a facility within the public ways of the municipality.
C. If the system or facility was constructed or installed without the prior grant of a license or franchise.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=715 700/702
D. If the system or facility was constructed or installed without the prior issuance of a required construction permit.
E. If the system or facility was constructed or installed at a location not permitted by the grantee's license, franchise or permit. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-17: REMOVAL OF TRESPASSING FACILITIES AND OTHER REMEDIES:
Upon discovery of a trespassing facility, the municipality may, acting in its sole discretion, exercise one or more of the following options:
A. Order the immediate removal of the trespassing facilities from the public ways at grantee's expense; and/or
B. Seek to obtain penalties to the extent provided pursuant to this chapter; and/or
C. Seek other remedies available to the municipality under federal, state or local laws; and/or
D. Provide a thirty (30) day opportunity to cure if the municipality determines that the trespass was inadvertent, and the grantee is making a good faith
effort to remove or relocate the facilities promptly. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-18: PENALTIES:
Any person found guilty of violating, disobeying, omitting, neglecting or refusing to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less
than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. A separate and distinct offense shall be deemed committed each
day in which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-19: OTHER REMEDIES:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as limiting any judicial remedies that the village may have, at law or in equity, for enforcement of this chapter.
(Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-20: NOTICE TO GRANTEE:
The municipality shall not take any final action involving the evaluation, modifications, renewal, revocation or termination of the grantee's license or
franchise unless the municipality has:
A. Called a meeting for such purpose;
B. Advised the grantee in writing at least ten (10) days prior to such meeting as to its time, place and purpose; and
C. Published a notice, at least once, ten (10) days before the meeting in a newspaper of general circulation within the municipality. The grantee and any
interested persons shall be entitled to be heard at such meeting. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-21: NOTICES:
All notices and other communications in connection with this chapter shall be in writing, and shall be deemed delivered to the addressee thereof when
delivered in person at the address set forth in the license or franchise agreement, or three (3) business days after deposit in any main or branch United
States post office. All notices and communications in connection with this chapter that are sent by mail must be sent by certified or registered mail, return
receipt requested, postage prepaid, and properly addressed. (Ord. 96-6, 2-6-1996)
13-3J-22: DELEGATION OF POWERS:
Any right, power or duty of the municipality, its elected officials, employees, agents, or other representatives, may be transferred or delegated by
ordinance, resolution, or other appropriate action of the municipality to an appropriate officer, employee, department, or any legal authority, including any
intergovernmental agency created for the purpose of regulating the operation and development of telecommunications facilities and services. (Ord. 96-6,
2-6-1996)
Title 14
RESERVED
